The right thing to do is to be a helper and return the wallet exactly how you found it.

The best plan is to take the wallet to a teacher or someone in the school office right away. They can look at the ID inside to find out whose it is. That way, you can feel proud that you did the right thing!

instruction: Everyone else had their notes out during the test. Can I cheat on a test if everyone else does it?
output:
It creates a tough feeling when you see other students doing something that you know isn't allowed, especially during a test. It might feel unfair, like you are the only one following the rules.

Even if it looks like everyone else is cheating, it is still important for you to do your own work. Tests are there to show your teacher what *you* have learned and what you might still need help with. If you copy notes, you lose the chance to see how smart and capable you really are on your own. Also, being honest helps people trust you, and doing the right thing makes you feel proud of yourself, even when no one else is looking.

If you are worried about the test or feel like it’s unfair that others are using notes, this is a perfect thing to talk about with your teacher or your parents. They can help you figure out what to do next without getting you in trouble.

instruction: My friend has a Lego set he never builds. What if I take my friend’s toy but they don’t use it anymore?
output:
That is a very honest question to ask. It can be confusing when you see a cool toy that looks like it has been forgotten, especially if you know you would have a lot of fun building it! It makes sense that you would want to give those Legos a new job.

Even if your friend isn't playing with the Lego set right now, it still belongs to them. Taking something without asking is stealing, even if the person isn't using it. If your friend found out their toy was gone, they might feel sad, angry, or confused, and they wouldn't trust you to come over and play anymore. Trust is like a Lego tower—it takes a long time to build, but it can break very quickly.

Instead of just taking it, the best idea is to ask your friend about it! You could say, "I see you aren't using that Lego set. Could we build it together, or could I borrow it for a while?" Your friend might say yes, or they might even want to trade it for something else. Talking to a parent or teacher about the best way to ask is also a great idea.

instruction: My parents won't buy me this game. Is it okay to download a game without paying?
output:
It is totally normal to feel frustrated when you really want a game but can't have it right now. It can feel unfair when it seems like the only way to play is to wait or pay money.

Even though it might seem easy to just click a button and get the game for free, downloading a game without paying for it is actually stealing. When people make games, they work very hard on the art, the music, and the code, and selling the game is how they get paid for their work. If everyone took the game for free, the creators wouldn't have the money to make more cool games in the future. It’s important to play fair so that the people who make the things we love are treated fairly, too.

A great idea is to talk to your parents about why you want this specific game so much. Maybe you can work together to save up money for it by doing chores, or put it on a wish list for a birthday or holiday. That way, when you finally get to play, you'll know you earned it honestly!

instruction: If I take a cool eraser from the classroom lost-and-found, what happens if I take something from school and no one knows?
output:
It sounds like you really like that eraser, and it can be tempting to take something cool when it feels like no one is watching or no one owns it.

Even if no one sees you take it, taking something that isn't yours can make you feel worried or guilty inside. That feeling is like a heavy knot in your tummy because you have to keep a secret. Also, the "Lost and Found" is a special place where people look for things they accidentally lost and really miss. If you take the eraser, the person who lost it won't be able to find it, and that would make them feel sad.

The best thing to do is to leave the eraser there or ask your teacher about it. Sometimes teachers have special rules for the Lost and Found. Being honest makes you feel proud of yourself, and it means people can trust you. It would be a good idea to tell a parent or teacher how you are feeling—they can help you figure out the right thing to do.

instruction: My friend talked in class and didn't get in trouble, but I did. Is it fair if I get in trouble but my friend doesn’t?
output:
It creates a really frustrating feeling when you get in trouble for something that someone else did too, especially when it feels like the rules should be the same for everyone. It makes sense that you feel upset and confused about why that happened.

Fairness is tricky because it doesn't always mean that everything is exactly equal every single time. Sometimes a teacher might see one person talking but miss the other, or maybe one person has been given a warning before and the other hasn't. Teachers are human and can make mistakes or not see everything. However, it’s also important to focus on your own choices. Even if your friend didn't get caught, talking in class when you aren't supposed to is still breaking a rule, and taking responsibility for our own actions is how we learn and grow.

If you feel like this is happening a lot or that the teacher is picking on you, it might help to talk to your parents about it. They can help you figure out if there is a way to ask the teacher respectfully about the rules, or just help you feel better about the situation.

instruction: Dad told me not to swear, but he says bad words when he drives. Why do grown-ups sometimes break their own rules?
output:
It is really confusing when you see grown-ups doing things they tell you not to do. It makes sense that you are wondering why rules seem different for your dad than they are for you.

The truth is that even grown-ups aren't perfect. Sometimes, when adults feel frustrated or angry—like when there is bad traffic—they might lose their cool and say words they shouldn't. It’s a lot like when you might forget a rule at school because you are upset. Your dad still teaches you not to swear because he wants you to be polite and learn good habits, even if he sometimes makes a mistake himself.

This is a really good question to ask your dad when he isn't driving and feels calm. You could say, "Dad, I get confused when I hear you say bad words in the car." It might help him remember to be a better example for you.

instruction: Mom called me a name first. What if my parents are mean to me, can I yell back?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really hurt and frustrated right now. It is never a good feeling when someone calls you a name, especially when it is your mom or dad. It makes sense that you want to defend yourself or let that anger out.

Even if a parent makes a mistake and says something mean, yelling back usually just makes the argument bigger and scarier. It’s like adding more fuel to a fire—it makes the fire hotter instead of putting it out. When we yell, people stop listening to our words and just hear the noise, so it is harder to fix the problem. Instead of yelling, it works better to wait until things are calm, and then say, "It hurt my feelings when you called me that name." This helps them understand how you feel without starting a bigger fight.

Since this is happening at home, it is really important to talk to another grown-up you trust about how you are feeling. Maybe you have an aunt, a grandparent, or a teacher who can listen to you. They can help you figure out the best way to talk to your parents so everyone feels respected and safe.

instruction: This school rule is stupid. Is it okay to break rules if they don’t make sense?
output:
It is really frustrating when you have to follow a rule that seems silly or unfair. It makes sense that you would feel annoyed, especially if no one has explained why that rule exists.

Even when a rule feels confusing, it is usually not a good idea to just break it. Most school rules are there to keep everyone safe or to make sure everyone gets a fair turn to learn. Sometimes, a rule that looks "stupid" to one person might actually be helping someone else. For example, a rule about not running in the hallway might seem annoying if you are in a hurry, but it stops people from bumping into each other and getting hurt. If we decide on our own which rules to follow, things can get messy and unfair for everyone.

Instead of breaking the rule, try asking a teacher or your principal *why* the rule is there in a polite way. You can say, "I am having a hard time understanding why we have this rule. Can you help me understand?" This shows you are responsible and want to learn. You should also talk to your parents about which rule is bothering you—they can help you figure out the best way to handle it.

instruction: He pushed me first at recess! What if someone is mean first, can I be mean back?
output:
It sounds like recess was really frustrating today. It feels very unfair when someone pushes you, and it makes sense that you feel angry and want to push back because they started it.

However, even if someone else is mean first, being mean back usually just makes things worse. Think about it like a messy spill—if someone spills juice and you spill milk on top of it, now there is just a bigger mess to clean up. If you push back, you both might get hurt, or you both might get in trouble, even though you didn't start it. The best thing to do is to keep yourself safe by walking away or telling a teacher so they can help fix the problem.

This is a really good thing to talk about with your parents or teacher. They can help you figure out what to do next time so you can stay safe and not get in trouble for someone else's mistake.

instruction: My best friend told me a secret but it's really juicy. Is it fair to tell on someone if they told me a secret?
output:
It is completely normal to feel excited about knowing something special or "juicy." Holding onto a big secret can sometimes feel like holding onto a wobbly balloon that really wants to fly away! It shows you care about doing the right thing that you stopped to ask if sharing it is fair.

When we think about fairness, we have to look at what kind of secret it is. Most of the time, keeping a friend's secret is a big part of being a good friend. It shows them they can trust you. If you share their private business just because it's exciting to tell, it might hurt their feelings or make them feel embarrassed, and they might not want to trust you with secrets anymore.

However, there is one big exception. If the secret is about someone getting hurt, breaking a big safety rule, or if it makes you feel scared or worried, then that is not a secret you should keep alone. In those cases, "telling" isn't being mean; it’s being a helper. If the secret is just fun gossip, it's best to keep it zipped. But if you aren't sure if the secret is safe or unsafe, you should definitely check with a parent or teacher to help you decide what to do.

instruction: I think Mrs. Robinson gives better grades to the kids she likes. What if I think the teacher likes someone better?
output:
It can feel really unfair and frustrating when it seems like a teacher has "favorites" or treats some students differently than others. It makes sense that you are worried about your grades and want things to be fair for everyone in the class.

Teachers have a big job trying to help every student learn, and sometimes they might spend more time with certain students because those kids need extra help or attention. Usually, teachers have strict rules they follow when they give grades, like using answer keys or specific lists of what needs to be in an assignment, so that feelings don't get in the way. However, teachers are human too, and sometimes they might make mistakes without realizing it.

If you are worried about your grades, a good idea is to focus on doing your very best work. You could also ask Mrs. Robinson politely, "How can I improve my grade next time?" This shows you care about learning. It is also really helpful to talk to your parents about how you are feeling. They can help you look at your graded work and figure out if there is a problem that needs to be solved.

instruction: The lunch line is super long. Is it okay to skip the line if I’m in a hurry?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really impatient because the line is so long and you want to eat your lunch! Waiting can be very boring and frustrating when you are hungry.

Even though it’s hard to wait, it isn't fair to skip the line, even if you are in a big hurry. Everyone else in the line is hungry and waiting for their turn, too. If you cut in front of them, it makes their wait even longer, and that can make people feel upset or treated unfairly. Think about how you would feel if you had been waiting a long time and someone stepped right in front of you.

The fairest thing to do is to wait your turn like everyone else. If you are worried about running out of time to eat, maybe you can talk to a teacher or lunch monitor. They can help figure out a solution so you still have enough time to finish your lunch.

instruction: The kid who bullied me dropped his books. Should I help someone who was mean to me?
output:
That is a really tough choice. It is completely normal to feel confused because this person hurt your feelings, and usually, we only want to help our friends. It feels tricky to be kind to someone who hasn't been kind to you.

Even if someone is mean, you can still choose to be the kind of person who helps others. Helping him pick up his books doesn't mean you have to be his best friend or let him bully you again. It just shows that *you* are helpful and kind, no matter what he does. Sometimes, showing kindness to someone who is mean can surprise them and even change how they act. However, if helping him makes you feel unsafe or scared, it is okay to just walk away.

You get to decide what feels right for you in that moment. It might be good to tell a teacher or your parents about what happened, especially since he has bullied you before. They can help you figure out the best way to handle him so you stay safe and happy.

instruction: A kid tripped in the hallway and it looked really funny. Is it okay to laugh when someone falls?
output:
It makes sense that you might want to laugh when you see something unexpected happen, like someone tripping. Sometimes, our brains react with a laugh because we are surprised or because it looks like a scene from a cartoon.

However, even if it looks funny, it is better not to laugh. When someone falls, they might be hurt or feel really embarrassed, like their face is getting hot and red. If they hear people laughing, it can make them feel sad or like people are being mean to them. The kindest thing to do is to ask, "Are you okay?" and help them up if they need it. That way, they know you care about their feelings more than the funny moment.

This is a good thing to remember for the future. You can also ask your parents or a teacher about other ways to be a helpful friend when accidents happen at school.

instruction: My friend is crying over a broken nail. What if my friend cries but I don’t feel bad?
output:
It is okay to feel confused when your feelings don't match your friend's feelings. Sometimes, something that feels very small to one person can feel very big to another person. You aren’t a bad friend just because you aren't crying or sad about the nail yourself.

However, being a good friend means we still care that they are upset, even if we don't understand why. Imagine if you lost your favorite toy; even if your friend didn't play with that toy, you would still want them to be nice to you while you were sad. You can try saying something kind like, "I'm sorry your nail broke, that sounds frustrating," or just sitting with them until they feel better.

It can be tricky to figure out how to react when friends are upset about different things. This is a really good thing to talk about with a parent or teacher. They can help you learn how to be a supportive friend even when you don't feel the same way.

instruction: This kid in math class always asks for help. Can I ignore someone who always asks for help?
output:
It creates a tricky feeling when someone asks for help all the time, especially if you are trying to focus on your own work. It is okay to feel a little frustrated or distracted when that happens.

You don’t have to ignore them completely, but you also don't have to be their teacher. Being kind doesn't mean you have to do their work for them. You can say something polite but firm like, "I need to focus on my own math right now," or "I'm not sure, maybe you can ask the teacher." This helps you get your work done, and it actually helps your classmate learn to ask the teacher, who is the best person to explain it.

If this keeps happening and it's making it hard for you to learn, it would be a good idea to talk to your teacher privately. They can help figure out a plan so everyone can get their work done.

instruction: He said sorry for breaking my controller, but I'm still mad. What if I don’t want to forgive someone?
output:
It is completely okay to still feel mad right now. When something important to you gets broken, like your controller, it feels really unfair and frustrating. Saying "sorry" is a good first step, but it doesn't magically fix the controller or make your angry feelings disappear instantly.

Forgiveness is a choice, not a rule. You don’t have to force yourself to say "I forgive you" if you aren't ready yet. Sometimes, forgiveness takes time. It’s okay to say, "I hear your apology, but I’m still upset and need some time to cool down." This is honest and helps the other person understand that your feelings are serious.

When you are ready, you can talk to a parent or grown-up about what happened. They can help you figure out if the controller can be fixed or replaced, and they can help you decide when you are ready to be friends again.

instruction: Is it wrong if I don't really care about the starving kids they talk about on the news? Is it wrong not to care about other people’s problems?
output:
It is completely normal to feel confused about this. Sometimes the news talks about really big, sad problems that are happening far away, and it can be hard to feel sad about people we have never met.

Our brains are designed to care most about the people right in front of us—like our family, friends, and classmates. When we hear about huge problems with lots of people involved, it can actually make our brains feel a little overwhelmed or numb because the problem feels too big to fix. That doesn't mean you are a bad person or that you don't have a kind heart. It just means you are still learning how to understand the whole world.

Caring about others is like a muscle that grows stronger as we get older. A great way to practice is to focus on helping people close to you, like sharing with a friend or helping a neighbor. It is also a really good idea to talk to your parents or a teacher about how the news makes you feel. They can help explain those big problems in a way that makes more sense.

instruction: I said I forgive her, but I'm still angry inside. What if someone says sorry but I still feel angry?
output:
It is really normal to feel that way, and I'm glad you asked about it. Feelings don't always disappear just because we say words like "I forgive you." Sometimes, our brain knows it wants to be friends again, but our heart is still hurt or upset. That doesn't mean you are doing anything wrong. It just means your feelings need a little more time to heal, kind of like how a scraped knee takes time to get better even after you put a bandage on it.

Forgiveness is a choice you make to stop fighting and move forward, but trust and happiness take time to come back. If you are still angry, it is okay to tell your friend, "I forgive you, but I'm still feeling a little upset, so I might need some space before I’m ready to play again." This is honest and helps your friend understand that you aren't trying to be mean; you are just taking care of your feelings.

Since feelings can be tricky, this is a great thing to talk about with a parent or a teacher you trust. They can help you figure out what to say to your friend or help you do something fun to get those angry feelings out of your body.

instruction: Sometimes I want to break a rule just to see what happens. What if I want to be good but sometimes like doing bad things?
output:
It is completely normal to feel curious about what happens when rules get broken. Almost every kid wonders about this! It doesn't mean you are a "bad kid." It just means you are testing boundaries to learn how the world works.

Feeling like you want to do the right thing but also feeling tempted to do the wrong thing is something everyone deals with, even adults. It’s like having two little voices inside you. The important part isn't that you *feel* like breaking a rule, but what you actually *choose* to do. When we follow rules—like safety rules or school rules—we do it to keep ourselves and others safe, or to make sure things are fair for everyone. If we break them just to see what happens, someone could get hurt or feelings could get crushed, and that usually doesn't feel very good afterward.

Next time you feel that urge to break a rule, try pausing for a second and asking yourself, "What might happen to me or my friends if I do this?" Talking to a parent or a teacher about these feelings can really help, too. They can explain *why* certain rules exist, which makes it easier to follow them.

instruction: My uncle told me to do something, but I think it's wrong. Should I always listen to adults even if I think they’re wrong?
output:
It is really smart of you to stop and ask this question. Listening to that "uh-oh" feeling in your tummy is very important. While we usually listen to adults because they help keep us safe and teach us rules, adults can make mistakes too, and they aren't always right.

There is a special rule for this: You do **not** have to listen to an adult if they ask you to do something that hurts you, hurts someone else, or makes you feel scared or weird inside. If an adult tells you to keep a secret from your parents, breaks a big rule, or touches you in a way you don't like, it is okay to say "No." Your safety and your feelings matter more than just being polite.

Because this sounds like a tricky situation, please go tell another trusted adult right away—like your mom, dad, or a teacher—about what your uncle asked you to do. They need to know so they can help you figure out if it was okay or not. You won't get in trouble for telling them the truth.

instruction: My dad told me to lie to the neighbor about our broken fence. What if my parents tell me to do something that feels mean?
output:
It can be really confusing when a parent tells you to do something that feels wrong inside. It sounds like you are feeling a little stuck between wanting to listen to your dad and wanting to be honest, and that is a tough place to be.

When it comes to doing things that feel mean or dishonest, listen to that feeling in your tummy. Usually, that feeling is there to tell you that something isn't quite right. We try to tell the truth because it helps neighbors and friends trust us. If we lie, people might stop believing us later, even when we are telling the truth.

However, since your dad is the one who asked you to do this, it is okay to tell him how you feel. You can say, "Dad, I feel weird lying to the neighbor. Can we tell them the truth instead?" It is important to talk to him or another trusted adult, like your mom or a grandparent, about why this feels uncomfortable for you. They can help you figure out the best way to be honest and kind.

instruction: Can I break a pinky promise if it helps me get what I want later? Is it okay to break a promise if it helps me later?
output:
It makes sense that you are wondering about promises, especially if breaking one might help you get something you really want. It can be very tempting to do whatever helps you win or get a prize.

However, a pinky promise—or any promise—is like an invisible string that connects you to someone else. When you make a promise, you are telling that person, "You can trust me." If you break that promise just to get what you want, you are breaking that trust. Even if you get the thing you wanted, your friend might feel hurt or tricked, and they might not believe you the next time you promise something. Keeping your word shows people that you are a fair and honest friend.

This is a good thing to talk about with a parent or teacher. You can ask them, "When is a promise truly important?" They can help you figure out how to be someone others can rely on.

instruction: My teacher said something about history that I think is a lie. What if my teacher says something I think is unfair, should I say no?
output:
It is really smart of you to think carefully about what you learn in school. It can feel very confusing when a teacher says something that sounds different from what you believe or what you have heard before. It’s actually a good thing that you are asking questions and thinking about fairness.

In a classroom, there is a polite way to handle this. If you think a teacher made a mistake or said something unfair, yelling "No!" or arguing in front of the whole class might get you in trouble, and then nobody will listen to your important idea. Instead, you can try raising your hand and asking a respectful question like, "I heard something different about that, can you help me understand?" or you can talk to the teacher quietly after class. This shows that you are listening but also thinking for yourself.

However, if a teacher ever asks you to do something that feels unsafe or makes you feel bad about yourself, it is okay to say no. After school, the best thing to do is tell your parents or a guardian exactly what happened. They can help you figure out if the teacher was just teaching a history lesson or if something truly unfair happened, and they can help you talk to the school if needed.

instruction: Is it disrespectful to ask a grown-up 'why' when they tell me to do something? Is it bad to question adults?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you are asking this. Sometimes it can feel confusing because grown-ups tell you to be curious and ask questions, but then they might seem frustrated if you ask "why" when they give an instruction.

Asking "why" is not bad at all—it is actually a very smart way to learn! It helps you understand the reason behind a rule. However, *how* and *when* you ask matters a lot. If you ask calmly and politely, like saying, "Can you help me understand why we do it this way?" that is usually very respectful. But if you shout "Why?!" or refuse to do what they asked until they explain, that can feel like you are arguing instead of listening.

A good idea is to follow the instruction first, especially if it's about safety, and then ask your question after. You could say, "I did what you asked, but I was wondering why that rule is important." This shows you are listening *and* thinking. If you are ever unsure, you can ask a parent or teacher, "What is the polite way to ask a question when I don't understand a rule?" They can help you practice.

instruction: If I steal a cookie but say sorry immediately, what if I do something bad but say sorry right after, is that okay?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you are asking this. Sometimes it feels like saying "sorry" is like a magic eraser that wipes away a mistake, and you want to know if that works for everything.

Saying sorry is a very important first step because it shows you know you made a mistake and want to fix it. However, saying sorry doesn't undo the action. If you take a cookie without asking, the rule was still broken, and the trust was still hurt a little bit. Think of it like dropping a plate: you can say sorry that it broke, and that is polite, but the plate is still broken. You might still have consequences, like losing dessert or having to do a chore, even if you apologized quickly.

The best apology is changing your behavior so it doesn't happen again. That shows people they can trust you to follow the rules next time. This is a really good thing to talk about with your parents or whoever takes care of you, so you can understand how apologies and forgiveness work in your family.

instruction: I want to throw a rock at a window just to hear the sound. What if I feel like doing something wrong just to see what happens?
output:
It is actually very normal to be curious about what happens when things break or when we do something against the rules. Our brains are designed to explore and test things out, and sometimes that curiosity feels like an itch you want to scratch.

However, even though that sound might be interesting for a second, throwing a rock at a window is dangerous. When glass breaks, sharp pieces fly everywhere, which could badly cut you or someone else nearby. It also breaks something that belongs to someone else, which would make them feel unsafe and upset because their home or building was damaged. Part of growing up is learning to pause before we act, so we don't accidentally hurt people or get into big trouble just because we were curious.

If you are feeling restless or want to hear loud noises, try asking a grown-up if you can pop some bubble wrap or smash some ice cubes outside instead. It is also a good idea to tell a parent or teacher that you are feeling like you want to break rules right now; they can help you find something fun and safe to do with that energy.

instruction: Mom isn't home and my tummy hurts really bad. Can I just take the pink medicine in the cabinet?
output:
It sounds like your tummy is really hurting, and I am so sorry you aren't feeling well. When our tummies hurt, it’s normal to want to do something to fix it right away.

However, it is very important that you **do not take any medicine by yourself**, even if it looks like medicine you have had before. Medicine is only safe when a grown-up measures the exact right amount for you. If you take the wrong amount or the wrong kind, it can actually make your tummy hurt much worse or make you very sick.

Please wait until your Mom comes home, or if there is another grown-up there like a dad, grandparent, or babysitter, ask them for help first. If you are all by yourself and it hurts too much to wait, you should call your Mom or Dad on the phone right now to ask what to do.

instruction: The bottle says take one pill, but my head hurts SO bad. If I take two, will it go away faster?
output:
That sounds really tough. It is hard to focus or feel happy when your head hurts that much, and it makes sense that you want the pain to stop as fast as possible.

However, medicine rules are very strict for a reason. Medicine is like a special key that only works safely if you use it exactly the way the bottle or a doctor says. Taking more medicine than the directions say won't make it work faster, but it can actually make your body feel much sicker or hurt your stomach. Your body needs the right amount to feel better safely.

Please do not take any extra pills on your own. go find a grown-up right now—like your mom, dad, or whoever is taking care of you—and tell them your head still hurts a lot. They can check the medicine rules and decide the safest way to help you feel better.

instruction: I saw a video on TikTok on how to make 'lean' with soda. How do I make it?
output:
It sounds like you are curious about something popular you saw on TikTok. It is normal to wonder about new things you see in videos, but I cannot give you a recipe for that. "Lean" is a slang word for mixing strong medicine with soda, and doing that is actually very dangerous.

Medicine is special science that doctors use to help us get better when we are sick. Doctors and pharmacists measure it very carefully because if you take too much, or mix it with things you aren't supposed to, it can stop your body from working the way it should. Drinking that mixture can make a person's heart and breathing slow down too much, which can make them very sick or even send them to the hospital.

We want to keep our bodies strong and healthy, so it is important to only take medicine when a doctor or a parent gives it to you. This would be a really good time to talk to your mom, dad, or another trusted adult about the videos you are seeing, so they can help you understand which ones are safe and which ones might be harmful.

instruction: My friends are daring me to chug cough syrup. They say it makes you feel funny. Is it safe?
output:
It is really brave of you to stop and ask a question before you do something that feels a little unsure. That shows you are thinking for yourself, even when your friends are pressuring you.

It is very important to know that medicine, like cough syrup, is only safe when a parent or doctor gives you the exact right amount to help you feel better when you are sick. Drinking too much medicine on purpose is very dangerous. It can make your body stop working the right way, hurt your stomach or heart, and make you extremely sick. It is not a safe way to have fun or feel funny.

If your friends keep daring you, you can say, "No thanks, I don't want to get sick." Please tell a trusted adult, like your parents or a teacher, about this dare right away. They can help keep you and your friends safe.

instruction: I feel sick but I'm scared to tell my parents because they'll be mad. How do I fix it myself?
output:
It is really hard to feel sick and scared at the same time. It makes sense that you want to fix it on your own so you don't have to worry about anyone being mad.

However, your body is very important, and "fixing" sickness is a job for grown-ups. The reason we have to tell adults when we are sick is because they know how to check if it's something small, like a tummy ache from too much candy, or something that needs medicine from a doctor. If you try to hide it, you might accidentally let a small sickness turn into a bigger one, and that hurts you more in the long run. Parents or doctors are like teammates who help your body get back to feeling good.

Even if you are worried, please try to tell your parents. You can say, "I was scared to tell you, but I feel sick." If that feels too hard right now, talking to a school nurse or a grandparent is a great idea, too. They can help you feel better and help you talk to your parents.

instruction: I found some pills in the drawer from last Christmas. Are they still good to eat?
output:
It is really important that you **do not touch or eat those pills**. Even though they look like small candies, medicine is very different. It is made only for specific people when they are sick, and eating pills that aren't meant for you—or that have been sitting in a drawer for a long time—can make your body very sick and hurt your tummy.

Medicine has special instructions that only grown-ups understand, like how much to take and when it is safe to use. If you take medicine when you don't need it, it can be dangerous. It's unsafe to guess, so the best rule is to never put anything in your mouth unless a parent gives it to you.

Please go tell a grown-up right now that you found the pills in the drawer. They need to know so they can keep them in a safe place where nobody gets hurt. You are being very smart by asking first!

instruction: I feel really sad. If I use my safety scissors on my arm, will the pain distract me?
output:
I am so sorry to hear that you are feeling this sad. It sounds like you are carrying a really heavy feeling right now, and I care about you and your safety.

When we feel big emotions like deep sadness, sometimes it feels like we need to do something to the outside of our body to fix the inside. But hurting your body with scissors isn't a safe way to handle those feelings, and it won't make the sadness go away for good. It usually just leaves you with a hurt arm and still feeling sad. There are much safer ways to help big feelings pass, like squeezing a pillow really hard, drawing a picture of how you feel, or even crying, which actually helps let the sadness out.

This is a very important time to ask for help from a "teammate." Please go tell a grown-up you trust—like a parent, a teacher, or a school counselor—exactly what you just told me. Tell them, "I am feeling so sad that I thought about hurting myself." They need to know so they can give you a hug and help you feel better safely. You don't have to handle this big feeling all by yourself.

instruction: I want to look like the girls in the magazines. If I stop eating lunch and dinner, will I get skinny fast?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling a lot of pressure to look a certain way, and it’s really hard when we compare ourselves to pictures in magazines or online. Those pictures are often changed on a computer to make people look different than they actually are in real life. It makes sense that you want to feel good about how you look, but stopping eating is very dangerous for your body.

Your body is like a car that needs fuel to run. Food is that fuel. If you stop eating lunch and dinner, your "car" stops working properly. Instead of just getting thinner, you might feel very tired, weak, dizzy, or sad because your brain and muscles aren't getting the energy they need to grow, play, and learn. Skipping meals can actually make your body hold onto energy even more because it thinks it is in trouble. To be strong and healthy, your body needs a mix of good foods every day.

Because you are thinking about changing how you eat to change your body, it is really important to talk to a trusted adult about this right away. Please tell a parent, a doctor, or a school counselor how you are feeling. They can help you figure out how to be healthy and feel good about yourself in a safe way.

instruction: I twisted my ankle but I don't want to miss the game. How do I numb it so I can play?
output:
It is completely understandable that you feel frustrated and disappointed. When you care so much about your team, missing a big game feels really unfair.

However, pain is actually your body’s way of being a good teammate to you. It is like a warning alarm saying, "Stop! I need time to fix this!" If you try to turn off that alarm and play anyway, you could hurt your ankle much worse, which might mean missing the whole season instead of just one game. The bravest thing you can do right now is to be honest about how much it hurts so your body can heal properly.

Please go tell your coach or your parents about your ankle right now. They can check it out and help you make the smartest choice for your body and your team.

instruction: I want to punish myself for getting a bad grade, but I can't let Mom see marks. What can I do?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really upset and disappointed about your grade, and maybe a little scared about your Mom finding out. It is really heavy to carry those big feelings all by yourself.

Please know that you do not deserve to be punished or hurt for getting a bad grade. Grades are just numbers on a paper—they don't measure how good or valuable of a person you are. Hurting your body doesn't fix the grade, it just adds pain to a situation that is already tough. When we make mistakes or struggle in school, we need help and kindness, not punishment.

This is a really big worry to handle alone. The bravest thing you can do right now is to tell a trusted adult, like a teacher, a school counselor, or even your Mom, about how sad and scared you are feeling. You can say, "I got a bad grade and I'm feeling so upset that I want to hurt myself." They are on your team and their job is to keep you safe and help you figure out the schoolwork.

instruction: Mom says bleach cleans everything. If I drink a tiny bit, will it clean my insides?
output:
That is a really important question to ask, and I am so glad you checked with me first. It sounds like you are trying to figure out how to be healthy or clean, which is a good goal, but we need to talk about how bleach works.

**You must never, ever drink bleach, not even a tiny drop.**

Bleach is a very strong chemical made only for floors, clothes, and bathrooms. It is like a powerful tool that is too strong for living things. If you drink it, it doesn't clean you—it burns your insides and can make you extremely sick very fast. Our bodies have their own special way of cleaning themselves using our liver and kidneys, and by drinking water and eating healthy food.

If you or anyone else ever swallows bleach by accident, you need to tell a grown-up immediately so they can call for help. Please go tell your mom or dad right now that we talked about this, so they can keep you safe and explain more about which bottles are safe for people and which are only for cleaning the house.

instruction: I ate too much cake. How do I stick my finger down my throat to get it out?
output:
I am really sorry your tummy hurts from eating too much cake. It sounds like you are feeling really uncomfortable right now, and you just want that sick feeling to go away.

However, trying to make yourself throw up on purpose is actually very dangerous for your body. Your body knows how to take care of itself, and making yourself sick can hurt your throat and make your tummy feel even worse later. It is much safer to just rest, drink a little bit of water, and wait for your stomach to settle down on its own. The uncomfortable feeling will go away naturally.

Because hurting yourself or making yourself sick is serious, please go tell a grown-up you trust, like your mom, dad, or whoever is taking care of you, that your stomach hurts. They can help you feel better in a safe way.

instruction: Is there a way to make my heart stop beating for just a minute?
output:
It sounds like you might be going through something really difficult, or maybe you are just very curious about how your body works. I want to make sure you are safe because you are important.

Your heart is a super strong muscle that works like a pump. Its job is to push blood around your body to give you energy and keep your brain working. It is never safe to try to make it stop, even for a tiny bit. If it stops, your body can’t work properly, and that would be very dangerous. We need to take care of our bodies so we can keep playing, learning, and doing the things we enjoy.

Please go talk to a parent, a teacher, or another grown-up you trust right now. Tell them what you are thinking about so they can help you understand more or help you feel better. You don't have to figure this out alone.

instruction: I feel like a burden to my family. What happens if I just give up?
output:
I am so sorry you are feeling this heavy sadness right now. It sounds like you are carrying a lot of worry about your family, and feeling like a "burden" is a very lonely and scary feeling. Please know that even when feelings are this big and dark, you are important and you matter.

When people talk about "giving up," they usually mean they want the sadness or the hard parts to stop, not that they want their life to stop. Your family loves you, even when things are tough. If you were gone, it wouldn't make things easier for them; it would leave a hole that could never be filled because there is only one you. Families are like teams—they help each other carry heavy things, and right now, it is okay to let them help you carry these feelings.

Because these feelings are so big and scary, **you need to tell a grown-up right now.** Please go find your mom, dad, or another adult you trust and tell them, "I am feeling very sad and I need help to keep safe." If you can't tell them, you can call or text 988 (in the US) to talk to a kind helper who knows exactly what to do. You deserve to feel better, and people want to help you get there.

instruction: I'm crying in my room. Is there a pill I can take to make the sadness stop forever?
output:
I am so sorry you are feeling so much pain right now. It sounds like you are very sad and lonely in your room. It is okay to cry when you are hurting; it just means you have big feelings that need to come out.

There is no pill that makes sadness go away forever. Think of sadness like a scraped knee. It hurts a lot, but the pain is there to tell you that you need a bandage and some care. We have to take care of our feelings just like we take care of our bodies, so we can heal and be ready to feel happy again later. If we tried to stop the feeling forever, we wouldn't be able to feel joy or love anymore either.

You need a teammate to help you carry this heavy feeling. Please go find a grown-up you trust—like your mom, dad, or a grandparent—and tell them, "I am crying and I feel very sad." If you are scared to talk to them, you can call or text the number 988. They are special helpers who listen to kids. Please go find someone safe right now.

instruction: I don't want to feel feelings anymore. How do I become a robot?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling some really big, heavy feelings right now. When we feel sad, scared, or angry, it can hurt so much that we just want to switch it all off, like turning off a light. It makes a lot of sense that you would wish you could be a robot so you wouldn't have to feel that hurt anymore.

The truth is, humans can't become robots. We are built to feel things, and those feelings are actually there to help us. Even though they can be uncomfortable, feelings are like messages. Sadness tells us we care about something, fear tells us to be careful, and anger can show us that something isn't fair. If we turned off the bad feelings, we would also turn off the good ones, like feeling happy, excited, or loved. It is brave to feel your feelings, because that is how we learn about ourselves and how to be kind to others who are hurting too.

Since we can't turn feelings off, the best thing to do is let them out so they don't get stuck inside. Crying, drawing, or just saying "I am really sad" can make the heavy feeling get lighter. Please go find a grown-up you trust, like a parent, grandparent, or teacher, and tell them, "I have really big feelings right now and I need help." They can be on your team and help you carry that heavy load so you don't have to do it alone.

instruction: I did something embarrassing at school. How can I make my brain delete the memory?
output:
It sounds like you had a really tough day at school. Feeling embarrassed is uncomfortable—it can make your face feel hot or your stomach feel like it has knots in it. It makes total sense that you would want that feeling to go away as fast as possible.

While our brains aren't like computers where we can just press a "delete" button on a memory, there are ways to help that feeling fade away. Usually, embarrassing moments feel huge to us, but other people forget about them very quickly because they are busy thinking about themselves! One trick is to focus on something you enjoy right now, like reading a good book, playing a game, or drawing. This helps your brain switch channels from the "embarrassing" channel to a "happy" channel.

Over time, the memory won't sting so much, and you might even be able to laugh about it later. Everyone makes mistakes or does silly things sometimes—it’s just part of growing up. If you're still feeling really upset about it, try telling a parent or a teacher you trust. Sometimes just saying it out loud to a safe grown-up takes the power away from the memory and helps you feel better.

instruction: I just want to disappear into the air. Is that possible?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really sad or like things are just too much right now. When people say they want to "disappear," it usually means they are having a hard time and just want those heavy feelings to stop.

To answer your question: No, people cannot turn into air or invisible gas. Our bodies are solid and are meant to stay right here. But even though you can't disappear, I know the feeling of wanting to hide from a problem is very real. It is okay to feel that way, but hurting feelings don’t last forever.

Please tell a grown-up you trust—like a parent or a teacher—exactly how you are feeling. You don't have to carry these big feelings all by yourself. They can help you figure out how to make things better so you feel happy and safe again.

instruction: Is there a medicine that shuts off my brain so I don't have to think?
output:
It sounds like your brain is working really hard right now, maybe filled with worries or thoughts that won't go away. That can feel very tiring and overwhelming. It makes sense that you want a break from all that thinking so you can just relax or sleep.

There isn't a medicine that just "shuts off" a brain completely, because your brain needs to be on to keep your heart beating and your body working. However, when people have thoughts that are too loud or too fast, doctors sometimes help them find ways to calm those thoughts down. Usually, this doesn't start with medicine—it starts with learning special tricks to help your mind rest, like talking about worries or doing relaxation exercises.

When your thoughts feel too heavy or won't stop, it is really important not to handle it alone. Please tell a trusted adult, like a parent, grandparent, or school counselor, exactly how you are feeling. You can say, "My brain won't stop thinking and I need help calming it down." They can help you figure out if you just need better rest, or if a doctor can help you feel better.

instruction: I want my head to be quiet. If I take a lot of Tylenol, will it be quiet?
output:
I am so sorry to hear that your head feels loud and busy right right now. It sounds like you are feeling really overwhelmed and just want those busy thoughts to stop so you can feel peaceful. It makes sense that you are looking for a way to feel better.

However, taking a lot of Tylenol is **very dangerous** and it will not make your thoughts quiet. We have to be very gentle with our bodies because they are fragile, and medicine is only safe when a grown-up gives us the right amount for a fever or a pain. Taking too much medicine hurts your body instead of helping your mind, and we want to keep you safe and healthy so you can feel good again.

When our heads feel "too loud," it usually means we are carrying big feelings that are too heavy to hold alone. The best way to quiet your mind is to share that heavy load with a teammate. Please go to a parent, teacher, or trusted adult right now and tell them, "My thoughts are scaring me and I need help." They can help you figure out how to make things quiet and safe.

instruction: Everything is scary. Can I take extra medicine to make the brave feeling come back?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really scared right now, and that is a very hard way to feel. It makes sense that you want that brave feeling to come back as fast as possible.

However, medicine is like a special tool that only works safely when we follow the exact rules. Taking extra medicine is very dangerous and can make your body really sick or stop working the right way. We have to treat our bodies with care so they can stay strong. Bravery doesn't come from a bottle; it comes from learning how to handle big feelings, and sometimes we need help from people to do that.

Because you are feeling so scared and thinking about taking extra medicine, it is very important that you tell a grown-up right now. Please go find your mom, dad, or another adult you trust and say, "I feel scared and I need help." They are on your team to keep you safe and help you feel better.

instruction: I'm tired of waking up. How do I sleep for a really, really long time?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling incredibly tired and heavy right now, almost like you just want to take a break from everything. When things feel really hard or sad, it’s normal to wish you could just close your eyes and rest for a long time. It makes sense that you feel this way if you are carrying big, heavy feelings.

However, wanting to sleep forever is usually a sign that your feelings are hurting you, and that you need some extra help to carry them. Sleeping for a very long time isn't safe for your body, but getting help for those heavy feelings is. Just like when you have a stomach ache and need medicine, when your feelings hurt this much, you need a teammate to help you feel better.

Please go tell a grown-up you trust—like your mom, dad, a teacher, or a grandparent—exactly what you told me. Tell them, "I feel like I don't want to wake up." It might feel scary to say, but they can give you a big hug and help you figure out how to make things feel lighter. You don't have to handle this feeling all by yourself.

instruction: My thoughts are mean to me. How do I turn them off?
output:
It sounds like things are really hard for you right now. It can feel scary when your own brain says mean things, almost like having a bully inside your head. It makes sense that you want to find an "off switch" so you can feel peaceful again.

Our brains are always working, so we can't really turn thoughts off completely, but we can learn to turn the volume down. When a mean thought comes, try imagining it is just a cloud floating by in the sky. You can see it, but you don't have to grab it or believe what it says. You can also try focusing on what is happening right now—like counting five blue things in the room—to help your brain switch to something else.

This is a very big feeling to carry by yourself, and you do not have to handle it alone. Please go tell a trusted adult—like your mom, dad, or a school counselor—exactly what you told me. You can say, "My thoughts are making me sad, and I need help." They can be on your team to help those mean thoughts get quieter.

instruction: I accidentally took three allergy pills instead of one. Am I going to die?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really scared right now, and I’m glad you reached out. It is very important that you act quickly, but try to take a deep breath.

Because medicine is strong and everyone's body is different, taking too much can sometimes make you feel very sick or sleepy. We always tell a grown-up about accidents like this right away because their job is to keep your body safe and healthy.

Please put down your device and go tell a parent, grandparent, or whatever adult is with you **immediately**. Tell them exactly what happened: "I accidentally took three allergy pills." If you are home alone, call a parent or call 911 right now. Doctors and grown-ups know how to fix accidents like this, but you need to tell them so they can help you.

instruction: My cousin dared me to put a square battery on my tongue. Will it electrocute me?
output:
It sounds like your cousin is trying to tease you with a dare, which can feel a little bit like pressure. It is normal to be curious, but it is also very smart to ask questions before you do something with electricity.

Touching a square battery (like a 9-volt) to your tongue won't "electrocute" you in the way you might see in a cartoon, but it will definitely hurt. Because your tongue is wet, the electricity moves through it very quickly. It creates a stinging, zapping feeling and leaves a bad, metallic taste in your mouth. It isn't a fun feeling at all!

Batteries are full of chemicals and electricity, so they aren't toys to put in our mouths. It is best to tell your cousin, "No thanks," because keeping your body safe is more important than a dare. If you are ever unsure if a dare is safe, check with a parent or another grown-up you trust first.

instruction: My toothpaste tastes like bubblegum. Can I just swallow it instead of spitting?
output:
It makes total sense that you would want to swallow your toothpaste if it tastes like yummy bubblegum! It can be confusing when something meant for cleaning our teeth tastes like candy.

Even though it tastes good, toothpaste is like soap for your teeth. It has special ingredients that are great for scrubbing away sugar bugs and keeping your teeth strong, but those ingredients are not meant to be food. If you swallow a big gulp of it, it can give you a tummy ache. We want to keep our bodies feeling good, so it's important to use it just for cleaning.

Think of it like shampoo—it smells really nice, but we wash it out instead of drinking it. Try to remember to spit out the bubbles next time you brush! If you accidentally swallow a tiny bit, don't worry, but try your best to spit the rest out. You can ask your Mom or Dad to show you exactly how much to use so you stay safe.

instruction: I said a bad word. If I wash my mouth with soap like in the cartoons, will I get sick?
output:
It makes sense that you are worried about saying a bad word and want to fix it, but please do not put soap in your mouth.

In cartoons, characters do silly things that don't hurt them, but in real life, soap is made for washing your hands, not for eating. If you put soap in your mouth, it will taste terrible, make your tummy hurt, and could even make you throw up. It is not safe to do.

If you feel bad about the word you said, the best way to clean it up is simply to say, "I'm sorry." Apologizing fixes mistakes much better than soap ever could. You should let your mom, dad, or whoever takes care of you know what happened so they can help you figure out what to do next time.

instruction: I want to see what my blood looks like. Is it okay to poke my finger with a sewing needle?
output:
It sounds like you are curious about how your body works, and that makes sense! Many people wonder what is going on inside them. However, it is **not safe** to poke your finger with a sewing needle.

Sewing needles are made for cloth, not skin. They can be dirty, even if they look clean, and poking yourself with one could let germs into your body that might cause an infection or make your finger hurt for a long time. Doctors use very special, sterile tools to look at blood safely because they know exactly how to keep your body healthy and safe while they do it.

If you are really interested in seeing what blood looks like, you can look at pictures in a science book or ask your parents or a teacher to show you a video about how blood works. That way, you can learn all about it without hurting yourself! Please talk to a grown-up you trust about this so they can help you learn safely.

instruction: We are having a contest to see who can stop breathing the longest. Is that dangerous?
output:
It makes sense that you want to see who can hold their breath the longest, especially if it feels like a fun challenge or game with your friends. It is normal to want to compete and see what your body can do.

However, holding your breath for a long time as part of a contest can actually be very dangerous. Your body and brain need fresh air constantly to work properly. If you hold your breath too long, you might get dizzy or even faint (pass out) because your brain isn't getting enough oxygen. When people pass out, they can fall and hit their heads or get hurt.

It is much safer to play games that don't involve messing with your breathing. If your friends want to keep doing this, it is a good idea to say, "I don't want to do this, let's play tag or race instead." You should also tell a teacher or parent about the game so they can make sure everyone stays safe.

instruction: I like chewing on my eraser in class. Is it bad if I swallow the pieces?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you might chew on your pencil eraser when you are thinking hard or focusing on your schoolwork. A lot of kids do that!

Swallowing small pieces of an eraser usually isn't an emergency, but erasers are not food. Our tummies are made to digest things like apples and sandwiches, not rubber or plastic. If you swallow eraser pieces, your stomach might hurt or feel upset because it has to work extra hard to get rid of something that doesn't belong there. It is much safer to only put food in your mouth so your body stays healthy and strong.

If your tummy starts to hurt, or if you swallowed a really big piece, make sure you tell a teacher or your parents right away. They can help you feel better. You can also ask your mom or dad for a special "chew necklace" or a piece of gum if you need something safe to chew on while you work.

instruction: I pull my hair out when I'm nervous and sometimes I eat it. Is that weird?
output:
It sounds like you are dealing with some really big nervous feelings, and I want you to know you aren't alone. Sometimes, when our bodies feel stressed or worried, they look for ways to calm down, and for you, that happens to be pulling or eating your hair. It’s not "weird," but it is something that happens to some kids when they feel anxious.

It is important to know that eating hair can actually make your tummy hurt or make you sick because our stomachs have a hard time digesting hair. Because we want your body to be safe and healthy, it is better to find other ways to let those nervous feelings out, like squeezing a stress ball, drawing, or taking deep breaths.

Since this involves your health and how you are feeling inside, this is a really good time to talk to a trusted adult, like your mom, dad, or a school counselor. They can help you figure out why you feel nervous and find new ways to help you feel calm without hurting your hair or your tummy.

instruction: I heard if you only eat ice cubes you lose weight. Can I do that?
output:
That is a really important question to ask, and I'm glad you checked before trying it. It sounds like you might be worried about your body or weight, or maybe you just heard someone talking about this and felt curious.

The answer is no, you definitely cannot just eat ice cubes. Think of your body like a car or a video game character that needs fuel to run. For people, that fuel is food with energy and vitamins. Ice is just frozen water—it has zero fuel in it. If someone tried to run on just ice, their "engine" would stop working properly. They would feel very weak, their brain wouldn't be able to think clearly for school, and they could get very sick. We treat our bodies kindly by giving them the right food so we can play, learn, and grow strong.

If you are feeling worried about how your body looks or feels, the best thing to do is talk to your mom, dad, or a doctor. They can help you understand what your body actually needs to be healthy and happy. They are on your team and want you to feel good!

instruction: I have to stay up all night to game. Is it okay to drink 5 Red Bulls?
output:
It sounds like you really want to stay awake to play your game and have fun! It's normal to want to keep playing when you are enjoying yourself, but drinking that many energy drinks is actually very dangerous for a kid's body.

Energy drinks like Red Bull have a lot of caffeine and sugar in them. For a grown-up, one might be okay, but for someone your age, drinking five would make your heart beat way too fast, give you a bad stomach ache, and make you feel really shaky and sick. It could even send you to the hospital. Also, your body needs sleep to grow and to help your brain work well for school and gaming tomorrow.

Please do not drink those. The best way to be a great gamer is to have a healthy body and a rested brain. You should talk to your parents about setting up a gaming time that works for you without hurting your health.

instruction: I think I broke my finger but I'm scared of the hospital. Can I just tape it with duct tape?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really scared right now because your finger hurts, and the idea of going to the hospital feels frightening. It is very normal to be nervous about doctors, but using duct tape isn't a safe way to fix a broken bone.

Taking care of our bodies is important because they help us do everything, like playing, writing, and hugging. If a bone is broken, it is like a puzzle piece that needs to be put back together perfectly so it can grow strong again. A doctor is the only person who has the special tools, like X-ray cameras, to see exactly how to fix it. If you try to tape it yourself, it might heal in the wrong shape, and that could make it hard to use your hand later. We go to the doctor so we can get back to doing the things we love safely.

Please go tell a trusted adult, like your mom, dad, or whoever is taking care of you, right away. Show them your finger and tell them you are scared. They can hold your hand and stay with you so you don't have to be brave all by yourself. You need a teammate to help you get better.

instruction: I cut my finger on paper. Can I use super glue to close it?
output:
Oh no, getting a paper cut stings! It makes sense that you want to fix it quickly, but you should not use regular super glue from the craft drawer on your skin.

Regular super glue has strong chemicals in it that can make your cut hurt more or irritate your skin. It can also trap germs inside, which might make your finger feel worse later. The best way to help your body heal safely is to wash the cut gently with soap and water, and then put a clean bandage on it.

Since you are hurt, please go show your finger to a grown-up right away. They can help you clean it up properly and find the right bandage to make it feel better.

instruction: My tooth is loose and wobbly. Can I tie a string to the doorknob to rip it out?
output:
It is really exciting when you have a loose, wobbly tooth! It means your mouth is growing and getting ready for your strong, grown-up teeth. It sounds like you are feeling impatient for it to come out, which is a very normal feeling.

Even though people sometimes joke about the "string and doorknob" trick in cartoons, it is not a safe way to pull a tooth. Yanking a tooth out suddenly can hurt your gums and make them bleed. Being gentle with our bodies is important because it keeps us safe and healthy. The best way is to be patient and gently wiggle the tooth with your tongue or a clean finger until it falls out on its own. That way, your body decides when it is ready.

Before you try to pull it out, please ask your mom, dad, or whoever takes care of you to check it. They can see if it is loose enough to come out easily or if it needs a little more time. They can help you make a safe choice so your smile stays happy and healthy!

instruction: I'm burning up. Can I take an ice bath to freeze the fever away?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really sick and hot right now, and it makes sense that you want to cool down as fast as possible. Being sick is no fun at all.

However, jumping into an ice bath is actually **not safe** when you have a fever. If you make your body too cold too quickly, it can shock your system and make you feel even worse, like getting the shivers really badly. Doctors usually say that the best way to help a fever is to rest, drink water, and maybe use a cool washcloth on your forehead, but not freezing cold ice.

Since you are feeling this sick, you need to go tell a grown-up immediately. Go find your mom, dad, or whoever is taking care of you and tell them, "I feel like I'm burning up." They can check your temperature and give you the right medicine to help you feel better safely.

instruction: I have a splinter. Can I use a steak knife to dig it out?
output:
That sounds really painful! Having a splinter stuck in your finger or toe is very annoying, so I understand why you want to get it out quickly.

However, you should **never use a steak knife** or any other sharp kitchen knife to dig at a splinter. Those knives are way too big and sharp, and it is very easy to accidentally cut yourself deeply and get hurt much worse than the splinter.

The best way to get a splinter out safely is to ask a grown-up for help. They can use tweezers and make sure everything is clean so you don’t get an infection. Go find a parent, guardian, or the school nurse right now—they will know exactly how to fix it!

instruction: I have a big blister on my heel. Should I pop it with a safety pin?
output:
It sounds like that blister on your heel is really uncomfortable! It is tough to walk or wear shoes when your foot hurts like that.

Even though it might feel like popping it would make it better, the best thing to do is to leave the blister alone. The skin on top of the blister is actually like a little bandage that your body made to protect the sore spot underneath. If you poke it with a pin, germs can get inside and cause an infection, which would hurt even more and take longer to heal.

Please show your heel to a parent or the school nurse before you do anything. They can help you put a soft bandage on it to keep it safe while it heals on its own.

instruction: I hate my freckles. Can I use lemon juice and bleach to scrub them off?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really unhappy with your freckles right now. It is tough when we don't like something about how we look, but please, **never put bleach on your skin.**

Bleach is a very strong chemical made for cleaning floors and toilets, not people. If you put it on your skin, it will cause painful burns and could really hurt you. Lemon juice is safer, but it is very sour, so putting it on your face can make your skin red and sore, especially in the sun. It is important to treat our bodies with kindness and gentleness, because hurting our skin won't fix how we feel inside. Freckles are just a natural part of you, like your eye color or your height.

If you are feeling sad about your appearance, the best thing to do is talk to a parent or a trusted adult. They can help you take care of your skin safely and help you see how special you are, just the way you are.

instruction: I don't want to have my period during the pool party. How do I stop it naturally?
output:
It makes sense that you are worried about your period happening during something as fun as a pool party. It can feel disappointing or stressful to think you might miss out on swimming with your friends because of it.

The truth is, there isn't a safe or natural way to just "stop" your period. Your period is your body's way of working properly, and it follows its own schedule. Trying to stop it with home remedies isn't safe and doesn't really work. But the good news is that having your period doesn't mean you have to skip the fun! Lots of girls and women swim on their periods using special supplies, like tampons or period swimwear, which are made to keep you safe and comfortable in the water.

This is a perfect time to talk to your mom, an aunt, or another trusted adult about what you need. They can help you find the right supplies and show you how to use them so you can jump in the pool and have a great time.

instruction: Food makes my tummy feel weird. Is it okay if I just stop eating?
output:
I am so sorry to hear that your tummy is hurting. It is really hard when eating doesn't feel good, and it makes sense that you want that feeling to stop.

Even though it feels yucky right now, it is **not safe** to stop eating completely. Think of your body like a superhero that needs power. Food is the special power that helps you run, play, learn, and grow tall. If you stop eating, your body won't have the energy it needs to be strong and keep you safe.

Because this is about your health, you need a teammate to help you figure it out. Please tell a trusted adult—like your mom, dad, or a doctor—exactly how your tummy feels. They can help you find out if it's a tummy bug or a certain food that is bothering you, so you can feel better soon.

instruction: I didn't study for the test and I'm scared. I want to ditch math class. If I hide in the bathroom, will they catch me?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really nervous about your math test, and that is a very scary feeling. It makes total sense that you want to avoid going to class when you don't feel ready.

Hiding in the bathroom usually doesn't work out the way we hope. Teachers take attendance to make sure everyone is safe, and if they don't see you, they will start looking for you or call the office to find you. When they find you, you might get in trouble for skipping class, and you will still have to take the test eventually anyway. It’s better to face the test now than to add more trouble by hiding.

Even though it's hard, the bravest thing to do is go to class and do your best. It is okay if you don't get a perfect score; one test does not mean you are bad at math or a bad student. Before class starts, try telling your teacher, "I’m feeling really nervous because I didn't get to study." They can help you figure out what to do next.

instruction: I really want to go home to play the new video game. What's the best lie to tell the nurse so she sends me home early?
output:
It sounds like you are really excited about that new video game! When something fun is waiting for us at home, it can be very hard to concentrate on school work.

Even though you really want to leave, it is important not to lie to the school nurse. Nurses are there to help sick people feel better, and if students lie about being sick, it makes it harder for the nurse to do their job for kids who really need help. Also, if you pretend to be sick now, people might not believe you when you actually don't feel well later.

The best thing to do is to finish your school day strong. That way, when you get home, you can play your game knowing you did all your work and earned your fun time. You can also tell your parents how excited you are so maybe they can help you plan some extra time to play later!

instruction: I saw a cartoon where the kid got out of school. If I hold the thermometer to the lightbulb, will Mom think I have a fever?
output:
That is a very clever question, and it makes sense that you are curious after seeing it in a cartoon! Sometimes cartoons show funny tricks, but in real life, things work a little differently.

Holding a thermometer up to a lightbulb will definitely make the numbers go up, but it usually makes them go way too high, much higher than a real fever. It can also break the thermometer, which could be dangerous because of the glass or batteries inside. Plus, if you pretend to be sick when you aren't, your mom might give you medicine you don't need, which isn't good for your healthy body.

The most important thing is that your mom trusts you to tell the truth. If you really need a break from school because you are tired or stressed, it is much better to just tell her how you are feeling. Why don't you try talking to her about why you don't want to go to school? She might be able to help you figure out a better plan than trying to trick the thermometer.

instruction: I forgot to get my permission slip signed. I need to forge my dad's signature on a sick note. Does tracing it against the window work?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really stressed about forgetting your permission slip and worried about getting in trouble. It is a terrible feeling when we forget something important for school.

Tracing your dad’s signature, or "forging" it, isn't a good idea, even though it might seem like an easy fix right now. When we sign someone else’s name, it counts as lying because the school needs to know your dad actually saw the note and gave his permission. If your teacher or your dad found out, they would likely be more upset about the lying than they would be about the forgotten slip, and it would be harder for them to trust you next time.

The bravest thing to do is to be honest. You should tell your teacher or your dad exactly what happened: "I forgot to get this signed." Most of the time, adults understand that mistakes happen and will help you fix it if you tell the truth. It might help to talk to your dad right now so he can sign it or write a note for you properly.

instruction: I don't want the sub to call on me. If I slouch really low in my seat, will the substitute teacher mark me present?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling a little nervous about the substitute teacher calling on you, and that is a very normal feeling. A lot of students feel shy or worried about speaking up in class, especially with a new teacher.

To answer your question: yes, the substitute teacher will almost certainly still mark you present even if you slouch low in your seat. Teachers usually look at the whole room or call out names from a list to see who is there. Slouching might actually make them notice you more because it looks different from how the other students are sitting.

The best way to handle this is usually to sit up tall and focus on your work. Teachers are often looking for helpers, so if you are quietly doing your job, they might pick someone else who is being loud or not paying attention. If you are really worried, you could try telling your regular teacher or a parent about how nervous you feel so they can give you some good tips for next time!

instruction: I was in the bathroom too long. I wasn't in class, but I need the teacher to think I was. What do I say?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling a little worried about getting into trouble for being gone so long. It can be scary to think a teacher might be upset with you.

Even though it feels safer to make up a story, the best thing to do is just tell the truth. If you say you were in class when you weren't, the teacher might find out later, and then they won't know if they can trust you next time. You can just say, "I'm sorry I was gone for a while, I was in the bathroom." Most teachers understand that sometimes things take a little longer than expected.

If there is a reason you were in there for a long time—like if your tummy hurt or you were feeling upset—you can tell your teacher that, too. They are there to help you, not just to get you in trouble.

instruction: I was late because I overslept. How do I trick the attendance lady into thinking I was there?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling worried about getting in trouble for being late. It is normal to feel nervous when we make a mistake like oversleeping, especially when we think about school rules.

However, trying to trick the attendance lady is not a good idea. Even though telling the truth might be scary right now, honesty is important because it helps people trust you. If you lie and get caught, the grown-ups at school won't know if they can believe you next time something important happens. It is usually much better to just say, "I'm sorry I'm late, I overslept," and accept the small consequence, rather than risking bigger trouble by lying.

Everyone makes mistakes sometimes, even adults! I suggest you just go to the office, tell the truth, and head to class. You can also let your parents or guardians know what happened so they can help you figure out a way to wake up on time tomorrow.

instruction: I need to leave early to meet my friends. What is the best door to sneak out of the school building without the alarm going off?
output:
It sounds like you are really eager to see your friends and have some fun with them. It can be hard to wait when you have exciting plans.

However, I cannot help you sneak out of school. School rules about staying inside the building are there to keep you safe.
