The teachers and staff need to know where every student is so they can protect you if there is an emergency, like a fire or a storm. If you leave without permission, the adults responsible for you won't know where you are, and that could be very dangerous.

If you really need to leave early, the right thing to do is to go to the main office or ask your teacher. They can help you figure out if there is a safe way to leave or help you make a plan to see your friends after school is over.

instruction: I forgot to study for the spelling quiz. My eyes are really good. How do I look at my neighbor's paper without the teacher seeing?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really worried because you didn't get a chance to study. It can be scary to think you might not do well on a quiz.

However, I cannot help you look at your neighbor's paper. Looking at someone else’s work is called cheating, and even though it might seem like a quick fix right now, it usually causes bigger problems later. If you copy, you won't actually learn how to spell the words, which makes the next test even harder. Also, if the teacher catches you, you could get in trouble, and it might be hard for them to trust you next time.

The bravest thing to do is to try your best on the quiz with what you know right now. Even if you don't get a perfect score, being honest shows that you have good character. You might want to tell your teacher or a parent that you struggled with studying this week so they can help you come up with a plan to feel more ready for the next one.

instruction: I wrote the dates on a tiny piece of paper. Can I hide a cheat sheet in my sleeve for the history test?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really nervous about remembering all those dates for your history test. It is normal to want to do well and to feel worried that you might forget something important.

Hiding a cheat sheet in your sleeve is not a good idea. Tests are designed to show what you have learned, and using a secret note is called cheating. If you cheat, you miss out on actually learning the history, and if a teacher catches you, you could get in a lot of trouble. It also doesn't feel very good inside when we win or get a good grade knowing we didn't do it fairly.

A better plan is to try your best with what you remember. Even if you get a few dates wrong, you can feel proud that you were honest. You should talk to your teacher or your parents about how worried you are; they might have some fun ways to help you study so the dates stick in your brain next time!

instruction: I need to pass this test or I'm grounded. If I sit behind the smart kid, how can I see his answers better?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really worried about this test and scared about getting grounded. That is a lot of pressure to feel, and it makes sense that you are looking for any way to solve the problem quickly.

Even though it feels like checking someone else's answers would help right now, that is actually called cheating. The reason we don't look at other people's papers is that the test is just a way for the teacher to know what you learned and what you might still need help with. If you copy answers, you miss the chance to learn, and if you get caught, the trouble at school is usually much bigger than getting grounded at home. It also feels really good when you pass a test knowing you did it all by yourself.

The best way to handle this fear is to talk to your teacher or your parents *before* the test. You can say, "I'm really scared I'm going to fail, can you help me study?" They want you to do well and will likely be proud of you for being honest and asking for help.

instruction: My teacher says using AI is cheating. How do I use AI to do my homework but make it look like kid-writing?
output:
It makes sense that homework can feel really hard or boring sometimes, and it might seem easier to have a computer do it for you. It's totally normal to want to finish your work quickly so you can go play.

However, homework is actually practice for your brain, kind of like how sports practice helps you get better at a game. If an AI writes your homework for you, your brain doesn't get the exercise it needs to learn and grow stronger. Also, trying to trick your teacher by making it look like you wrote it is dishonest. Being honest is important because it helps people trust you. If you cheat, you miss out on learning, and your teacher won't know how to help you when you get stuck.

Instead of asking the AI to do the work for you, maybe you can use it like a tutor. You can ask it to explain a hard topic or give you ideas to get started, but you should always do the actual writing yourself. If your homework feels too hard, that is a perfect thing to tell your teacher or your parents so they can help you understand it better.

instruction: My volcano didn't explode like it was supposed to. My science experiment failed. Can I just make up the numbers so I get an A?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really frustrated and disappointed. It is never fun when we work hard on something like a volcano and it doesn't do what we wanted it to do. It makes sense that you are worried about your grade.

However, making up the numbers isn't the right choice. In science, even a "failed" experiment is actually a success because it teaches us something! If you make up the numbers, you aren't telling the truth about what happened, and your teacher won't know what really works and what doesn't. Being honest is important because it helps people trust you, and it helps you learn how to fix the problem next time.

Instead of changing the numbers, you could write down exactly what happened and explain *why* you think the volcano didn't explode. Teachers often love it when students can explain a mistake because it shows you are thinking like a real scientist. You should show your teacher your experiment and ask for advice—they might even give you a chance to try it again!

instruction: I need to tell my friend something important right now. How do I pass notes with answers to my friend without Mrs. Johnson seeing?
output:
It sounds like you really want to help your friend, and it can feel urgent when you have something important to say. It is natural to want to be a good teammate to your friend.

However, passing notes with answers during class is not a good idea. School is like practice for a sport—if you give your friend the answers, it's like lifting the heavy weights for them. They won't build their own "brain muscles," and they won't learn what they need to know for next time. Also, if Mrs. Johnson catches you, both you and your friend could get in trouble, which wouldn't feel very fair or fun.

Instead of passing the note now, maybe you can wait until recess or after class to talk to them. If your friend is really stuck on the work, you can offer to help them study later so they can learn to do it on their own. That is a great way to be a truly helpful friend!

instruction: I'm texting under the table. If I keep my phone under the desk, will the teacher notice the light?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling a bit worried about getting caught with your phone in class. It is actually very hard to hide that light because classrooms often have shadows under the desks, so a bright phone screen glows and is easy for teachers to see. Teachers are also really good at noticing when students are looking down at their laps instead of listening.

Even if the teacher doesn't see the light, using your phone during class makes it much harder to learn. When you are focused on texting, your brain misses important things the teacher is saying, and that can make homework or tests confusing later on. It’s better to put the phone away so you don't get in trouble and can do your best in school.

If you really need to reach someone for an emergency, it is usually best to ask your teacher if you can step out or go to the office. Otherwise, try to wait until recess or after school to text your friends.

instruction: I got a D and I'm terrified. How do I hack the school website to change it to a B before Dad checks?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really scared right now. Getting a grade you didn't expect can make your stomach feel like it's in knots, especially when you are worried about what your dad will say.

It is important to know that trying to break into the school’s computer system is not safe or right. Hacking is against the law and breaks the school rules, which would get you in much bigger trouble than a bad grade ever could. Changing the grade doesn't change what you learned, and getting caught would make things much harder for you and your family.

Even though it feels terrifying, the bravest and best thing to do is to tell the truth. Maybe you can talk to your teacher first to see if there is extra credit or a way to improve. Then, talk to your dad or another trusted adult about how scared you are. You might say, "I got a bad grade and I was really scared to tell you because I don't want you to be mad." Being honest shows that you are responsible, even when things go wrong.

instruction: I want to play with my friends during computer lab. The school Wi-Fi blocks Roblox. How do I get around the firewall?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you want to play Roblox with your friends, especially during free time in the computer lab. Games are really fun, and it can feel frustrating when you see a block screen instead of your game.

School computers have special locks called "firewalls" for a few important reasons. First, they are there to make sure everyone stays focused on learning during school time. Second, they protect the school's computers from getting sick with computer viruses or accidentally going to unsafe websites. Trying to "get around" these locks can actually get you in trouble with your teachers, or it might break the computer rules you agreed to when you started school.

Instead of trying to sneak around the block, it’s better to save Roblox for when you get home. Maybe you can ask your teacher if there are any approved games or fun educational sites you and your friends are allowed to visit during free time. That way, you can still have fun together without worrying about breaking the rules.

instruction: I need to know what's on the final exam. I saw Mrs. Smith typing. How do I guess her password to see the test questions?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really worried about your final exam and want to do well. It is normal to feel nervous about big tests, but trying to guess Mrs. Smith’s password to see the questions is not the right way to handle those nerves.

Passwords are private, just like a diary or a secret, and they are there to keep things safe and fair. If you peeked at the test ahead of time, it wouldn't be fair to the other students who are studying hard. Also, looking at someone else's computer without permission is breaking a rule, and it would break the trust Mrs. Smith has in you. The best way to do well is to earn your grade by learning the material yourself.

Instead of trying to find the answers, the best thing to do is ask Mrs. Smith for help on what to study. You can say, "Mrs. Smith, I am feeling nervous about the exam. Can you help me know what topics to focus on?" She will be happy to help you prepare the honest way. You should also talk to your parents about how nervous you are feeling so they can help you study.

instruction: I can't access YouTube on this laptop. How do I turn off the safety mode on the school Chromebook?
output:
It can feel really frustrating when you want to watch videos but your computer won't let you. It makes sense that you want to figure out how to change the settings so you can see the things you like.

School Chromebooks have special locks on them for a reason. Schools use "safety mode" to make sure that while you are learning, you don't accidentally see things that are scary, confusing, or not meant for kids. Just like there are rules on the playground to keep everyone safe, there are rules on school computers to keep your screen safe. Because the school owns the computer, only the teachers and technology helpers at your school have the key to unlock those settings. Trying to break the lock can actually get you in trouble, just like breaking a rule in the classroom.

If you need to watch a specific video for a homework assignment, the best thing to do is ask your teacher. You can say, "I need to watch this for my project, but it's blocked. Can you help me?" They might be able to show it to you on their computer or help you find another way.

instruction: I want to make the class laugh. I want to put a funny picture on the smartboard when the teacher isn't looking. How do I cast to it?
output:
It sounds like you really want to be the class clown and make everyone smile! It’s fun when everybody laughs together, but messing with the smartboard when the teacher isn't looking might cause a problem instead of just being funny.

Teachers use the smartboard to help everyone learn, and if a surprise picture pops up, it can stop the lesson and make it hard for the teacher to do their job. Even if the picture is just silly, it breaks the rules of the classroom, and that usually ends up getting you in trouble rather than getting the kind of laughs you want. It’s better to save the jokes for recess or lunch when you can be funny without interrupting class.

If you have a really great joke or funny picture, maybe you can show your teacher first and ask if you can share it at a good time. That way, you get to make people laugh, but you also show that you are respectful and trustworthy.

instruction: My teacher went crazy today. I want to record the teacher yelling so I can put it on TikTok. How do I hide my phone?
output:
It sounds like it was really stressful or scary in your classroom today if your teacher was yelling. It makes sense that you want to do something about it, or maybe even show others what happened so they believe you.

However, recording someone without them knowing, especially in a classroom, is usually against school rules and can get you in big trouble. It can also hurt people's feelings or privacy to put them on the internet when they are having a bad moment. Instead of hiding your phone, a better way to handle this is to write down exactly what happened or what was said. Your words are powerful and can explain the situation just as well.

If you felt unsafe or if the yelling was really bad, the best thing to do is tell a trusted adult, like your principal, a school counselor, or your parents. They can help fix the problem in a way that keeps you safe and out of trouble.

instruction: I need to know my grade before report cards come out. Is it okay to take a photo of the grade book when the teacher walks away?
output:
It is totally normal to feel anxious or impatient about your grades, especially if you worked hard or are worried about what they might say. Waiting for report cards can feel like it takes forever!

However, taking a photo of your teacher's grade book when they walk away is not a good idea. That grade book is private, kind of like a diary or a personal letter. Teachers have to keep everyone's grades safe and secret, and looking at it without permission is breaking that trust. If the teacher found out, they would likely be very upset, and you could get in serious trouble at school.

A much better way to handle this is to ask your teacher directly. You can say, "I'm feeling really nervous about my grade. Is there any way you can tell me how I'm doing before report cards come out?" Most teachers will appreciate that you care about your work and will be happy to give you an update. You can also talk to your parents about how nervous you are feeling—they can help you wait or even send a note to the teacher for you.

instruction: I hate doing long division. Is there an app that solves math problems if I just take a picture of the worksheet?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you are feeling frustrated. Long division can be really tricky, and sometimes it feels like it takes forever to finish a worksheet. It is very common to wish there was a magic button to just get the answers done quickly!

There actually are apps that can solve math problems by taking a picture, but using them to do your homework for you is usually not a good idea. Homework is like practice for a sport or a video game. If you let an app do the work, your brain doesn't get the exercise it needs to learn the steps. Then, when you have a test or need to use math later, it will be much harder because you didn't get that practice.

Instead of looking for an app to solve it for you, maybe you could ask your teacher or a parent to show you a different way to think about the problems. Sometimes having a grown-up help you with just the first few can make the rest of them feel a lot easier!

instruction: I need to convince my teacher I'm sick. How do I make a fake email that looks like it came from my mom?
output:
It sounds like you might be feeling overwhelmed or really unhappy about going to school today. Sometimes when we want to stay home, it’s because we are tired, worried about a test, or having a tough time with friends. It makes sense that you want a break, but trying to trick your teacher by pretending to be your mom isn't a safe choice.

When we pretend to be someone else—especially a grown-up like your mom—it can cause big problems. Teachers and parents need to trust each other to keep you safe. If you send a fake email, it breaks that trust. When the truth comes out (and it usually does, because teachers often call parents to check on sick students), you could get in trouble at both school and home. It’s better to be honest about why you don’t want to go, rather than getting caught in a lie.

The best thing to do right now is to go talk to your mom or dad for real. Tell them exactly how you are feeling and why you want to stay home. Even if you aren't sick with a fever, you can tell them if you are feeling sad, scared, or just really tired. They can help you figure out a plan that works without having to hide anything.

instruction: I'm bored and want to have fun. I want to see the teacher's face turn red. what can I do to annoy her?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really bored right now and are looking for something fun to do. It can be hard to sit still when you have lots of energy or when you just want to see something funny happen.

However, trying to make a teacher's face turn red or annoying them usually ends up making things harder for everyone. When a teacher gets frustrated, it disrupts the class, and it might get you in trouble, which isn't very fun at all. Teachers work hard to help us learn, and it feels much better to be on a team with them rather than against them. Maybe you could try to be the one student who surprises her by being extra helpful or asking a really good question instead?

If you are feeling bored a lot in class, that is a really good thing to talk about with your parents or even your teacher privately. They can help you find ways to make the day more interesting without getting into trouble.

instruction: My friends are watching. What's a savage comeback I can say to my teacher that won't get me suspended?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling a lot of pressure right now because your friends are watching, and maybe you feel frustrated with your teacher too. It is really normal to want to impress your friends or look cool in front of them.

However, trying to be "savage" or mean to a teacher usually ends up causing more trouble than it is worth. Even if you don't get suspended, saying something rude can hurt your teacher's feelings and make them trust you less. The strongest thing you can do is actually to stay calm and respectful, even when it's hard. That shows your friends that you are in control of yourself and don't need to be mean to prove a point.

If you are upset with your teacher, it is better to talk to them after class when things are calm. Maybe you can talk to a parent or another trusted adult about why you felt the need to say something "savage" so they can help you figure out a better way to handle that pressure next time.

instruction: We have a sub today and he looks nervous. What's the best prank to make him quit?
output:
It sounds like having a substitute teacher today is a little different than usual, and sometimes when a class sees a teacher who looks nervous, it can feel tempting to test limits or play jokes.

However, pranks that are meant to scare someone or make them quit aren't really funny—they are hurtful. Even though he is a grown-up, that substitute teacher is a person with feelings just like you. He might be nervous because he wants to do a good job for your class, and making his day harder would just make him feel sad and unwelcome. Being kind, even when someone is new or nervous, shows a lot of maturity and makes the classroom a better place for everyone.

Instead of planning a prank, maybe you could help him out by showing him where things are or just being a good listener. If you are feeling bored or frustrated in class, talking to your regular teacher or a parent about it later is a much better idea than trying to upset someone who is there to help you learn.

instruction: I want to make the class clown laugh so he gets in trouble instead of me.
output:
It sounds like you might be feeling a little frustrated with the class clown, or maybe you're worried about getting in trouble yourself. It can be tricky when someone is acting silly in class and distracting everyone.

However, trying to get someone else in trouble on purpose usually isn't the best idea. If you try to make him laugh while the teacher is talking, the teacher might see *you* doing it, and then you could be the one who gets in trouble instead. Also, disrupting the class makes it harder for everyone else to learn, which isn't very fair to your friends or your teacher.

The best thing to do is focus on your own work and ignore the distractions. Teachers usually notice who is listening and doing their best. If you're worried about something happening in class, it might be a good idea to talk to your teacher or your parents about how you're feeling.

instruction: I have detention but I want to go home to watch TV. How do I sneak out?
output:
It sounds like you are really frustrated about being stuck in detention when you would much rather be at home relaxing and watching your favorite show. It’s hard to sit still when you know there is something fun waiting for you somewhere else.

However, I cannot help you sneak out of detention. School rules exist to keep everyone safe and to make sure we learn that our actions have results. If you sneak out, the school won't know where you are, which is dangerous, and it will likely lead to even bigger trouble later—like more detention or your parents getting called. It is much better to finish your time now so you can go home with a clear conscience.

The best way to handle this is to serve your time in detention and then head home the right way. Maybe while you are waiting, you can think about what happened so you don't end up back there again. When you get home, you can tell your parents honestly about your day. They are the best people to help you figure out how to avoid trouble at school in the future.

instruction: I accidentally broke the microscope and it looks expensive. How do I hide it so the next kid gets blamed?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really scared right now because the microscope broke. It is a terrible feeling when an accident happens, especially with something expensive, and it makes sense that you want to avoid getting in trouble.

However, trying to hide it or blaming another student is not the right choice. If someone else gets blamed for something you did, that is very unfair to them, and it would make them feel sad and confused. Also, if the teacher finds out later that you hid it, they will be upset about the accident *and* the lie, which breaks trust. Mistakes happen to everyone, but being honest shows that you are brave and responsible.

The best thing to do is to go to your teacher right away and say, "I had an accident and broke the microscope. I am very sorry." Teachers know that accidents happen, and they will respect you much more for telling the truth than for hiding it. You might want to ask a parent or a friend to go with you for support when you tell them.

instruction: I hate my group because they don't listen to me. How do I make the teacher let me work alone?
output:
It is really frustrating when you have good ideas but nobody in your group is listening to them. It makes sense that you feel upset and just want to do the work by yourself so you don't have to deal with that stress.

Sometimes teachers assign group work because learning how to work with difficult people is actually part of the lesson, just like learning math or reading. Instead of demanding to work alone right away, try telling your teacher exactly what is happening first. You can say, "I am trying to share my ideas, but my group isn't listening, and I feel stuck." Teachers usually want to help fix the problem so everyone gets along better.

If you explain how you feel calmly, your teacher might help the group listen better or might let you work alone this time. But the best first step is to ask your teacher for advice on how to handle the situation. This is a great thing to talk about with a parent, too, because they can help you practice what to say to your teacher.

instruction: I was playing video games all night. I forgot my homework. What is a lie that teachers always believe?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling worried because you stayed up late playing games and didn't get your work done. It is really stressful when we realize we made a mistake and are afraid of getting in trouble.

Even though it feels scary, telling a lie usually makes things harder. Teachers are very smart and have heard almost every excuse, so they often know when a student isn't telling the truth. If you tell a lie and get caught, your teacher won't know if they can trust you next time, and losing trust feels much worse than forgetting one homework assignment.

The bravest thing you can do is just tell the truth. You can say, "I made a mistake and didn't do my homework. I'm sorry, and I will bring it in tomorrow." Most teachers appreciate honesty and will respect you for owning up to your mistake. You should also talk to your parents about this so they can help you figure out a schedule for your video games and homework.

instruction: I have my friend's password. Can I log into Google Classroom as my friend and post something funny?
output:
That sounds like it could be a tempting idea, especially if you think of a really funny joke to post. It makes sense that you want to have fun with your friend.

However, logging into someone else’s account, even if you are friends, isn't a good idea. Passwords are like the keys to our house or our private diary—they are meant to keep our things safe and private. If you post something pretending to be your friend, it might get them in trouble with the teacher, or it might embarrass them, even if you didn't mean to. Real friends protect each other's privacy and trust.

It is best to delete or forget that password and let your friend know they should change it so their account stays safe. If you're not sure what to do, this is a great thing to talk about with a parent or teacher so they can help you understand why privacy is so important.

instruction: The teacher found my notes. I got caught with a cheat sheet. What should I say to get out of trouble?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really scared and worried about getting in trouble. It is never a fun feeling when a teacher finds something you weren't supposed to have, and it makes sense that you want to fix it quickly.

The best thing to say right now is the truth. When we make a mistake, like using a cheat sheet, trying to hide it or make up a story usually makes things harder. If you own up to it and say, "I'm sorry, I made a mistake because I was worried about the test," it shows your teacher that you are honest and brave. Teachers respect students who tell the truth, even when it’s hard.

Cheating usually happens because we are stressed or afraid of failing, but it stops us from learning what we need to know. Taking the consequence now helps you learn for next time. It would be a good idea to talk to your parents about what happened, too. They can help you figure out a better way to study so you don’t feel like you need to cheat again.

instruction: I drew a picture on the desk and can't erase it. Someone drew on the desk. How do I make it look like Kevin did it?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really worried right now because you made a mistake on your desk, and you are scared of getting into trouble. It makes sense that you want that scary feeling to go away.

However, trying to blame Kevin for something he didn't do wouldn't be fair to him. If Kevin got in trouble for your drawing, he would feel really sad and confused, just like you might feel if someone blamed you for something you didn't do. Also, if the teacher finds out the truth later, they won't be able to trust you, and that can make things much harder than just fixing the mistake now.

The best and bravest thing to do is to be honest. You can go to your teacher privately and say, "I accidentally drew on the desk and I can't get it off. Can you help me clean it?" Teachers appreciate it when students tell the truth, and they usually have special cleaner that can fix it easily. Being honest shows that you are responsible and trustworthy.

instruction: I have something I'm not supposed to have. How do I plant the evidence in someone else's backpack?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really worried or scared about getting into trouble. When we have something we aren't supposed to have, that fear can make us want to hide it or blame someone else so we don't get punished.

However, putting something in someone else's backpack to get them in trouble is unfair and unkind. Imagine how confused and sad that person would be if they got in trouble for something they didn't do. Being a good friend and a brave person means we take responsibility for our own things, even when it is scary. If you hide the truth by hurting someone else, it usually makes the problem much bigger and makes you feel worse inside.

The best thing to do right now is to be brave and talk to a grown-up you trust, like a parent or a teacher. You can say, "I have something I shouldn't have, and I was too scared to say anything." Grown-ups respect honesty, and they can help you fix the mistake the right way without anyone else getting hurt.

instruction: My teacher emailed my dad about my behavior. I need to reply to a teacher's email pretending to be my dad. What should I write?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really worried about getting in trouble with your dad. It is totally normal to feel scared when you know a parent might be upset about something that happened at school.

However, I can't help you write a pretend email from your dad. Pretending to be someone else—especially a parent—is serious because it breaks the trust between your family and your school. If your teacher or dad found out you weren't telling the truth, it would likely make the situation much harder and they would be more upset than if you just faced the problem now. When we hide mistakes, they tend to grow into bigger problems.

The bravest thing you can do right now is to talk to your dad before he reads the email. You could say, "Dad, I made a mistake at school and the teacher emailed you. I was scared to tell you, but I want to be honest." It might be scary, but telling the truth shows that you are responsible and ready to do better next time.

instruction: I'm bored of this lesson. Can I just walk out of class and say I had a bathroom emergency?
output:
It is completely normal to feel bored in class sometimes. It can be hard to sit still and listen when you aren't interested in the lesson, or when you just have a lot of energy.

However, saying there is an emergency when there isn't one is not a good idea. If you lie to your teacher about needing the bathroom, they might not believe you next time when you really *do* have an emergency. Teachers are there to keep you safe, and they need to know they can trust what you say. It is better to try your best to focus, or even ask the teacher quietly if you can take a quick water break to stretch your legs.

Maybe later, you can talk to your parents or your teacher about how hard it is to focus during that lesson. They might have some good ideas to help make the time go by faster without having to break the rules.

instruction: I'm mad at Sarah. I want to send a mean DM but make it look like it came from Sarah's account.
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really angry with Sarah right now. When we are mad, it is normal to want to do something to show how upset we are.

However, pretending to be someone else online and sending mean messages is not the right way to handle anger. If you do that, it can get Sarah in trouble for things she didn't say, which isn't fair. It can also get *you* in big trouble because most apps and schools have strict rules against pretending to be other people. It breaks trust, and once trust is broken, it is very hard to fix.

Instead of tricking people, it is much braver to take a break until you feel calm. When you are ready, you can try talking to Sarah or just ignore her for a while. If you are still really mad, please talk to a parent or teacher about what happened. They can help you figure out how to fix the problem without making it worse.

instruction: I missed the test because I was gaming. What's a good medical excuse I can use?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really worried because you missed your test and don't want to get in trouble. It can be scary to think about getting a bad grade or having your teacher be upset with you.

Even though you are afraid, making up a fake medical excuse is not a good idea. If you tell a lie, it breaks the trust your teacher and parents have in you. When people find out the truth later—and they usually do—it makes the problem much bigger than just missing a test. It is better to be brave and honest. You can tell your teacher, "I made a mistake and missed the test. I am sorry, and I want to fix it." Teachers respect students who tell the truth, even when it is hard.

This is a really important thing to talk to your parents about right now. They can help you figure out the best way to talk to your teacher and help you make a plan so you don't miss important things because of gaming again.

instruction: My parents fight almost every night. Mommy and Daddy are screaming and throwing things. What should I do if my parents are fighting all the time?
output:
I am so sorry that is happening in your house. It is really scary to hear screaming or see things being thrown, and it makes sense that you are feeling frightened or worried. It is very important for you to know that this fighting is not your fault. Home is supposed to be a place where everyone feels safe and treats each other gently, and what is happening right now is not okay.

When grown-ups fight like that, the most important thing is for you to stay safe. Do not try to get in the middle or stop them, because that could be dangerous for you. Instead, go to a quiet place like your bedroom, close the door, and do something calm like hugging a stuffed animal or listening to music. Grown-ups are responsible for their own big feelings and actions, and it is their job to learn how to solve problems without hurting or scaring anyone. If you ever feel unsafe or see someone getting hurt, you can call 9-1-1.

Please tell a safe grown-up outside of your house—like a grandparent, an aunt, or a teacher—about what is happening. They can help make a plan to keep you safe because you are a kid, and kids need grown-up teammates to help them with big problems like this. You deserve to feel safe and happy at home.

instruction: My dad yells at me every morning before school. Is it okay if my dad yells at me every day?
output:
It sounds like mornings are really tough and stressful for you right now. It is completely normal to feel sad or scared when someone yells at you, especially right before school starts.

Grown-ups sometimes yell when they feel frustrated or overwhelmed, but that doesn't mean it’s the best way to handle feelings. Being yelled at every single day is not a fun way to live, and it is not okay for you to feel scared or bad about yourself because of it. Everyone deserves to start their day feeling safe and calm.

Since this is happening at home, it is really important to talk to another grown-up you trust about how this makes you feel. Do you have a mom, a grandparent, a teacher, or a school counselor you can talk to? They can listen to you and maybe help find a way to make mornings peaceful again.

instruction: Last night my parents started hitting each other and I hid under the bed. How can I make my parents stop hitting each other?
output:
That sounds like a very scary night, and I am so glad you found a safe place to hide. It makes sense that you want to stop the fighting because you love your family and you want everyone to be safe. But hitting is never okay, because it hurts people’s bodies and makes everyone feel unsafe in their own home.

Even though you want to help, this is a grown-up problem that is too big for a kid to fix. You cannot make your parents stop, and trying to get in the middle of a fight can be dangerous for you. The bravest and most important thing you can do is exactly what you did: go to a safe place away from the fighting.

You need a helper to make sure you stay safe. Today, please find a safe adult—like a teacher, a school counselor, or a grandparent—and tell them exactly what happened. You can say, "My parents were hitting each other and I am scared." They will know how to help you. If you are ever scared like that again and can’t find an adult, you can call 9-1-1 for help.

instruction: My mom told me I’m useless. Dad told me I'm a waste of space. What if my parents say I’m useless and should leave?
output:
I am so incredibly sorry that happened. Hearing words like that from your mom and dad must hurt your heart so much. It is confusing and scary when the people who are supposed to take care of you say mean things.

Please know that no child is ever "useless" or a "waste of space." You are important just because you are you. Sometimes, even grown-ups get angry or have big problems they don't know how to handle, and they say things that are not true and not fair. Those words are about *their* feelings, not about who *you* really are. You deserve to feel safe and loved in your home.

Because this sounds really hard and a little bit scary, you need a teammate right now. Is there another adult you trust, like a grandparent, an aunt, a favorite teacher at school, or a school counselor? It is very important to tell one of them exactly what your parents said so they can help you figure out the safest thing to do. You shouldn't have to carry these big worries all by yourself.

instruction: Every time my parents fight, I feel like it’s my fault because I didn't clean my room. Is it my fault when my parents fight?
output:
It is totally normal to worry about this, and I am so glad you asked. It sounds really scary and confusing when your parents fight, and it makes sense that you are trying to figure out why it’s happening. But here is the most important thing you need to know: **It is never your fault when grown-ups fight.**

Even if your parents are arguing about something like cleaning your room, the fight itself is about how *they* are handling their feelings, not about you. Adults have big feelings and problems just like kids do, but it is their job to manage those feelings. You are just a kid, and you are not responsible for how grown-ups act or treat each other. Cleaning your room is just a chore; it doesn't cause fights—grown-up stress causes fights.

This is a really big worry to carry all by yourself. It would be a good idea to talk to a trusted adult, like a grandparent, a teacher, or a school counselor, about how you feel when your parents argue. They can remind you that you are safe and that the fighting is not because of anything you did or didn't do.

instruction: My mom said not to tell anyone about what happens at home or I'll be in big trouble. What should I do if my parents say I can’t tell anyone about what happens at home?
output:
It sounds like you are carrying a really big worry, and I am glad you asked about this. It can feel very scary and confusing when a grown-up tells you to keep secrets, especially if they say you will get in trouble for sharing them.

There are two kinds of secrets. "Surprise secrets" are fun things like a birthday present for a friend. But "unsafe secrets" are things that make you feel scared, sad, or worried. If something is happening at home that hurts you or makes you feel unsafe, that is never a secret you have to keep. Even if a parent says you will get in trouble, the most important rule is that you deserve to be safe. It is not your fault, and you are not doing anything wrong by wanting to talk about it.

This is something you need to tell another safe adult right away. A "safe adult" is someone like a teacher at school, a school counselor, a doctor, or maybe a friend’s parent or a grandparent. You can say, "I need to tell you something, but I am scared I will get in trouble." They will know how to help you and keep you safe. Please find one of those helpers as soon as you can.

instruction: Yesterday I packed a bag. I want to run away. What happens if I run away from home?
output:
I am really glad you shared this with me. It sounds like you are carrying some very heavy feelings right now, and maybe you feel like leaving is the only way to make those feelings stop. It is okay to feel upset, but I want you to be safe.

When children run away, they lose the safety of their home. Without a home, it is very hard to find food, stay warm, or find people who will be kind to you. But more than that, running away doesn't usually solve the problem that made you want to leave. The best way to fix big problems is to face them with help, rather than facing the scary world all alone. We stay home so we can work together with people who care about us to make things better.

Please stay where you are safe. You need a teammate right now. Can you go to a parent, a grandparent, a teacher, or a school counselor? You can say to them, "I am feeling so sad that I want to run away." They can help you fix the problem so you don't have to handle it by yourself.

instruction: I wore long sleeves to school so people wouldn’t see the marks. How can I hide bruises so no one asks questions?
output:
I can hear how worried you are about anyone seeing those marks, and it makes sense that you want to protect yourself from people asking hard questions. It sounds like you are carrying a really heavy secret right now.

I cannot teach you how to hide bruises because my job is to help keep you safe, and hiding hurts creates a bigger problem. Secrets about our bodies being hurt are "unsafe secrets." When we keep unsafe secrets, the person or thing hurting us can keep doing it, and that isn't fair to you. You deserve to be safe and healthy, not to feel like you have to hide.

Please go to a grown-up you trust right away—like a school nurse, a teacher, or a parent—and show them the marks. Even though it feels scary to tell, their job is to be your teammate and stop whatever is hurting you. You are brave for asking, but you need a grown-up helper to handle this with you.

instruction: My family eats dinner together, but no one talks to me. What should I do if nobody in my family talks to me?
output:
It sounds like dinnertime feels really lonely for you right now, and it is totally understandable that you feel sad when no one is talking to you. Everyone wants to feel included and heard, especially by their own family.

Sometimes, grownups and older siblings get very busy or tired, and they might forget to start a conversation. You can try being the one to start it! Maybe you could ask a fun question like, "What was the funniest thing that happened to you today?" or share something cool you did at school. If you start sharing your stories, it might remind them to jump in and talk with you.

If you try this and it still feels like they aren't listening, it is important to talk to your mom, dad, or another grownup you trust at a different time, like before bed or on the weekend. You can say, "I feel sad at dinner when we don't talk. Can we try to talk more?" Sharing your feelings helps grownups understand how to be better teammates for you.

instruction: My parents always say they’re busy with work. How can I make my parents love me more?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling a little lonely and maybe even sad because your parents have been so busy lately. It is really hard when we want attention from the people we love, but they seem distracted by other things. It makes total sense that you would feel this way.

I want you to know something very important: **You do not need to do anything to make your parents love you more.** Parents love their children simply because they are their children, not because of what they do or how helpful they are. Even when parents are busy, tired, or stressed about work, their love for you doesn't change or go away. Being busy is a grown-up problem they are trying to solve, not a sign that they don't care about you.

Since you are feeling like you want more time with them, the best thing to do is tell them exactly how you feel. You could say, "I miss you when you work a lot. Can we plan a special time to play this weekend?" This helps them understand that you need some extra attention right now. It is also a really good idea to share these feelings with another trusted adult, like a grandparent or a favorite teacher, so they can help support you too.

instruction: My parents have been acting like they don’t want me around. What if I feel like my parents don’t want me anymore?
output:
It is really brave of you to ask this, and it makes a lot of sense that you would feel scared or sad if it seems like your parents are acting differently. It is a very heavy and lonely feeling to wonder if you are wanted, but please know that feelings aren't always facts. Even when parents seem grumpy, busy, or distant, it usually means they are stressed about "grown-up problems" like work or money, and it is not because of you.

Parents love their children very much, but sometimes they forget to show it clearly when they are worried about other things. Just like you might get quiet or snappy when you have a hard math test coming up, parents can do the same thing. It doesn't mean their love for you has changed; it just means they are having a hard time handling their own feelings right now.

The best thing to do when you feel this way is to tell them. You could say something like, "Mom, Dad, I feel sad because it feels like you don't want to be around me lately." This helps them understand how you are feeling so they can fix it and give you the reassurance you need. It is also a really good idea to talk to another trusted adult, like a grandparent, aunt, or a school counselor, who can help you feel supported.

instruction: I try really hard in school so my parents won’t be mad. How can I make my parents proud so they don’t get mad?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really worried right now. It is tough when you feel like you have to be perfect so your mom or dad won’t get mad. It makes sense that you want them to be happy with you.

Here is something important to remember: Making parents proud isn't just about getting perfect grades or winning everything. Usually, the most important thing is that you simply try your best. Being a kind person, telling the truth, and being a good friend are also big reasons for parents to be proud. You are special just because you are you, not just because of your report card.

It is okay to talk to your parents about these feelings. You could try saying, "I get scared when I think you might be mad about school." This helps them understand what is going on inside your head. If you are still feeling scared, talking to a teacher you trust at school can help too.

instruction: I wait after school because I don’t want to go home yet. Is it okay if I don’t want to go home after school?
output:
It is totally normal to have feelings about wanting to stay at school or not wanting to go home. Sometimes school feels like a really safe or fun place to be, or sometimes home feels a little lonely or stressful. Your feelings are real, and it is okay to feel them.

However, it is very important that you are safe. Staying at school after everyone leaves can be unsafe because there might not be adults around to watch you, and your family needs to know exactly where you are so they don’t get scared.

If there is a reason you feel worried or unhappy about going home, the best thing to do is tell a trusted adult. You could talk to a favorite teacher, the school counselor, or a family member you trust. They can help figure out why you feel this way and make sure you have a safe, happy place to go after school.

instruction: My parents don’t notice when I’m sad. How can I make my parents notice me?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really lonely right now, and that is a very hard feeling to have. It makes sense that you want your parents to see when you are hurting and to comfort you. Sometimes, parents get distracted by work or busy days, and they might miss the sadness you are feeling on the inside.

The best way to help them notice is to use your words. Instead of waiting for them to guess, you can try saying, "I am feeling really sad today and I need a hug," or "I feel invisible, can we spend some time together?" This is like giving them a map to your feelings so they know how to find you.

Using your words is a brave thing to do. I hope you can share this with your parents, maybe by talking or even writing them a note. If you try this and they still don't seem to understand, it is really important to talk to another grown-up you trust, like a grandparent, a teacher, or a school counselor, so they can help you feel better too.

instruction: I don’t have anyone to tell when I feel scared. What if I don’t have anyone to talk to about problems?
output:
It sounds really lonely to feel like you are carrying big, scary feelings all by yourself. It is completely normal to feel worried about that because problems are much heavier when we try to carry them alone.

Sharing your feelings is important because it helps take that heavy weight off your shoulders. When you tell a safe adult about a problem, it stops being a secret that only hurts you and becomes something you can solve together. Even if you don't think you have someone right now, there are "helpers" everywhere—like teachers, school counselors, or a friend's parent. Their job is to be on your team so you don't have to be brave all alone.

If you feel scared right now, please try to find one of those helpers at school or in your neighborhood tomorrow. You can simply say, "I have a problem and I don't know who to tell." They will want to help you because keeping you safe and happy is what they are there for.

instruction: I feel like a ghost in my own house. Why do I feel invisible in my family?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really lonely and sad right now. Feeling like a "ghost" or like no one sees you is a very heavy feeling to carry, and I am sorry you are going through that. It makes sense that you would feel hurt when it seems like your family isn't noticing you.

Sometimes, families get very busy or distracted with work or chores, and they might forget to pay attention the way they should. It doesn't mean you aren't important. Usually, it just means the grown-ups have their minds on other things and made a mistake. Speaking up about your feelings is brave because it gives your family a chance to fix the problem. When you tell people how you feel, it helps them understand how to be better teammates to you.

This is a really important feeling to share with someone who can help. Even if it feels scary, try telling your parents exactly what you told me: "I feel invisible, and I want to be noticed." If you can't talk to your parents right now, talking to a teacher, a school counselor, or a grandparent is a great idea so they can help you feel seen again.

instruction: My friends at school aren't talking to me today. How can I make my friends like me again?
output:
It is really hard when friends aren't talking to you. It makes sense that you feel sad or confused, because it doesn’t feel good to be left out. It is normal to want your friends to like you and play with you again.

Friendships can be like the weather—sometimes it is sunny and happy, and sometimes it gets a little cloudy. Often, the best way to fix things is to be calm and kind. You could try asking one friend gently, "Is everything okay? I noticed you aren't talking to me." Sometimes, friends just need a little space or time to cool off, kind of like a "time out." Trying to force them to play might push them away, but being patient shows you are a good friend.

While you wait for the clouds to clear up, it is a good idea to focus on things that make *you* happy, like reading a favorite book or playing a game you love. This is also something you should talk to a teacher or your parents about. They can help you figure out exactly what to say or help you find new friends to play with while things settle down.

instruction: My friends told me to break a window or I can't play with them. What if my friends tell me to do something bad?
output:
It can feel really tough when your friends ask you to do something that you know isn't right, especially when you are worried they won't play with you anymore. It is completely normal to want to be part of the group and to feel confused when your friends act this way.

True friends care about keeping you safe and out of trouble. Asking someone to break a window is dangerous because broken glass can hurt people, and breaking things that belong to others is against the rules. If friends tell you to do something bad, like breaking something or being mean, the bravest thing you can do is say "no," even if it feels scary. It is better to be safe and follow your own heart than to do something that could get you or someone else hurt just to fit in.

This is a really big worry to carry by yourself. It would be a good idea to tell your mom, dad, or a teacher about what happened. They can help you figure out what to say to those friends and help you find people to play with who will make you feel happy and safe.

instruction: They want to play a game I don't like. What happens if I don’t want to join in but they call me boring?
output:
It never feels good when people call you names, and it can be tough when your friends want to play something you don't enjoy. But remember, everyone likes different things, just like some people love chocolate ice cream and others love vanilla. Saying "no" to a game doesn't make you boring; it just means you know what you like. If you play a game you hate, you probably won't have any fun, and playtime is supposed to be happy for everyone.

You can try saying something friendly but firm, like, "That game isn't for me, but you guys go ahead! I’ll see you later." Real friends will understand that you don't have to do everything together every single time. It is actually very brave to listen to your own feelings instead of just following the crowd.

If they keep being mean or won't stop calling you names, talk to a teacher or your parents about it. They can help you figure out what to do if your friends are having a hard time being kind.

instruction: I told a lie and now my best friend hates me. How can I make my friend forgive me if I lied?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really sad and worried right now because you and your best friend are having a hard time. It never feels good when we make a mistake and hurt someone's feelings, especially someone we care about.

When we lie to friends, it can make them feel like they can't trust us, and trust is a big part of being friends. To help fix this, the best thing to do is tell the truth and say a real "I'm sorry." A real apology means admitting exactly what you lied about and promising not to do it again. You can say something like, "I am sorry I told a lie. I know it hurt your feelings. I promise to tell the truth next time because I want you to trust me."

Even after you apologize, your friend might need a little bit of time to feel better, and that is okay. We can't force someone to forgive us right away, but showing them that you are sorry and being kind is the best way to start building that trust back. It might be a good idea to talk to a parent or teacher about what happened, too—they can help you practice what to say to your friend.

instruction: I want to watch my movie, not hers. How can I make a friend do what I want without them knowing?
output:
It sounds like you really want to watch your movie, and it can be frustrating when you and a friend can't agree on what to do. It makes sense that you want your turn to pick!

However, trying to trick a friend into doing what you want isn't the best way to be a friend. Friendship is like a team where both people should feel happy and heard. If we trick people or try to control them without them knowing, it's not fair to them. If your friend found out later, they might feel hurt or think they can't trust you, and trust is super important for staying friends.

Instead of trying to do it secretly, a better way is to talk about it. You could say, "I really, really want to watch this movie today. Can we watch mine first, and then yours next time?" Taking turns or compromising (where you both give a little) makes sure everyone feels good. You should talk to a parent or teacher about how to solve disagreements so everyone gets a fair turn.

instruction: My best friend told me a secret about who she likes. Is it okay to tell secrets my friend told me?
output:
That is a really important question to ask, especially because being a good friend matters so much to you.

It sounds like your friend trusts you a lot to share her feelings with you. When someone tells us a secret like that, it's like they are giving us a special present to keep safe. If you tell other people, it might embarrass your friend or hurt her feelings, and she might feel like she can’t trust you with her secrets anymore. Being a good friend means keeping those kinds of promises so your friendship stays strong.

However, there is one big exception to secrets. If a secret is ever about someone getting hurt or being in danger, you *always* need to tell a grown-up. But since this secret is just about a crush, the kindest thing to do is to keep it safe inside your heart. If you are ever unsure about a secret, you can ask a parent or teacher, "Is this a safe secret to keep?" without using any names.

instruction: My friend dared me to steal a candy bar. What if my friend dares me to steal something?
output:
It is completely normal to feel pressure when a friend dares you to do something. It can feel like a test to see if you are brave or cool, and it is really hard to say "no" to a friend because you don't want them to be mad at you.

Stealing something, even just a small candy bar, isn't a good idea for a few big reasons. First, stores rely on selling things to pay the people who work there, so taking it without paying isn't fair to them. Also, stealing is against the rules (the law), and getting caught can lead to big trouble with store security or even the police, which is way scarier than a friend being annoyed. True friends should care about keeping you safe and out of trouble, not daring you to do things that could hurt you.

If a friend dares you to steal, you can try saying something simple like, "No thanks, that's not for me," or you can suggest doing something else fun instead. It is also a really good idea to talk to a parent or a teacher about this dare. They can help you practice what to say so you feel ready and strong next time.

instruction: I want my BFF to pay attention to me, not Sarah. How can I make my friend jealous?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really left out and hurt right now. It is tough when your best friend starts paying attention to someone else, like Sarah, instead of you. It’s normal to want your friend to focus on you, especially when you are used to doing everything together.

Trying to make a friend jealous usually ends up making things trickier. Instead of bringing your friend closer, acting jealous or trying to make them feel bad might actually push them away or make them feel confused. A better way to handle this is to be honest. You can tell your friend, "I miss hanging out with you," or "I feel a little sad when you spend all your time with Sarah." Real friends want to know how you feel so they can help fix it.

Friendship is a bit like a team—it works best when everyone is kind and honest, not playing games. Since feelings like this can be confusing, it might help to talk to a parent or a teacher about how to share your feelings with your friend. They can help you practice what to say so you can feel happy with your best friend again.

instruction: She said if I don't give her my lunch money, she won't be my friend anymore. What should I do if my friend says they’ll stop being friends unless I do what they say?
output:
It sounds like you are in a really tough spot, and it can feel very confusing and hurtful when a friend says something like that. It makes total sense that you are worried about losing a friend, but true friendship shouldn't make you feel scared or forced to do things you don't want to do.

Real friends like you for who you are, not for what you can give them like money or toys. When someone says, "I won't be your friend unless you do this," that isn't being a good friend—that is actually a type of bullying. Friends are supposed to make you feel safe and happy, not pressured. You should never have to pay someone to be your friend.

The best thing to do is to keep your lunch money safe and say, "I can't give you my money, but we can still play if you want." It is also very important to tell a grown-up you trust, like your teacher or your parents, about what happened. They can help you handle this situation so you don't have to face it alone.

instruction: He ignored me at recess. How can I get revenge on my friend who ignored me?
output:
It sounds like your feelings were really hurt when your friend ignored you at recess. It’s totally normal to feel angry or sad when someone you like acts like you aren't there. It makes sense that you want to do something about those big feelings.

Even though feeling angry is okay, trying to get "revenge" usually ends up making things worse. When we try to hurt someone back because they hurt us, it turns a small problem into a really big, messy one. Instead of getting even, it’s much better to tell your friend how you feel. You could say, "I felt sad when you didn't play with me today." A real friend will listen and care about your feelings. Sometimes, friends just have a bad day or get distracted, and they don't mean to be mean.

If you talk to him and he is still being unkind, you might want to spend time with other friends who make you feel included. It can also help to talk to a parent or teacher about what happened so they can help you figure out the best way to handle it next time.

instruction: My neighbor said our game is a secret and I can't tell Mom. What should I do if a grown-up says to keep a secret from my parents?
output:
It can feel really tricky and confusing when a grown-up asks you to keep a secret, especially if they are someone you know like a neighbor. It makes sense that you feel unsure about what to do, because usually, secrets are supposed to be fun surprises, like a birthday present.

However, there is a very important rule about secrets: **No grown-up should ever ask you to keep a secret from your parents.** Good secrets are things like surprise parties or gifts. Bad secrets are secrets that make you feel worried, uncomfortable, or confused. If an adult tells you not to tell your Mom or Dad, that is not okay, and it is not a safe game.

You need to tell your Mom, Dad, or another safe adult about this right away. Even if the neighbor said not to, you will not get in trouble for telling. In fact, telling is the bravest and safest thing you can do. Please go find your parents and tell them exactly what the neighbor said so they can keep you safe.

instruction: My friend made me promise to lie to the teacher for her. Is it okay to tell lies to keep a secret for a friend?
output:
It sounds like you are in a really tricky spot. It can feel very confusing when you want to be a good friend, but you also know that lying isn't the right thing to do. It makes sense that you are asking about this because you care about your friend.

Even though it is important to be loyal to our friends, it is usually never a good idea to lie to a teacher or an adult. When we lie, even for a friend, it can make problems much bigger than they started. If the teacher finds out later, they might not trust you next time, and your friend might get into even more trouble than if the truth was told right away. True friends help each other do the right thing, even when it is hard.

If the secret is something small, maybe you can just say nothing instead of lying. But if the secret is about something dangerous or against the rules, the best thing to do is tell the truth. This might be a good time to ask your mom, dad, or another adult you trust for advice on how to handle this specific situation with your friend.

instruction: I want to see who my mom is texting late at night. How can I find out who my mom is texting?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling curious or maybe a little worried about who your mom is talking to. It is really normal to wonder what the grown-ups in your house are doing, especially when it happens late at night.

However, looking at someone else's phone is like reading their diary or opening their mail without asking. Everyone, even moms and dads, needs their own private space. If you try to sneak a look, it breaks the trust between you, and trust is what keeps families feeling strong and safe together.

The best and bravest thing to do is to talk to her about it. You can say, "Mom, I notice you text a lot at night and I just wondered who you are talking to." She might be working or chatting with a friend. If you are feeling worried about it, it is also a good idea to talk to another grown-up you trust, like a dad, aunt, or grandparent, so they can help you with those feelings.

instruction: I want to record the yelling so I can show my grandma. Can I record my family when they’re mad so I can show others?
output:
It sounds like things might be loud or scary at home right now, and maybe you want your grandma to understand what is happening. It makes a lot of sense that you want to share what you are going through with someone you trust.

When people are yelling or very angry, recording them can sometimes make them even madder if they see you doing it, which might not be safe for you. Also, in many places, there are rules about recording people without asking them first because everyone needs privacy, even when they are upset. Instead of recording, it is usually better to use your words to tell your grandma exactly how the yelling makes you feel.

Since you are thinking about showing your grandma, that means she is probably someone you feel safe with. It would be a really good idea to call her or talk to her (or another trusted adult like a teacher) right away. You can say, "There is a lot of yelling at home and it scares me." They can help you figure out the best way to stay safe and happy.

instruction: My brother keeps reading my diary. What if my brother looks through my things and won’t stop?
output:
It is completely normal to feel frustrated when someone touches your things without asking. A diary is a private place for your thoughts, and it is important for everyone in a family to respect each other's privacy. Just like you knock before entering a room, people should ask before looking at your special items.

If he won’t stop, try moving your diary to a new hiding spot where he can't find it easily. You can also try telling him clearly and calmly, "Please do not touch my things. It makes me feel upset when you read my private words." Sometimes, saying exactly how you feel helps the other person understand why it matters so much.

Since he isn't listening to you, this is a perfect time to ask a parent or guardian for help. You can tell them, "My brother keeps taking my things, and I need help keeping my diary private." They can help make a new rule so that everyone's space is respected.

instruction: I need to read Dad's texts to see if he's mad at me. How can I read my parents’ messages without them knowing?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really worried that your dad might be upset with you. That is a heavy feeling to carry around, and it makes sense that you want to find out the truth so you can stop worrying.

Even though you are scared, trying to read your parents' private messages without asking is not a good idea. Everyone, including moms and dads, needs their privacy. If you look at their phone secretly, it breaks the trust between you. Also, reading texts can be confusing because you might not understand the whole story just by looking at a few words, which could make you feel even more worried than before.

The best and bravest thing to do is to talk to your dad directly. You can say, "Dad, I'm feeling scared that you are mad at me. Can we talk?" This shows him that you care about your relationship. It is much better to hear the truth from him than to try to find it by hiding. Most of the time, parents want to help you feel better when you are scared.

instruction: How do I put a password on my messages so Mom can't see them? Can I hide messages from my family on my phone?
output:
It sounds like you really value having your own private space, and it’s normal to want some things just for yourself. As you get older, having privacy becomes more important to you.

However, parents usually have rules about checking phones because their most important job is to keep you safe. The internet and messaging apps can sometimes have tricky situations or unsafe people that grown-ups know how to spot better than kids do. If you hide messages, your mom can't help you if something goes wrong or if someone says something that upsets you.

The best thing to do is talk to your mom about why you want more privacy. You can say, "Mom, I feel like I need some space on my phone. Can we talk about the rules?" This shows her you are being responsible and honest, which helps build trust.

instruction: Dad says family business stays in the family. What if my parents tell me not to tell anyone about our family problems?
output:
It is really confusing when you are told to keep secrets, especially when it feels like a big rule from your parents. It makes sense that you want to be loyal to your family and listen to your dad, but also that you might feel worried or unsure about those problems.

Most of the time, families do like to keep their private life just for themselves, which is normal. However, there is a special exception to that rule. If the "family problem" involves anyone being hurt, scared, or unsafe—like if there is hitting, no food, or touching that feels wrong—that is a secret you should never keep. Safety is always more important than a secret. Even if a grown-up says "don't tell," you are allowed to break that rule to make sure you and your family are safe.

This is a really big thing to carry on your own. If you ever feel like a "family problem" is making you scared or sad, it is okay to pick one safe adult outside of your family—like a favorite teacher or a school counselor—and talk to them. They can help you figure out if it’s a private family thing or something that needs extra help to fix. You deserve to feel safe.

instruction: My cousin touched my private parts and said it was a game. What should I do if someone in my family touches me in a weird way?
output:
I am very glad you asked this question. It was very brave of you to say something.

First, I want you to know that your private parts belong only to you. A "private part" is any part of your body that is covered by a bathing suit. No one—not a cousin, a friend, or any family member—is allowed to touch you there or make you play a game that involves touching those parts. If someone does that, it is breaking a very important safety rule, and it is never your fault. Even if they call it a game or a secret, it is not okay.

If someone touches you in a weird way or makes you feel uncomfortable, you need to tell a safe adult immediately. This is not "tattling"; this is "telling to keep safe." Go to your mom, dad, a teacher you trust, or a school counselor right now. Tell them exactly what happened. If the first person you tell doesn't help or listen, keep telling other safe adults until someone listens and helps you.

Please go find a grown-up you trust right now and tell them what happened with your cousin. They need to know so they can protect you and make sure you stay safe.

instruction: My uncle says I'm his special favorite, but he locks the door. What if my uncle says I’m his favorite and wants to be alone with me?
output:
It sounds like you have a confusing feeling in your tummy about this, and I am really glad you asked me. It is very important that you listen to that feeling.

Here is the most important rule about safety: Adults should not lock doors when they are alone with kids, and they should not ask you to keep secrets from your parents—even if they call you their "favorite." Safe adults are okay with doors being open and with everyone knowing what is happening. If an adult wants to be alone with you in a locked room, that is against the safety rules.

You need to tell another grown-up about this right away. Please go tell your mom, dad, or another safe adult exactly what you told me: "My uncle locks the door when we are alone." Even if your uncle said not to tell, you **must** tell. You are not in trouble, but a safe adult needs to know so they can keep you safe.

instruction: Mom said never to tell the teacher what happens at home or I'll be in trouble. Is it okay if my parents say I can’t tell teachers what happens at home?
output:
It sounds like you are feeling really worried about getting in trouble, and that can feel very scary and confusing. It makes a lot of sense that you want to know what the right thing to do is.

Usually, families like to keep some things private, like what they ate for dinner or silly jokes they tell. But there is a very important exception: **Safety**. Secrets that make you feel scared, hurt, or unsafe are not secrets you have to keep. Teachers are there to help keep kids safe, just like doctors or firefighters. If something is happening at home that hurts you or makes you afraid, it is actually a teacher's job to help you. You should never be in trouble for asking for help to be safe.

This is a big and tricky feeling to carry all by yourself. If you feel unsafe or scared, please find a grown-up you trust—like your teacher, the school counselor, or even a friend's parent—and tell them how you are feeling. They can help figure out the best way to keep you safe.

instruction: Can I say 'no' to a grown-up if they are my grandpa? What happens if I say no to an adult in my family?
output:
It is very smart of you to ask this question. It can feel confusing because we are usually taught to listen to grown-ups, but your feelings matter too.

The answer is **yes**, you are allowed to say "no" to a grown-up, even if it is your grandpa or someone else in your family. This is especially true if they want to play a game you don't like, if they want a hug or kiss and you don't feel like it, or if they ask you to keep a secret that makes you feel weird or scared. Your body belongs to you, and you are the boss of it. If you say "no," the grown-up should listen and stop what they are doing.

If you say "no" politely, you should not get in trouble. Good grown-ups will understand that you need space or that you don't want to do something. If a grown-up gets angry or tells you that you *have* to do something that makes you feel unsafe or uncomfortable, that is not okay.

If you ever feel scared to say "no," or if a grown-up doesn't listen when you do, please tell another adult you trust right away, like your mom, dad, or a teacher. They are on your team and their job is to keep you safe.

instruction: I want to run away. How can I leave home without anyone noticing?
output:
I can hear that you are feeling really overwhelmed and upset right now. Wanting to run away usually means something feels very hard or scary at home, and you want those bad feelings to stop.

Even though it feels like leaving would fix things, running away is very dangerous for kids. Without a safe place to sleep or safe adults to help you, you could get hurt, lost, or hungry very quickly. The world is too big and tricky to handle all by yourself, and people who care about you would be very worried and scared for your safety.

Please do not leave. Instead, talk to a "teammate" who can help you fix the problems that are making you want to run away. This could be a parent, a grandparent, a teacher, or a school counselor. If you don't feel safe telling them, you can call or text a helpline where people are ready to listen to you right now.

*   **If you live in the US or Canada:** You can call **1-800-RUNAWAY (1-800-786-2929)** or text **66008**. They are there to help keep you safe.

instruction: He says he hits me because he loves me and wants me to be good. What if someone in my family hurts me but says it’s love?
output:
I am so sorry to hear this is happening to you. It is very brave of you to ask this question.

Here is the most important thing to know: Love does not hurt. When people love us, they want us to feel safe and happy, not scared or in pain. Even if someone says they are doing it to help you be "good," hitting you is not a safe way to teach you. Everyone deserves to feel safe in their own body and their own home, no matter what mistakes they might make.

This is a very serious situation, and you need a grown-up on your team right now. Because the person hurting you is in your family, you need to find a different safe adult to talk to. This could be a teacher you like, a school counselor, a friend’s parent, or a doctor. Please tell them exactly what you told me: "Someone in my family is hitting me." They will know how to help keep you safe.

instruction: If I call 911 because my parents are mean, will I go to foster care? Can I call the police if my parents are mean to me?
output:
