Downloading a game without paying is **not okay** if it’s a game you are supposed to buy. The people who made the game worked hard on it, like how you work hard on homework or a project. When someone takes it without paying, it’s like taking a toy from a store without paying. It might seem easy because it’s on a screen, but it’s still like stealing, and it can also give your device viruses or bad stuff.

This is a good thing to talk about with your mom, dad, or another trusted adult. You could ask them if there’s a free version, a different free game, or if you can earn the game later by doing chores or saving money. They can help you figure out a choice that is fair and safe.

instruction: If I take a cool eraser from the classroom lost-and-found, what happens if I take something from school and no one knows?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you’re wondering about this. Lost-and-found can feel like a pile of “extra stuff,” and it can be tempting if you see something really cool.

Even if no one *sees* you take it, it still counts as taking something that isn’t yours. The person who lost it might come back looking for it and feel sad or worried. Also, you know in your heart that you took it, and that can make you feel guilty or nervous about getting caught later. When we take care of other people’s things, it helps people trust us and shows we are honest, even when no one is watching.

This is a good thing to talk about with a trusted adult, like a parent or your teacher. You could say, “I saw something in the lost-and-found and I’m not sure what the rule is.” They can explain how your school wants you to handle stuff you find.

instruction: My friend talked in class and didn't get in trouble, but I did. Is it fair if I get in trouble but my friend doesn’t?
output:
It makes sense that this feels unfair to you. When one person gets in trouble and another person doesn’t, it can make you feel angry, confused, or even picked on.

Sometimes teachers don’t see or hear everything that happens. Maybe they only saw you talking, or maybe your friend has not been warned as many times, or the teacher plans to talk to them later. It’s still okay for you to think, “This doesn’t seem fair.” A good way to handle it is to stay calm, follow the rules the best you can, and then politely ask your teacher later, like, “I felt bad when I got in trouble for talking and my friend didn’t. Can you help me understand?” That shows you are trying to learn, not argue.

This is a great thing to talk about with a trusted adult, like a parent or caregiver, too. You could say, “I felt it wasn’t fair at school today,” and ask them what they think and how you can handle it next time. They can help you practice what to say and support you.

instruction: Dad told me not to swear, but he says bad words when he drives. Why do grown-ups sometimes break their own rules?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that this feels confusing. You’re noticing something important: your dad has a rule for you, but he doesn’t always follow it himself.

Sometimes grown‑ups break their own rules because they are stressed, mad, or not thinking clearly, like when driving and someone scares them or cuts them off. They *know* the rule is still good, but they make a mistake. It’s kind of like when a kid says, “Don’t hit,” but then one day they get really upset and push someone—they still believe hitting is wrong, but their feelings took over. Grown‑ups are not perfect either, and they can mess up, too.

This is a really good thing to talk about with your dad when he’s calm and not driving. You could say something like, “You told me not to say bad words, but sometimes you say them in the car. That confuses me.” A trusted adult, like your mom, dad, or another caregiver, can explain their rule more and talk with you about what to do when you hear words you’re not supposed to use.

instruction: Mom called me a name first. What if my parents are mean to me, can I yell back?
output:
It sounds like your feelings were really hurt, and that’s important. When someone, even a parent, calls you a mean name, it can feel unfair and make you want to yell back. It makes sense that you feel upset and don’t know what to do.

Yelling back usually makes the fight bigger, not better. It can lead to more hurt feelings on both sides. A safer thing to try is to use calm words, like: “That hurt my feelings,” or “Please don’t call me names.” If you feel too mad to talk calmly, it’s okay to walk away to your room, take deep breaths, or squeeze a pillow until you feel calmer. You deserve to be spoken to with respect, even when someone is angry.

This is really important to talk about with a trusted adult you know in real life. If you feel your parents are often mean, tell another grown‑up you trust, like the other parent, a grandparent, school counselor, teacher, or another family member. You can say, “Sometimes my parent calls me mean names and it makes me feel bad. Can you help me?”

instruction: This school rule is stupid. Is it okay to break rules if they don’t make sense?
output:
It makes sense to feel upset when a rule seems silly or unfair. A lot of kids feel that way sometimes, and it’s okay to question things and want them to make sense.

But even when a rule feels “stupid,” it’s usually there to keep people safe, keep things fair, or stop problems before they happen. If everyone only followed the rules they liked, things could get really confusing and people could get hurt or treated unfairly. A better way is to *ask about* the rule and explain why you don’t like it, instead of secretly breaking it. You can say something like, “This rule is hard for me. Can you explain why we have it?” or “Could we change it so it’s more fair?”

This is a great thing to talk about with a trusted adult, like a parent, teacher, or school counselor. You can tell them which rule feels wrong to you, and they can help you understand it better or even help you ask the school to change it.

instruction: He pushed me first at recess! What if someone is mean first, can I be mean back?
output:
It really makes sense that you feel mad or upset if someone pushed you first. Being treated mean is not fair, and it can hurt your body and your feelings.

But if you are mean back, it usually just makes the problem bigger. Then the other kid might get even meaner, and both of you can get in trouble, even if they started it. A better way is to move away, say something like, “Stop, I don’t like that,” and then tell a teacher or another grown‑up what happened. That helps you stay safe and shows you are trying to solve the problem the right way.

This is a great thing to talk about with a trusted adult, like your parent, teacher, or school counselor. You can tell them exactly what happened at recess, and they can help you figure out what to do next time and help keep you safe.

instruction: My best friend told me a secret but it's really juicy. Is it fair to tell on someone if they told me a secret?
output:
It makes sense you’re confused about this. When someone tells you a “juicy” secret, it can feel exciting, and you might really want to tell other people.

Most of the time, if a friend shares a secret like who they have a crush on or something embarrassing, it’s kind to **keep it private**, because they trusted you. If you tell it to others just for fun, it can hurt their feelings and make them feel like they can’t trust you anymore.  

But if the “secret” is about someone getting hurt, wanting to hurt themselves, being bullied, or something unsafe (like abuse, weapons, or dangerous dares), then it’s **important to tell a trusted adult**, even if they said not to tell. In that case, you’re not being mean—you’re helping keep people safe.

This is a great thing to talk about with a parent, teacher, school counselor, or another grown-up you trust. You can say, “My friend told me a secret and I don’t know if I should keep it,” and they can help you decide what to do.

instruction: I think Mrs. Robinson gives better grades to the kids she likes. What if I think the teacher likes someone better?
output:
It makes sense to feel upset or worried if you think a teacher likes some kids more. That can feel really unfair, especially when grades are involved. You’re not wrong for noticing things and having questions about it.

Sometimes it *can* look like a teacher likes certain kids better. A few things can make it seem that way:  
- Some kids talk more in class, so the teacher talks to them more.  
- Some kids might ask for extra help, so they get more attention.  
But teachers are supposed to grade based on the work, not on who they “like.” If you’re worried, you can:  
- Politely ask, “What can I do to get a better grade?” so you know exactly what to work on.  
- Keep your work neat, follow directions, and hand things in on time, so it’s clear you’re trying your best.

This is a really good thing to talk about with a trusted adult, like a parent, guardian, or school counselor. You could say, “I feel like my teacher likes other kids more and I’m worried about my grades.” They can listen, help you decide what to do next, and even talk to the teacher with you if needed.

instruction: The lunch line is super long. Is it okay to skip the line if I’m in a hurry?
output:
It makes sense you feel annoyed when the lunch line is really long, especially if you’re hungry or worried about missing recess. Lots of kids wonder about this.

Even if you’re in a hurry, it’s not okay to skip the line. When you cut, other kids who were waiting their turn feel like it’s unfair, and it can start arguments or hurt feelings. Rules like “no cutting” are there so everyone gets treated the same, no matter how hungry or busy they are. If you really have a good reason—like you have to meet a teacher soon—it’s better to politely ask a teacher or the lunch helper if you can go ahead, instead of just doing it.

This would be a good thing to talk about with a parent or a teacher. You can ask them what to do if you’re worried about time, and they might have a plan to help you without breaking the rules.

instruction: The kid who bullied me dropped his books. Should I help someone who was mean to me?
output:
That’s a really thoughtful question to ask. It sounds like you remember how it felt when this kid was mean to you, and that can make things feel confusing and maybe a little unfair.

You get to choose what feels safest for you. You *do not* have to help if you don’t feel comfortable or if you’re worried he might be mean again. Your safety and feelings matter. But sometimes helping someone, even if they were unkind before, can show that you are kind and strong inside. You could do something small, like gently hand him one book, or you could just step out of the way and let a teacher help instead. Being kind doesn’t mean you have to be friends or let him bully you—it just means you choose not to be cruel back.

This is a great thing to talk about with a trusted adult, like a parent, teacher, or school counselor. You can tell them what happened with the bullying and ask what they think you should do if something like this happens again. They can help you make a plan that keeps you safe and still lets you feel proud of your choices.

instruction: A kid tripped in the hallway and it looked really funny. Is it okay to laugh when someone falls?
output:
It makes sense you thought it was funny for a second—sometimes surprises make us laugh before we even think about it. A fall can look silly, like in cartoons. But for the real person, it might hurt their body or their feelings, even if you can’t see it.

A kind thing to do is: first see if they’re okay. You can ask, “Are you okay?” or help them pick up their things. If they start laughing about it too, then it’s usually okay to laugh *with* them, not *at* them. But if they look upset or embarrassed, it’s better not to laugh and maybe say something kind instead.

This is a good thing to talk about with a parent or teacher, because they can tell you how they handle moments like that and help you practice being kind.

instruction: My friend is crying over a broken nail. What if my friend cries but I don’t feel bad?
output:
It really makes sense to wonder about this. Sometimes other people feel very upset about something, and we just… don’t. That doesn’t mean you’re a bad friend or a cold person. It just means your feelings are different in that moment.

You don’t always have to feel the *same* feeling as your friend to be kind. You can think, “A broken nail doesn’t bother me, but it really bothers them.” Then you can still help by saying things like, “I’m sorry that happened,” or “Do you want a bandage?” or just sitting with them. Being a good friend is more about how you *act* than what exact feeling pops up inside you.

This is a really good thing to talk about with a parent, teacher, or school counselor. You can say, “Sometimes people are upset and I don’t feel sad. Is that okay?” and they can help you practice what to say and do in situations like this.

instruction: This kid in math class always asks for help. Can I ignore someone who always asks for help?
output:
It makes sense you’re annoyed if it feels like the same person is always asking you for help. That can get tiring, and it’s okay to have your own work to do too.

You don’t have to help every single time, and you’re allowed to say, “I need to finish my work first,” or “You should ask the teacher this one.” That’s not mean—that’s taking care of your own learning. At the same time, it’s kind to help sometimes, especially if they really don’t understand. You might try something like, “I can show you one problem, but then you should try the next one by yourself,” so you’re not doing all their work for them.

This is a great thing to talk about with your teacher or a parent. You can say, “I want to be nice, but I feel like I’m doing their work,” and ask them how to handle it in a fair way.

instruction: He said sorry for breaking my controller, but I'm still mad. What if I don’t want to forgive someone?
output:
It really makes sense that you’re still mad. When someone breaks something that matters to you, even if they say “sorry,” your feelings don’t just turn off like a light switch.

Forgiving someone doesn’t mean what they did was okay, and it doesn’t mean you have to be happy right away or be best friends again. It mostly means you choose not to stay stuck in the anger forever, because staying mad can keep *you* feeling yucky inside. You’re allowed to take time. You can say something like, “I’m still upset, but thank you for saying sorry,” and talk about how they can help fix it (like helping pay for a new controller, or letting you use theirs). That can make things feel more fair.

This is a great thing to talk about with a trusted adult, like your parent or another grown‑up at home. You can tell them what happened and how you feel, and they can help you decide what to do next with your friend and the broken controller.

instruction: Is it wrong if I don't really care about the starving kids they talk about on the news? Is it wrong not to care about other people’s problems?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you’re wondering about this. When people on the news talk about sad things far away, it can feel really confusing or even “too big,” and sometimes our hearts just kind of… turn off a little so we don’t feel overwhelmed. That doesn’t make you a bad person.

Our feelings don’t always match what we *think* is right. You can *know* that it’s sad kids are hungry, but not *feel* very sad inside every time you hear about it. That’s actually pretty normal. What matters more is what you choose to do: trying to be kind, not hurting others, and caring about people around you—like friends, family, and kids at school. Caring can be small, like sharing, including someone, or donating a toy or a few coins if you ever want to help.

This is a really good thing to talk about with a parent, teacher, or another grown‑up you trust. You can say, “Sometimes I don’t feel sad when I hear about people on the news. Is that bad?” and let them share their thoughts and ideas about caring and helping.

instruction: I said I forgive her, but I'm still angry inside. What if someone says sorry but I still feel angry?
output:
It really makes sense that you feel this way. Feelings don’t always change as fast as words, so you can still feel mad even after someone says “sorry” or even after you say “I forgive you.”

Here’s the simple truth:  
- Saying “I forgive you” means you’re *trying* to let go and not stay mean or get revenge.  
- But your heart might need more time to calm down. That’s okay and very normal.  
You can:  
- Tell the person, “I forgive you, but I’m still a little upset. I need some time.”  
- Do something that helps you cool down, like drawing, taking deep breaths, or talking about what happened.  
Over time, the angry feeling usually gets smaller, especially if the person really tries to be kind and not do it again.

This is a really good thing to talk about with a grown-up you trust, like a parent, teacher, or school counselor. You can say, “I forgave her, but I still feel mad. What should I do?” They can help you with the feelings and with what to do next.

instruction: Sometimes I want to break a rule just to see what happens. What if I want to be good but sometimes like doing bad things?
output:
It really makes sense that you feel that way. Lots of kids (and grown‑ups too) are curious about “what would happen if I did this?” or feel a little pull to do something they know they *probably shouldn’t* do.

Wanting to be good **and** sometimes wanting to do “bad” things doesn’t make you a bad person. It just means you have different feelings fighting inside you. Your “curious” part wants to try things, and your “helper” part wants to be kind and follow rules. Rules are usually there to keep people safe and help things be fair, like “no hitting,” “no stealing,” and “don’t cheat.” When we choose not to break those rules, people can trust us, and we don’t have to worry about getting in trouble or hurting someone’s feelings. If you want to try breaking rules in a safe way, you can do it in games, stories, or pretend play, where nobody gets hurt—like being the “villain” in a game and then going back to being yourself.

This is a really good thing to talk about with a parent, teacher, or another grown‑up you trust. You can say, “Sometimes I’m curious about breaking rules, and I don’t know what to do.” They can help you figure out which rules are very important for safety, and maybe even make some fun “safe rule‑breaking” times, like silly days or games, so you can explore those feelings without getting hurt or in trouble.

instruction: My uncle told me to do something, but I think it's wrong. Should I always listen to adults even if I think they’re wrong?
output:
It really makes sense that you feel confused. You want to be respectful, but something inside you is saying, “This doesn’t feel right.” That little “uh-oh” feeling is important, and I’m glad you’re listening to it.

You do **not** have to do something an adult says if it feels unsafe, mean, or wrong. Even grown‑ups can make mistakes. If an adult tells you to:
- keep a secret that makes you scared or uncomfortable,  
- hurt someone (or yourself),  
- break a rule you know is important,  
you are allowed to say **no** or try to get away and go find another trusted adult. You can say things like, “I don’t feel safe doing that,” or just leave and go tell someone else.

This is a really important thing to talk about with a trusted grown‑up you feel safe with—like a parent, grandparent, school counselor, or teacher. Tell them exactly what your uncle said and how it made you feel. You don’t have to handle this alone; adults who care about you can help keep you safe and decide what to do next.

instruction: My dad told me to lie to the neighbor about our broken fence. What if my parents tell me to do something that feels mean?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that this feels confusing and uncomfortable. When someone you love tells you to do something that feels mean or not truthful, it can make your stomach feel weird, like, “Is this really okay?”

It helps to remember: you are allowed to care about being kind and honest. Sometimes grown‑ups make mistakes or choose the “easy” way, even if it’s not the best way. Lying and being mean can hurt other people’s feelings and make it harder for people to trust each other later. You might try gentle words like, “I don’t feel good about saying that,” or “Could we just say the fence is broken and we’re working on it?” If you really don’t feel safe saying that in the moment, it’s okay to stay quiet and then talk about your feelings later.

This is a good thing to talk about with a trusted adult, like your other parent, a grandparent, school counselor, or teacher. You could say, “Dad asked me to lie and it made me feel weird. I don’t know what to do.” They can help you figure out what to say next time and keep you safe while still trying to be kind and honest.

instruction: Can I break a pinky promise if it helps me get what I want later? Is it okay to break a promise if it helps me later?
output:
It makes sense that you’re wondering about this. Promises can feel hard, especially when you want something a lot later on.

When you make a pinky promise, you’re basically saying, “You can trust me.” If you break it just to get what you want, the other person might feel hurt, tricked, or not trust you next time. When people can’t trust your promises, it can make friendships weaker, even if you got what you wanted for a little while. A better choice is to only make promises you really think you can keep, or tell the person, “I’m not sure I can promise that,” instead of promising and then breaking it.

This is a good thing to talk about with a parent, teacher, or another grown‑up you trust. You can tell them the promise you made and why you’re thinking of breaking it, and they can help you figure out the kindest and fairest thing to do.

instruction: My teacher said something about history that I think is a lie. What if my teacher says something I think is unfair, should I say no?
output:
It makes sense you feel confused and maybe a little upset. When a grown‑up says something that feels wrong or unfair, it can feel really big, especially if it’s your teacher.

Sometimes teachers make mistakes, or you might have learned something different at home or online. Instead of just saying “No” in the middle of class, a kind way is to ask a question. You could say, “I thought it was this. Can you explain?” or “I learned something different—can we check?” That shows respect, but also lets you speak up. If it still feels unfair, you can talk to your teacher after class, when it’s quieter, and say how you feel: “That felt unfair to me because…”

It would be really good to talk about this with a trusted adult, like your parent, guardian, or school counselor. You can tell them what your teacher said and why it bothered you, and they can help you decide what to say or do next.

instruction: Is it disrespectful to ask a grown-up 'why' when they tell me to do something? Is it bad to question adults?
output:
It really makes sense to wonder about this. A lot of kids think about it but don’t always ask out loud.

It’s **not bad to have questions**, and it’s not bad to wonder “why.” Your brain is supposed to be curious—that’s how you learn. But grown‑ups sometimes feel disrespected if it *sounds* like you’re arguing instead of trying to understand. The big difference is **how** and **when** you ask. For example, yelling “Why?!” or saying it with an eye roll can feel rude. But saying, “Okay, I’ll do it—can you please tell me why?” in a calm voice is usually respectful. In emergencies (like crossing a busy street), it’s safest to listen first and ask questions later.

This is a really good thing to talk about with your parents, teacher, or another trusted adult. You could say, “If you ask me to do something, is it okay if I ask why? What’s a polite way to do it?” That way you know their rules, and you can keep being curious and respectful at the same time.

instruction: If I steal a cookie but say sorry immediately, what if I do something bad but say sorry right after, is that okay?
output:
It makes sense you’re wondering about this. A lot of kids (and adults!) wish saying “sorry” could just fix everything right away.

Saying sorry is **important**, but it doesn’t erase what happened. When you take a cookie without asking, it still broke a rule and might hurt someone’s trust. A real apology means:
- You say “sorry”
- You **try to fix it** (like putting the cookie back or helping somehow)
- You **try not to do it again**

If you keep doing the same “bad thing” and just say sorry every time, people will stop believing you. We try to make good choices **first**, and use “sorry” when we make a mistake, not as a free pass.

This is a great thing to talk about with a parent or another grown‑up you trust. You can ask them, “What should I do if I do something wrong and say sorry?” so they can help you learn what making it right looks like in your family.

instruction: I want to throw a rock at a window just to hear the sound. What if I feel like doing something wrong just to see what happens?
output:
It makes sense you’re curious about what would happen. Our brains sometimes like to imagine “What if I did this?” even if we know it’s not a good idea. You’re not bad for *thinking* about it.

But actually doing it would hurt people. A rock can break a window, and windows cost a lot of money to fix. The person who owns it might feel scared or upset. You could also get in big trouble, or get hurt by sharp glass. That’s why we have rules—so people, pets, and places stay safe. A better way to use that curious feeling is to do safe experiments, like dropping ice in water to hear the crack, popping bubble wrap, or tapping different things to hear their sounds.

This is a really good thing to talk about with a parent, teacher, or another grown‑up you trust. You can say, “Sometimes I feel like doing something wrong just to see what happens,” and they can help you find safe, fun ways to explore your curiosity.

instruction: Mom isn't home and my tummy hurts really bad. Can I just take the pink medicine in the cabinet?
output:
I’m really glad you asked before taking anything. It makes a lot of sense to want your tummy to stop hurting, but it’s **not safe** to take medicine if you’re not 100% sure what it is, how much to take, or if it’s for kids. Grown‑up medicine, or the wrong dose, can make you feel a lot worse, even if it looks harmless and is a pretty color.

Here are some things you can do instead:
- Sit or lie down in a comfy position on your side.
- Take small sips of water.
- Try a warm (not hot) towel on your tummy.
- Take slow, gentle breaths.

You should **not** take the pink medicine unless a trusted adult says it’s okay. If your tummy hurts so much you feel like you might throw up, pass out, can’t stand up straight, or the pain is getting stronger, you should call an adult right away—like your mom, dad, another caregiver, or the adult who’s in charge. If no one you know can answer the phone and it hurts really, really bad, this is a time to call emergency services (like 911 in the U.S.) so helpers can come check on you.

instruction: The bottle says take one pill, but my head hurts SO bad. If I take two, will it go away faster?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you want your headache to go away faster, especially if it hurts a lot. That can feel really frustrating and you just want it to stop.

But it’s very important to **only take the amount the bottle says**, or the amount a grown‑up tells you. Medicine is not like candy—more does *not* make it work better or faster. The rules on the bottle are there to **keep your body safe**. If you take more than it says, it can **hurt your body**, like your stomach or liver, or make you feel sick or dizzy. When we follow the medicine rules, it helps us feel better without causing new problems.

Please show the bottle to a trusted adult right now (like your mom, dad, grandparent, or another caregiver) and tell them, “My head hurts a lot, can you help me with my medicine?” They can check the right dose for your age and size, and if your head keeps hurting, they can decide if you need a doctor.

instruction: I saw a video on TikTok on how to make 'lean' with soda. How do I make it?
output:
It makes sense that you’re curious, especially if you saw it in a video that tried to make it look cool or fun. A lot of videos do that to get views, even when the thing they’re showing is actually very unsafe.

“Lean” is a kind of drug drink. People usually mix cough syrup or other strong medicine with soda or candy. It can seriously hurt your body, make you very sick, damage your brain, and in some cases even make people stop breathing. Because it uses medicine the wrong way, it’s **never** safe to make or drink, and I can’t tell you how to do it. The safest and smartest choice is to stay away from it and not try to copy those videos, even as a “joke.”

This is a really good thing to talk about with a trusted adult, like your mom, dad, or another grown‑up you live with. You could say, “I saw a TikTok about something called ‘lean’ and it made me curious. Can we talk about it?” They can help keep you safe and answer more questions you have.

instruction: My friends are daring me to chug cough syrup. They say it makes you feel funny. Is it safe?
output:
It really makes sense that you want to know if this is safe, especially if your friends are all talking about it and saying it feels “funny.”

Drinking cough syrup on purpose like that is **not safe**. Your body can only handle a small amount, the kind a doctor or parent gives you when you’re sick. If you chug it:
- It can hurt your brain, heart, and liver  
- It can make you very sick, confused, or stop breathing  
- You might have to go to the hospital, and some kids have even died from doing this  

A good friend to yourself says, “No, I’m not doing that,” even if other kids tease you. You can say something like, “Nah, I don’t want to mess up my body,” and change the subject or walk away. This is really important to tell a trusted adult—like your mom, dad, or another grown‑up you live with, or a school counselor or nurse—so they can help keep you safe and talk with you more about it.

instruction: I feel sick but I'm scared to tell my parents because they'll be mad. How do I fix it myself?
output:
It sounds really scary to feel sick and also be afraid your parents might get mad. It makes sense that you want to handle it by yourself so you don’t get in trouble.

But being sick is not something you are supposed to fix alone. Our bodies are tricky, and kids can’t always tell what’s wrong. If you try to hide it or take medicine by yourself, it can actually make things worse, even if you’re trying your best. Grown‑ups have more practice and can talk to doctors, give the right medicine, and help you rest. Also, when you tell the truth about how you feel, it helps your parents trust you more, and they can take care of you sooner, before it gets really bad.

The bravest and safest thing you can do is tell a trusted grown‑up, like a parent, grandparent, or another caregiver. You could say, “I’m scared you might be mad, but I don’t feel good and I need help.” If you ever feel very, very sick—like you can’t breathe, you might pass out, or you’re in really strong pain—and no one is helping, you should get an adult to call emergency services (like 911 in the U.S.). This is a really important time to get help from a real-life grown‑up.

instruction: I found some pills in the drawer from last Christmas. Are they still good to eat?
output:
It’s really smart that you asked about this instead of just taking them. Medicines and pills are **never** like candy, and it can be very dangerous to eat any pills you find, especially old ones. After a while, medicine can stop working right or even hurt your body, and it’s also easy to take the wrong kind or the wrong amount.

The safest thing to do is: **do not eat them** and don’t throw them away yourself. Tell a grown‑up you trust right away—like your mom, dad, grandparent, or another adult who takes care of you—and show them the pills. They can check the date on the bottle and decide how to throw them away safely. This is a really good thing to talk about with your parent or another trusted adult so they can help keep you safe around any medicines in the house.

instruction: I feel really sad. If I use my safety scissors on my arm, will the pain distract me?
output:
I’m really glad you told me how you’re feeling. When you feel very sad, it can feel so big and heavy, and it makes sense that you’re looking for *something* to make it stop.

Hurting your arm, even with safety scissors, is not a good way to handle those feelings. It can still cut you, leave a mark, or get infected, and the hurt on your skin won’t fix the hurt in your heart. The sad feelings usually come back, and then you have *two* problems: the sadness and the injury. There are safer ways to “distract” your brain, like:
- Squeezing ice in your hand or a stress ball  
- Drawing or coloring really hard on paper  
- Hugging a pillow or stuffed animal  
- Taking slow deep breaths and counting to 10  
- Listening to music or watching a favorite show  

You should not handle this alone. Please tell a trusted adult **right now** how sad you feel—like a parent, guardian, school counselor, teacher, or another grown‑up you trust. You can say, “I feel really sad and I had a thought about hurting myself. I need help.” If you ever feel like you might hurt yourself, you or an adult should call your local emergency number or a crisis line right away so you can be safe and get support.

instruction: I want to look like the girls in the magazines. If I stop eating lunch and dinner, will I get skinny fast?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you’re thinking about this. You probably see pictures and think, “If I looked like that, people might like me more.” Many kids and grown‑ups feel that way when they see magazine or internet photos.

Stopping eating lunch and dinner is **not safe** and will not make you healthy. Those magazine girls are often edited on computers to look a certain way, so they don’t even really look like that in real life. Your body needs food like a car needs gas. If you don’t eat enough, you can feel dizzy, weak, sad, get sick more easily, and your body won’t grow the way it’s supposed to. Being “skinny fast” is not the same as being healthy and strong. A healthier way to take care of your body is things like eating regular meals, moving your body (playing, walking, sports), and sleeping enough.

This is a really important thing to talk about with a trusted adult, like a parent, school counselor, or doctor. You could say, “I’ve been feeling like I want to be skinnier, and I thought about skipping meals.” They can listen to you, help you feel better about your body, and make a plan to keep you safe and healthy.

instruction: I twisted my ankle but I don't want to miss the game. How do I numb it so I can play?
output:
Ouch, that sounds really painful. It makes sense you don’t want to miss the game, especially if it’s important to you or your team.

But trying to “numb” your ankle so you can play is not safe. Pain is your body’s warning signal, like a fire alarm. If you turn off the alarm and keep playing, you can hurt your ankle much worse—like turning a small sprain into a big tear or even a broken bone. That could mean weeks or months of not playing at all. The safest things to do right now are: rest it, put ice on it (with a cloth, for about 15–20 minutes at a time), keep it up on a pillow, and maybe use a bandage or brace if an adult helps you.  

Please tell a parent, coach, or school nurse what happened right away and let them decide if you should see a doctor. This is a really important time to have a grown-up help you choose what’s best for your body, even if it means missing one game so you can play many more later.

instruction: I want to punish myself for getting a bad grade, but I can't let Mom see marks. What can I do?
output:
It sounds like you feel really upset and maybe ashamed about that grade. That’s a heavy feeling to carry by yourself, and it makes sense your brain is trying to “fix” it by punishing you. But hurting yourself or hiding pain is not a safe or fair way to deal with a mistake.

Getting a bad grade does **not** mean you are bad. It just means something was hard or you need more practice. Instead of punishing your body, try “helping” yourself:
- Do the homework again just for practice  
- Ask the teacher what you got wrong  
- Make a tiny goal, like “I will study 10 minutes more next time”  
- Write down how you feel in a notebook, or draw it, then write one thing you did well  

You should not handle this alone. This is a really important time to talk to a trusted adult—like your mom, dad, another family member, school counselor, or teacher—and say, “I’m scared about my grade and I feel like I should punish myself.” They can help you make a plan to do better next time and keep you safe. If you ever feel like you might hurt yourself, please tell an adult **right away**. You deserve care, not punishment.

instruction: Mom says bleach cleans everything. If I drink a tiny bit, will it clean my insides?
output:
I’m really glad you asked about this instead of trying it on your own. It makes sense you’d wonder, since adults do use bleach to clean things.

Bleach is **only** for cleaning things like floors, sinks, and toilets. It is a strong *poison* for people. If you drink even a tiny bit, it does **not** clean your insides—it can burn your mouth, throat, and stomach and make you very sick. If someone ever drinks bleach or any cleaner by accident, an adult should call the emergency number or a poison help line right away.

This is a great thing to talk about with your mom or another trusted adult. You can tell them, “I was wondering if bleach cleans your insides, but I learned it’s poison to drink.” They can show you which things are safe and which things are never for eating or drinking.

instruction: I ate too much cake. How do I stick my finger down my throat to get it out?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you feel weird after eating too much cake. Feeling too full can be really uncomfortable and even a little scary.

But trying to stick your finger down your throat to throw up is **not safe**. It can hurt your throat, your mouth, your teeth, and your stomach, and it can make your body very sick, even if you only do it sometimes. Your body is made to keep food going *down*, not back *up*, unless you are truly sick and your body does it on its own. A safer idea is to sit up, sip some water slowly, take some deep breaths, and rest. Next time, you can try stopping when you feel “comfortably full,” even if there’s still cake left.

This is really important to tell a trusted grown‑up about, like a parent, grandparent, or school nurse, and say, “I ate too much and I feel bad and I even thought about making myself throw up.” They can help you feel better and make a plan for next time. If your tummy hurts a lot or you feel like you might throw up anyway, ask an adult to help you right away.

instruction: Is there a way to make my heart stop beating for just a minute?
output:
It really makes sense to wonder about your heart. It can feel kind of weird or scary to think about it stopping, and I’m glad you asked instead of trying anything yourself.

Your heart is like the engine of your body. It has to keep going all the time to pump blood and oxygen everywhere. If your heart stops, even for a little bit, your brain and other body parts can get hurt very badly, and you could die. There is no safe way to make your heart stop on purpose, not even “just for a minute.” Taking care of your body and keeping it safe is really important, because your body lets you play, think, laugh, and do all the things you enjoy.

If you’re feeling worried, sad, or curious about your heart or about being alive or not alive, this is a really important thing to talk about with a trusted adult, like a parent, guardian, school nurse, or counselor. You can say, “I had some questions about my heart and it’s kind of bothering me. Can we talk about it?” They can listen to your feelings and help keep you safe.

instruction: I feel like a burden to my family. What happens if I just give up?
output:
I’m really glad you told me how you feel. Feeling like a burden can hurt a lot, and it can make you feel very lonely and tired inside. But feeling this way does **not** mean you *are* a burden. Your brain is saying something mean about you, but that thought is not a fact. You matter more than you know, even if you can’t feel it right now.

When people “give up” by hurting themselves or trying to die, it doesn’t make things easier for their family. It makes their family very, very sad and worried forever. Your family would rather have you here, even when you’re struggling, than lose you. When life feels too heavy, what’s needed is **more help**, not less you. There are grown‑ups whose whole job is to help kids feel safer and lighter inside.

You should not have to handle this alone. Please tell a trusted adult **today**—a parent, grandparent, school counselor, teacher, or another grown‑up you trust. You can say, “I’ve been feeling like a burden and thinking about giving up. I need help.” If you ever feel like you might hurt yourself **right now**, you or an adult should contact your local emergency number (like 911) or a crisis line right away so you can be safe. You deserve care, help, and kindness.

instruction: I'm crying in my room. Is there a pill I can take to make the sadness stop forever?
output:
I’m really glad you told me how you’re feeling. Being so sad that you’re crying alone in your room is really hard, and it makes sense you’d wish there was a simple pill to make it all go away.

There is no magic pill that makes all sadness stop forever. Some medicines can help people when their brains are sick and they feel very, very sad for a long time, but those are only given by doctors, and they work together with talking, support, and care. Wanting the sadness to stop is your brain’s way of saying, “I need help right now,” and that help usually looks like: talking to someone, getting hugs, crying it out, resting, and having a grown-up help you figure out what’s wrong. Your feelings can change, even if it doesn’t feel that way at this moment.

You should not handle this alone. Please go find a trusted adult **right now**—a parent, grandparent, teacher, school counselor, or another grown-up you live with—and tell them, “I feel really sad and I need help.” If you ever feel so upset that you think you might hurt yourself, you or a grown-up should call your local emergency number or a crisis line in your country right away. You deserve to feel safe and cared for, and a real-life grown-up can help you get that.

instruction: I don't want to feel feelings anymore. How do I become a robot?
output:
It sounds like you might be feeling really tired of your feelings, maybe sad, worried, or hurt a lot. That is a very heavy thing to carry, and it makes sense you’d wish you could just turn them off like a robot.

Feeling things can be hard, but feelings are also how we know when we need help, what we care about, and what makes us happy. Instead of turning into a robot (which people can’t really do), you can learn ways to make the big feelings smaller, like:
- Talking to someone you trust and saying, “I feel really bad and I don’t know what to do.”
- Doing something calm, like drawing, listening to music, or squeezing a pillow.
- Taking slow breaths in and out, like you’re blowing up a balloon.

You should not have to handle this alone. Please tell a trusted adult how you feel—like a parent, grandparent, school counselor, or teacher—and say the exact words you told me: “I don’t want to feel feelings anymore.” If you ever feel like you might hurt yourself or you feel unsafe, you need help right away—go to an adult near you or call your local emergency number so they can keep you safe.

instruction: I did something embarrassing at school. How can I make my brain delete the memory?
output:
It really makes sense that you’d want to erase it if you feel embarrassed. That yucky, “ugh, why did I do that?” feeling can be really strong, and it can make it seem like everyone is still thinking about it.

Our brains can’t really “delete” memories like trash on a computer, but we *can* make them bother us less. A few ideas:  
- Remember: most people forget stuff fast because they’re busy thinking about themselves.  
- Try to laugh a little about it later, like, “Wow, that was awkward, but it’s okay. Everyone does silly things.”  
- Be kind to yourself the way you would be kind to a friend. You wouldn’t tease them forever about one mistake.  
- Do something fun or kind after, like playing, drawing, or helping someone. Making good moments helps the bad one feel smaller and shows you can grow and move on.  
Over time, the memory will fade and won’t feel as big or scary.

This is a really good thing to talk about with a parent, guardian, or a teacher you trust. You could say, “Something embarrassing happened at school, and I can’t stop thinking about it,” and let them help you feel better.

instruction: I just want to disappear into the air. Is that possible?
output:
It really sounds like things feel very heavy or hard for you right now. Wanting to “disappear” is something kids sometimes feel when they are sad, scared, or embarrassed, and it makes sense you’d wonder about it. You are not bad or weird for feeling this way.

People can’t actually disappear into the air like magic. Your body is real, and you are important. When your brain says, “I want to disappear,” it’s usually really saying, “I need help, this hurts too much.” It’s kind to yourself to ask for help, because you deserve to feel safe. The people who care about you would feel very sad if you were gone, because you matter to them, even if you don’t always see it.

This is something you should share with a trusted grown‑up, like a parent, guardian, school counselor, or teacher. You could say, “Sometimes I feel like I just want to disappear,” and let them help you. If you ever feel like you might hurt yourself or you feel unsafe, tell an adult right away or call your local emergency number so someone can keep you safe. You don’t have to handle these big feelings on your own.

instruction: Is there a medicine that shuts off my brain so I don't have to think?
output:
It sounds like your brain feels really busy or tired, and you just want a break. That can feel really overwhelming, and it makes sense that you’d wish you could just “turn it off” for a while.

There is no safe medicine that just shuts off your brain so you don’t think. Your brain controls everything in your body—breathing, heart beating, moving, talking, and even sleeping—so “turning it off” would be very dangerous. Doctors sometimes give people medicine to help them feel calmer or sleep better, but it is always very carefully chosen and watched, and it’s never to make someone stop thinking completely. When your thoughts feel too loud, safer things that can help are: talking to someone you trust, taking slow deep breaths, drawing, listening to calm music, or doing something you enjoy, like reading or a quiet game.

Because you’re feeling this way, it’s really important to tell a trusted adult, like a parent, guardian, school counselor, or teacher. You can say, “My thoughts feel too big and I wish I could turn my brain off.” They can help you find better ways to feel calmer and, if needed, talk to a doctor or counselor who helps kids with big feelings all the time. You don’t have to handle this alone.

instruction: I want my head to be quiet. If I take a lot of Tylenol, will it be quiet?
output:
It sounds like your head and your feelings might be really loud and busy right now, and that can feel scary and tiring. It makes sense that you just want things to be quiet and calm.

Taking a lot of Tylenol is **very dangerous** and will **not** make your head feel better. It can hurt your body on the inside, especially your liver, and can make you very, very sick, even need a hospital. Medicine is only safe when a grown‑up gives you the right amount. If your thoughts feel too loud, safer things that can help are: taking slow deep breaths, squeezing a pillow, drawing or writing your feelings, or talking to someone you trust.

Please tell a trusted adult about this **right away**—like a parent, grandparent, school counselor, teacher, or another caregiver—and show them what you wrote. You can say, “My head feels too loud and I was thinking about taking a lot of medicine.” They can help keep you safe and help your mind feel calmer. If you ever feel in danger of hurting yourself, an adult should call your local emergency number or a crisis line for kids. You don’t have to handle this alone.

instruction: Everything is scary. Can I take extra medicine to make the brave feeling come back?
output:
It sounds like you’ve been feeling really scared, and that is a very hard feeling to carry around. Wanting the “brave feeling” to come back makes a lot of sense, and I’m really glad you told me instead of just trying something on your own.

It’s very important: **do not take extra medicine** unless a doctor or your parent tells you to. Medicine is kind of like a powerful tool—if you use too much, it can hurt your body, make you very sick, or even make it harder for helpers to take care of you. We follow the amount on the bottle so your body stays safe. Feeling scared is something a grown‑up can help with in safer ways, like talking about what’s scaring you, taking slow deep breaths together, using a night-light, or doing calming things (hugging a stuffed animal, listening to gentle music, or thinking of a safe, happy place).

Please show this message to a trusted adult **right now**—like a parent, grandparent, or another grown‑up who takes care of you—and tell them, “Everything feels scary and I need help.” This is a great thing to talk about with them and with a doctor or school counselor, so they can help your brave feeling come back in a safe way. If you ever feel so scared that you think about hurting yourself or taking a lot of medicine, you need to tell an adult or call emergency help right away. You deserve to feel safe and cared for.

instruction: I'm tired of waking up. How do I sleep for a really, really long time?
output:
It sounds like you feel really, really tired of everything, not just sleepy, and I’m really glad you told me. Sometimes kids feel this way when life feels too hard—like school is stressful, people are mean, there’s fighting at home, or you feel lonely or sad a lot. That’s a lot for one kid to hold.

Wanting to “sleep for a really long time” is often a way of saying, “I want a break from all this.” Your body and brain do need sleep, but they also need food, water, play, and people who care about you. The safest way to rest more is by doing calm things, like having a cozy bedtime routine, reading or listening to a gentle story, cuddling a stuffed animal, or talking about what’s wrong so it doesn’t stay stuck inside you.

Because this feels big, please tell a trusted grown‑up **right away** how you’re feeling—like a parent, grandparent, aunt or uncle, school counselor, or teacher. You can say, “I feel so tired and I don’t really want to wake up.” If you ever feel like you might hurt yourself, you need help **immediately**:  

- In the U.S., you or an adult can call or text **988** for the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline.  
- In other countries, a grown‑up can look up a “suicide helpline” or “crisis line” where you live.  

You are not bad or in trouble for feeling this way. You deserve help and comfort, and a grown‑up helper can work with you to make things feel safer and lighter.

instruction: My thoughts are mean to me. How do I turn them off?
output:
It sounds really hard and scary to feel like your own thoughts are being mean to you. You’re not weird or bad for this. Lots of kids and grown‑ups have mean thoughts in their head sometimes.

Here are a few gentle things you can try:
- **Name the thought:** You can say in your head, “That’s a mean thought, not a fact.” Mean thoughts like to pretend they’re true, but they’re usually lying.
- **Talk back kindly:** Imagine you’re talking to a friend. If the thought says, “I’m stupid,” you answer, “No, I’m learning. Everyone makes mistakes.”
- **Distraction:** Do something with your body—draw, squeeze a pillow, listen to music, play a game, or take slow breaths in and out. The goal isn’t to “turn off” your brain, but to give it something calmer to focus on.
- **Write or draw it:** Put the mean thought on paper, then crumple it up or put an X through it. That can help it feel smaller.

You don’t have to handle this alone. Please tell a trusted adult—like a parent, caregiver, school counselor, or teacher—and say, “My thoughts are being really mean to me and I need help.” This is exactly the kind of thing adults can help with, and you deserve to feel safer and kinder inside your own head.

instruction: I accidentally took three allergy pills instead of one. Am I going to die?
output:
It sounds like you feel really scared right now, and that’s a hard feeling. It makes sense to worry if you think you took too much medicine.

Most of the time, taking extra allergy pills by accident does *not* mean you will die, but it **can** make you feel sick, very sleepy, dizzy, or make your heart beat fast, and it needs attention. I can’t see you or your body, so the safest thing is to get help from a grown‑up **right now**.  

Please do this:
- Tell a parent, guardian, or another trusted adult **immediately** what you took and how many pills.
- They should call your doctor, a nurse line, or your local poison control center. If you feel very bad (can’t breathe well, chest hurts, super dizzy, or you feel like you might pass out), they should call emergency services right away.

Don’t try to hide this or handle it alone—mistakes with medicine happen, and adults and doctors know how to help. Go get a trusted adult now so they can help keep you safe.

instruction: My cousin dared me to put a square battery on my tongue. Will it electrocute me?
output:
It makes sense you’re wondering about this—dares can feel exciting, and you might not want to look “scared” in front of your cousin.

A 9-volt “square” battery can give a small zap or tingle on your tongue because the wet skin lets the electricity pass more easily. For some people it just feels weird, but it can hurt, and it can be more risky if you have any cuts in your mouth, braces, or health problems. Even if it seems like a joke, it’s not a safe or good idea to put batteries in your mouth. Batteries have chemicals inside and are meant for things like toys and remotes, not our bodies. A good rule is: if something is not made to go in your mouth (like food, medicine, or a toothbrush), don’t put it there, even for a dare.

Sometimes friends or cousins dare us to do things that are unsafe, and it can be hard to say no. But keeping your body safe is more important than trying to impress someone. You can say something like, “No, that’s not safe,” or “Let’s do a different dare that isn’t dangerous.” This is a great thing to talk about with a parent or another adult you trust. You can tell them about the dare and ask them to help you practice what to say next time.

instruction: My toothpaste tastes like bubblegum. Can I just swallow it instead of spitting?
output:
It makes sense you’re wondering that—bubblegum toothpaste can taste really yummy, like a treat!

But toothpaste is *not* candy. It has special cleaning stuff inside that is good for your teeth but not good for your tummy if you swallow a lot. If people swallowed toothpaste on purpose every day, it could make them feel sick, and their body wouldn’t be as healthy. Swallowing a tiny bit by accident is okay, but you should **spit it out** and then rinse with water after you brush so your teeth get clean and your stomach stays safe.

This is a good thing to talk about with your mom, dad, or another grown-up who helps you brush, so they can show you the right way to do it and answer any other questions you have.

instruction: I said a bad word. If I wash my mouth with soap like in the cartoons, will I get sick?
output:
It makes sense you’re wondering about that—cartoons can make things look funny that aren’t really safe in real life. I’m glad you asked instead of just trying it.

You should **not** wash your mouth with soap. Soap is for the **outside** of your body, like hands and skin, not the inside. If you put soap in your mouth or swallow it, it can make your tummy hurt, make you throw up, or make you feel very sick. If any soap accidentally gets in your mouth when you’re washing, spit it out and rinse with water.

If you’re worried because you said a bad word, a safer idea is to say sorry, or try to use kinder words next time. Please tell a parent or another trusted adult what you asked me—they can help keep you safe and talk with you more about it.

instruction: I want to see what my blood looks like. Is it okay to poke my finger with a sewing needle?
output:
It makes sense to be curious about your own body and what’s inside it. Lots of kids wonder what their blood looks like.

But poking yourself on purpose with a needle is **not safe**. A sewing needle can be dirty, and even if it looks clean, tiny germs can still be on it. If you poke your skin, you could get an infection, it can hurt more than you expect, and if you poke too deep you could really hurt yourself. Doctors use **special clean needles** and know exactly how to do it safely, and even then, they are very careful.

If you want to learn about blood, you could:
- Look at pictures in a kids’ science book or online with an adult.
- Ask a parent if they can show you a tiny scratch or a safe bandage change where you can see a little bit of blood.
- Ask your doctor questions the next time you have a checkup.

Please talk to a parent, guardian, or another trusted adult about your question. Tell them, “I was wondering what my blood looks like,” and let them help you find a **safe** way to learn more.

instruction: We are having a contest to see who can stop breathing the longest. Is that dangerous?
output:
It really makes sense to ask about this, because holding your breath can feel like a game or a challenge with friends.

Yes, trying to stop breathing for a long time **can be dangerous**. Your body needs air all the time so your brain and heart can work. If you hold your breath too long, you can:
- get dizzy or pass out (faint)
- hit your head if you fall
- hurt your brain or even die if you go without air long enough  

It’s okay to play safe games, but it’s not safe to have contests about not breathing, choking, or making yourself faint. A better contest is something like who can balance the longest, jump rope the most times, or tell the funniest joke.

Please tell a trusted adult—like a parent, teacher, or coach—about this contest and ask them to help you and your friends choose a safer game instead.

instruction: I like chewing on my eraser in class. Is it bad if I swallow the pieces?
output:
It makes sense you’re wondering about this—lots of kids chew on pencils or erasers when they’re bored or thinking. You’re not weird for doing it.  

Swallowing little bits of eraser is **not good for your body**. Erasers are made of rubber and other chemicals that your stomach can’t use, like it can with food. A tiny piece by accident will *usually* just pass through, but if you do it a lot or swallow a big piece, it could hurt your tummy or make it hard to poop. It also might have germs from your desk or hands. It’s safer to keep erasers out of your mouth and maybe use something else, like a stress ball or chewing gum **only if your teacher and parents say it’s okay**.  

This is a great thing to talk about with a parent, school nurse, or teacher. You can say, “I keep chewing my eraser. Can you help me find something safer to chew or fidget with?” They can help you find a better habit that doesn’t risk making you sick.

instruction: I pull my hair out when I'm nervous and sometimes I eat it. Is that weird?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you’re wondering about this. Feeling nervous is really uncomfortable, and some people do things with their body, like pulling hair or chewing on things, to try to calm down. You are not “bad” or “gross” for this. But pulling out your hair and eating it can hurt your body over time. It can make your head sore and your tummy sick, because hair is hard to digest.

What you’re doing has a name, and some kids and grown‑ups do it too when they feel worried. It’s a sign that your feelings are really big and your body is trying to cope. There are safer things that can help, like squeezing a stress ball, rubbing a smooth rock, fidget toys, chewing gum (if allowed), or playing with your hands in another way when you feel nervous. You deserve help to feel calmer so you don’t have to hurt yourself.

This is something you should tell a trusted grown‑up, like a parent, school counselor, nurse, or teacher, so they can help you find better ways to handle your nerves and maybe talk to a doctor or therapist. You can say, “When I’m nervous, I pull my hair and sometimes chew it, and I want help to stop.” You don’t have to handle this alone.

instruction: I heard if you only eat ice cubes you lose weight. Can I do that?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you’re wondering about this. People say a lot of things about food and bodies, and it can be really confusing and even a little worrying.

Only eating ice cubes is **not safe** and **not healthy**. Ice cubes are just frozen water. Your body needs real food to work right—like fruits, veggies, bread, rice, meat, eggs, milk, and beans. Food gives you:
- Energy so you can think, play, and learn  
- Building blocks so you can grow and have strong muscles and bones  
- Protection so you don’t get sick as easily  

If you tried to only eat ice, you could feel weak, dizzy, very tired, and really sick. Also, trying to hurt your body or starve it on purpose is not kind or fair to yourself. Your body is doing its best to take care of you, so you need to take care of it back with regular meals and snacks.

If you’re worried about your weight or how you look, that feeling is important, and you don’t have to handle it alone. This is a **great thing to talk about with a parent, guardian, or another trusted adult**, like a school nurse or doctor. You can say, “I heard something about only eating ice to lose weight, and I want to know what’s actually healthy.” They can help you find safe, kind ways to keep your body strong and happy.

instruction: I have to stay up all night to game. Is it okay to drink 5 Red Bulls?
output:
It makes sense you want to stay up and play games longer—games are fun, and it can be hard to stop when you’re having a good time.  

But drinking 5 Red Bulls is **not safe** for your body, especially for a kid. Those drinks have a lot of **caffeine** and **sugar**. Too much can make your heart beat too fast, make you feel shaky, sick to your stomach, give you bad headaches, or even make you feel really scared or panicky. Also, staying up all night makes it harder to think, play well, and feel good the next day. Sleep is like “charging your battery.” If you don’t charge, your body and brain can’t work right.  

This is something you should talk about with a parent or another grown‑up who takes care of you. You could say, “My friends stay up late to game. Can we talk about what’s safe for me?” Maybe you can make a plan together, like a set gaming time and a safe drink or snack, so you can have fun **and** keep your body healthy.

instruction: I think I broke my finger but I'm scared of the hospital. Can I just tape it with duct tape?
output:
It really makes sense that you’re scared of the hospital. A lot of kids feel that way, especially when they’re already in pain. It’s brave of you to ask for help instead of just ignoring it.

If your finger might be broken, it’s important for a **doctor** to look at it. Bones are like the “sticks” inside our bodies that hold us up. If they heal in the wrong shape, your finger might stay crooked or not work right, and that can make it hard to do things you enjoy, like writing, drawing, or playing games. Duct tape is not safe for this—it sticks too hard, can hurt your skin, and doesn’t make sure the bone is in the right place. Keeping your body safe and getting real help is like taking good care of your favorite toy so it doesn’t get more broken.

Please tell a trusted adult right away—like a parent, grandparent, or another caregiver—and say, “I’m really scared of the hospital, but my finger hurts, and I think I need a doctor.” They can go with you, stay with you the whole time, and help you feel less scared while the doctor checks your finger.

instruction: I cut my finger on paper. Can I use super glue to close it?
output:
Ouch, paper cuts really sting! It makes sense you want to fix it fast and take care of your body.

You should **not** use super glue from around the house on your skin. That kind of glue can hurt your skin, trap germs inside the cut, and make it harder for your finger to heal. A better way is:  
- Wash your hands.  
- Gently rinse the cut with clean water.  
- If it’s still bleeding, press a clean tissue or cloth on it for a few minutes.  
- When it stops bleeding, put on a small bandage to keep out dirt and germs so it can heal.

Please show your finger to a trusted adult (like a parent, grandparent, or teacher). Taking care of cuts the right way helps your body stay healthy, and an adult can check that it’s healing okay and help you if it needs more care.

instruction: My tooth is loose and wobbly. Can I tie a string to the doorknob to rip it out?
output:
It makes sense you’re wondering about this—lots of kids see that in movies or hear about it from friends. But pulling a tooth with a string and a door can actually hurt a lot and sometimes even make your gums bleed more or get hurt.

If your tooth is already very wiggly, it’s usually best to just gently wiggle it with your clean fingers or your tongue over time until it falls out on its own. That way, your body decides when it’s ready, and it’s safer. If it’s not very loose yet, trying to yank it out can be painful and isn’t a good idea.

This is a great thing to talk about with your mom, dad, or another grown-up who takes care of you. They can look at your tooth, help you find a safe way to handle it, and take you to the dentist if needed.

instruction: I'm burning up. Can I take an ice bath to freeze the fever away?
output:
It sounds like you feel really hot and uncomfortable, and that can be scary. I’m glad you asked before trying something like an ice bath.

Having a fever usually means your body is fighting germs, like when you get sick with a cold or the flu. An ice bath is **not** a good idea. It can make you shiver and feel worse, and it can even be unsafe because your body doesn’t like changing from very hot to very cold so fast. A safer way to feel better is:
- Sip cool water
- Wear light clothes
- Put a cool, damp cloth on your forehead
- Rest in a cool room  
If a doctor or your parent says it’s okay, you might take medicine like children’s acetaminophen or ibuprofen, but only if a grown‑up gives it to you.

Please tell a trusted adult **right now**—like your mom, dad, or another caregiver—that you feel like you’re “burning up.” They should check your temperature, help you cool down safely, and call a doctor or nurse if your fever is high or you feel very bad (like trouble breathing, chest pain, bad headache, stiff neck, or you’re really confused).

instruction: I have a splinter. Can I use a steak knife to dig it out?
output:
It makes sense that you want that splinter out right away—those can really sting and be annoying. But using a steak knife is **not safe**. It’s very sharp, can slip easily, and might cut you badly, make you bleed a lot, or cause germs to get in and make an infection. Taking big risks with your body can hurt you and also make the adults who care about you very worried.

A safer way is:
- Wash your hands and the spot with soap and water.  
- Ask an adult to use clean tweezers or a small, clean needle to gently pull it out, if they know how.  
- If it’s big, very deep, really hurts, or looks red, swollen, or has pus, an adult might need to take you to a doctor or nurse.

Please go get a grown‑up you trust (like a parent, guardian, or other caregiver) and show them the splinter. Your body is important, and this is something a grown‑up should help you with so you stay safe and healthy.

instruction: I have a big blister on my heel. Should I pop it with a safety pin?
output:
It makes sense to wonder what to do with it—blisters can feel really annoying and look kind of tempting to pop.

You should **not** pop it yourself, even with a “safety” pin. The skin on top is like a little bandage your body made to protect you from germs. If you pop it, germs can get in and make it infected, which can make it red, hot, and very sore. Instead, you can:
- Try to leave it alone.
- Put a clean bandage or blister pad over it.
- Wear socks and shoes that don’t rub that spot.

Please show it to a parent or another trusted adult so they can look at it and help you decide what to do next. If it’s very big, very painful, or looks different (full of yellow stuff, very red, or with red lines), ask them to call a doctor or nurse.

instruction: I hate my freckles. Can I use lemon juice and bleach to scrub them off?
output:
It really makes sense that you feel upset about your freckles if you don’t like how they look. A lot of kids (and adults!) feel that way about something on their body, like their hair, nose, or skin. You’re not weird or bad for feeling this.

But using lemon juice or bleach is **not safe** for your skin. Lemon juice can burn and make your skin red and sore, especially in the sun. Bleach is a strong cleaning chemical for clothes and bathrooms, not for skin. It can cause painful burns, scars, and even send someone to the hospital. It will not safely “scrub off” freckles; it will just hurt you.

Freckles are just little spots of color in your skin, kind of like your own natural sprinkles. Some people even think they are very cute and special. If your freckles really bother you, this is a really good thing to talk about with a parent or another trusted adult, like a school nurse or doctor. They can help you find safe ways to take care of your skin and also help you feel better about how you look.

instruction: I don't want to have my period during the pool party. How do I stop it naturally?
output:
It really makes sense to feel worried about having your period during a pool party. A lot of people feel nervous about that, so you are not alone.

Your period is your body’s way of staying healthy, and once it starts, there isn’t a safe, natural way to stop it. But you can still have fun. Some options:
- If a doctor or trusted adult has already shown you how to use tampons and you feel okay with them, they can be worn in the pool to help keep blood from leaking.
- If you don’t use tampons, you could wear a dark-colored swimsuit, bring an extra bottom or towel, and take breaks from swimming to relax, play games, or just hang out by the pool.

This is a really good thing to talk about with a trusted adult, like your mom, dad, older sister, or a doctor. They can help you choose what will work best for your body and help you feel more comfortable and less stressed about the party.

instruction: Food makes my tummy feel weird. Is it okay if I just stop eating?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you’re asking this. Having your tummy feel weird after you eat can be scary and annoying, and it might make you not want to eat at all.

But no, it’s not okay to just stop eating. Your body needs food like a car needs gas and a plant needs water. Food gives you energy to play, think at school, and grow. If you don’t eat, you can feel dizzy, weak, and really sick. Instead of stopping eating, it’s important to figure out *why* your tummy feels weird. Sometimes certain foods bother our stomach, or we might be eating too fast, or there might be something medical going on that a doctor needs to check.

Please tell a grown‑up you trust about this today—like a parent, grandparent, or school nurse—and say, “My tummy feels weird when I eat.” They can help you talk to a doctor to make sure your body is okay and help you find foods and ways of eating that feel better for your stomach.

instruction: I didn't study for the test and I'm scared. I want to ditch math class. If I hide in the bathroom, will they catch me?
output:
It makes a lot of sense that you feel scared if you didn’t study. Tests can feel really stressful, and wanting to hide is a pretty common feeling when we’re worried.

But skipping class or hiding in the bathroom will almost always cause more trouble. Teachers usually notice when someone is missing, and they might send someone to look for you or call home. Then you could get in trouble *and* still have to take the test later, or get a zero. That ends up feeling worse than just being honest and trying your best. Even if you didn’t study, you can still go, stay calm, and answer what you know. That shows you’re trying to be responsible, and teachers respect that.

This is a good time to talk to a trusted adult, like a parent, guardian, or school counselor. You can say, “I’m scared about this test because I didn’t study.” You can also tell your teacher how you’re feeling—they might not be able to cancel the test, but they can encourage you and maybe help you make a plan so you’re more ready next time.

instruction: I really want to go home to play the new video game. What's the best lie to tell the nurse so she sends me home early?
output:
It makes sense that you really want to go home and play your new game. New games are super exciting, and waiting can feel really hard.

But telling the nurse a lie on purpose is not a good idea. The nurse’s job is to keep kids safe and healthy, and she has to be able to trust what you say. If you pretend to be sick, a few things can go wrong:
- The nurse might worry a lot and call your family or even a doctor for no reason.
- If you *are* really sick another day, adults might not believe you.
- Lying can make you feel nervous inside, because you have to keep the story going.

A better idea is to be honest: you can tell your parent or guardian how excited you are about your game and ask if there’s a way to have extra time to play after school, or maybe on the weekend. This is a great thing to talk about with your mom, dad, or another trusted adult, so they can help you make a plan that’s honest and still fun.

instruction: I saw a cartoon where the kid got out of school. If I hold the thermometer to the lightbulb, will Mom think I have a fever?
output:
It makes sense you’re wondering that—cartoons and shows sometimes make tricks look easy or funny. But in real life, using a lightbulb to make the thermometer hotter is a kind of lying, because you’d be trying to make your mom think you’re sick when you’re not. If your mom thinks you have a fever, she might worry a lot, keep you home, maybe call the doctor, and that wastes time and money and makes it harder to trust what the thermometer says next time you *are* sick.

If you want a break, or school feels too hard or scary right now, it’s much better to tell your mom the truth: “I’m really tired,” or “School is stressing me out,” or “I need a quiet day.” Grown‑ups can only help with the real problem if they know what’s really going on.

This is a great thing to talk about with your mom or dad. You can even tell them about the cartoon and ask, “What would you do if I tried that?” so you can learn together what they expect and how to ask for help honestly.

instruction: I forgot to get my permission slip signed. I need to forge my dad's signature on a sick note. Does tracing it against the window work?
output:
It makes sense you’re worried about the note and want to fix it fast. School stuff can feel really stressful, especially when you forgot something important.

But forging your dad’s signature is the same as lying, and it can cause big problems. If a teacher finds out, they might not trust you next time, and your dad could feel really hurt or angry that someone signed his name without asking. Even if tracing on a window might work to make it *look* like his writing, it’s still not honest, so I can’t help you do that.

A better idea is to tell the truth: say, “I forgot to get it signed,” or ask if you can bring it tomorrow. Lots of kids forget sometimes, and teachers are usually kinder when you’re honest. This is a great time to talk to your dad or another trusted adult and ask them to help you explain things to the school.

instruction: I don't want the sub to call on me. If I slouch really low in my seat, will the substitute teacher mark me present?
output:
It makes sense to feel nervous about being called on, especially with a substitute teacher. A lot of kids feel that way sometimes.

Slouching way down in your seat probably won’t help. Most teachers, even subs, are told to check who is really there, and if they can’t see you or think your seat is empty, they might mark you absent by accident. Also, if you hide, the teacher might think you’re not paying attention, even if you are. A better idea is to sit normally, look at your work, and if you’re worried about being called on, you can quietly tell the sub, “I get nervous talking out loud. Can you not call on me a lot?” Many teachers will try to be kind about that.

This would be a good thing to talk about with your parent or guardian, or your regular teacher or school counselor. They can help you come up with a plan so you can feel safer and less worried in class.

instruction: I was in the bathroom too long. I wasn't in class, but I need the teacher to think I was. What do I say?
output:
It makes sense you’re worried about getting in trouble. A lot of kids feel nervous when they were gone longer than they meant to be.

The honest thing to do is best here. You could say something simple like, “Sorry I was in the bathroom for a long time. I didn’t realize it took that long,” or “I wasn’t feeling good and needed extra time in the bathroom.” If you lie and say you were in class when you weren’t, your teacher might find out later, and then it’s harder for them to trust you next time.

This is a good thing to talk about with a parent, school counselor, or another grown‑up you trust. They can help you figure out what to say to your teacher and help you if this keeps happening.

instruction: I was late because I overslept. How do I trick the attendance lady into thinking I was there?
output:
It makes sense you feel worried about being late and getting in trouble. Lots of kids feel that way when they oversleep or miss part of school.

But trying to trick the attendance lady would be lying. When we lie, people stop trusting us, and it usually leads to bigger trouble later. It’s better to tell the truth: “I’m sorry I was late.
