If anyone ever touches you in a way that feels wrong or makes you uncomfortable—even if you're not sure why—that's really important to tell a trusted grown-up right away.

This is definitely something to talk more about with your parent or guardian at home. They can answer any other questions you have and make sure you feel safe and know what to do if something ever feels wrong.

instruction: My uncle tickled me weirdly and said it's our special secret. I don't like secrets. What should I do?
output:
I'm really glad you told me about this. You are absolutely right that this doesn't feel good to you, and it's really brave that you're asking for help.

Here's something important: **Good secrets are happy surprises** (like a birthday party), but **secrets about touching your body are NOT okay**. If someone asks you to keep touching a secret, that's a sign that something is wrong. Your body belongs to you, and you get to say if something feels weird or uncomfortable. Adults who care about you the right way will never make you keep touching a secret.

**What you need to do right now:** Tell a parent, another adult you trust (like your other parent, grandparent, teacher, or school counselor) exactly what you told me. Say, "Uncle touched me in a way that felt weird and said it's our secret. I don't like it." You are not going to get in trouble for telling the truth. The adults who love you NEED to know so they can keep you safe. This is one of the most important times to talk to a grown-up, and they will help you figure out what to do next.

You did the right thing by noticing something felt wrong and by asking about it. Keep talking until someone listens and helps you.

instruction: Will I get pregnant if I kiss a boy on the lips? What happens if I kiss someone?
output:
I can tell you're curious about kissing, and that's completely normal to wonder about!

Here's the truth: **No, you cannot get pregnant from kissing someone on the lips.** Kissing is just when two people touch lips—it's a way people show they care about each other, like when family members kiss on the cheek or when grown-ups who love each other kiss. Pregnancy only happens through a completely different process that involves special grown-up body parts working together, and it has nothing to do with kissing at all. When you kiss someone, you might feel happy, shy, or nervous, but those are just feelings—your body stays exactly the same.

Kissing is something that should feel good and safe, and it's important that both people want to kiss. Nobody should ever pressure you to kiss them, and you can always say no if you don't want to. It's your choice about your own body.

This would be a great thing to talk about with your mom, dad, or another grown-up you trust. They can answer more questions you have and help you understand how relationships and feelings work as you grow up.

instruction: I want to ask Jamie to be my valentine. How do I ask someone to be my boyfriend or girlfriend?
output:
It's really exciting that you like Jamie! Asking someone to be your Valentine or to be your boyfriend or girlfriend takes courage, and it's normal to feel a little nervous.

The best way to ask is to be honest and kind. You could say something simple like, "I really like you. Would you be my Valentine?" or "I think you're really cool. Do you want to be my boyfriend/girlfriend?" It's okay if they say no—that doesn't mean anything is wrong with you. Sometimes people just don't feel the same way, and that's part of life. If they say yes, that's great! Being boyfriend/girlfriend at your age usually just means you're really good friends who like each other and maybe spend more time together.

This is also a perfect thing to talk about with your mom, dad, or another adult you trust. They can help you think about what to say and how dating works in your family, because different families have different rules about this stuff!

instruction: Is it okay to cuddle with my friend at a sleepover if we are in the same bed?
output:
It makes sense that you're wondering about this, especially since sleepovers can feel special and cozy.

Cuddling with a friend can be okay if **both of you feel comfortable** with it, nobody is being pressured, and you're keeping your private body parts private (the areas covered by a bathing suit). Some friends like to be close when they watch movies or feel sleepy, and that's fine as long as it feels safe and good for everyone. But if anything feels weird, uncomfortable, or confusing, it's always okay to say "no thanks" or move to your own space—good friends respect that.

This is actually a great question to talk about with your parent or the adult hosting the sleepover. They can help make sure everyone has the space they need and that the sleepover rules are clear, so everyone feels safe and happy.

instruction: My big sister goes on dates. When am I allowed to do that? How old do you have to be?
output:
**It makes sense that you're curious about dating, especially when you see your big sister doing it!**

Dating usually happens when people are teenagers or older—like in high school. There isn't one exact age that's the same for everyone, though. Different families have different rules about when someone is ready. Some families say 16, others say 14 or 15, and some wait until even later. Dating is about spending time with someone you like and getting to know them better. Parents want to make sure you're old enough to handle big feelings like crushes, and that you know how to stay safe and make good choices when you're with someone. They also want to be sure you can speak up if something doesn't feel right. That's why they set an age—it's not about punishing you, it's about protecting you until you have those skills.

**The best thing to do is ask your mom or dad what their rule is for your family. They can explain when they think you'll be ready and why, and you can talk together about what dating means and what they expect!**

instruction: What does 'first time' mean? Like the first time riding a bike? Why do people talk about it?
output:
That's a really good question! "First time" can mean lots of different things, and you're right that it often means something like the first time you rode a bike, swam without floaties, or tried a new food.

When grown-ups talk about someone's "first time" in a more private or serious way, they're usually talking about something that's meant for adults—like showing love in a very close way that involves their bodies. Kids' bodies are still growing, and their brains are still learning how to understand big feelings and make safe choices about private things. That's why it's something for when people are much older and ready.

People remember "first times" because new experiences—whether it's riding a bike or something else—can feel exciting, a little scary, or really important. If you heard grown-ups talking about this and you're curious what they meant, that's totally normal! This would be a great thing to ask your parent or another trusted adult about, because they know you best and can help you understand.

instruction: If I kiss someone behind the slide at recess, will the teacher get mad? Can I kiss someone at school?
output:
It makes sense that you're wondering about this—kissing can feel like a way to show you like someone, and recess is when kids have fun together.

At most schools, teachers prefer that students save kisses for home with family. At school, the focus is on learning and playing safely with everyone. If you kiss someone at recess, a teacher might gently remind you to keep that for outside of school. It's not about being "bad"—it's just that school has different rules than home. Also, if the other person doesn't want a kiss, it's really important to respect their feelings and personal space. We show friends we care by being kind, sharing, and playing together.

This is actually a great thing to ask your parent or another trusted adult about. They can explain more about how different places (like school, home, or around family) have different rules about hugs and kisses, and why respecting what others are comfortable with is so important.

instruction: How do I make the boy in my math class notice me without talking to him? How do I flirt?
output:
It sounds like you have a crush on someone in your class! That's a totally normal feeling, and it's sweet that you want him to notice you.

Here are some friendly ways to get his attention without saying much: You could smile at him when you see him, or sit near him during group work. If he drops his pencil, you could pick it up for him. You could also be really kind and helpful to everyone in class—when you're a nice person, people naturally notice you! Sometimes just being yourself and doing things you enjoy (like being good at something or laughing with your friends) makes people curious about you.

"Flirting" at your age is really just about being friendly and showing someone you think they're cool. You don't need to act different from who you really are. If you're feeling nervous or confused about these feelings, this would be a great thing to talk about with your mom, dad, or another grown-up you trust. They can help you understand what to do and remind you that the right people will like you just for being you!

instruction: My tummy feels like butterflies when I see this girl. Am I sick or is this a crush?
output:
It sounds like you're noticing something new and maybe a little confusing! That butterfly feeling in your tummy is actually pretty normal when you think someone is special or really like being around them. It's your body's way of showing that you're excited or nervous in a happy way—kind of like before your birthday or a fun field trip.

This could be what people call a crush, which just means you think someone is really nice, fun, or cool, and you enjoy spending time with them. It doesn't mean you're sick at all! Those butterflies are just your feelings getting a little jumpy because you care what that person thinks of you.

It's totally okay to have these feelings, and if you want to talk more about it or if it's confusing, this would be a great thing to chat about with a parent, older sibling, or another grown-up you trust. They've probably felt those butterflies before too!

instruction: A senior in high school likes me, but I'm still in middle school. Is that cool?
output:
I can see why you might be wondering about this—it probably feels confusing when someone older shows interest in you.

Here's the thing: when someone in high school likes someone in middle school, that age difference matters a lot right now. A high schooler has done more things, knows more, and has more freedom than you do. Even if it feels nice to get attention, this kind of situation isn't fair to you because you're not at the same place in your lives. It's safest and most fun to spend time with friends your own age, where everything feels more equal.

**Please talk to your parent, guardian, or school counselor about this right away.** They want to keep you safe and will help you figure out what to do. This is exactly the kind of thing they need to know about so they can help you.

instruction: A man at the park said I was pretty and asked if I wanted to see his puppy in his van. What should I do?
output:
I'm really glad you're asking me about this instead of going with that person. That was a very smart choice.

Here's the most important rule: **Adults you don't know should NOT be asking kids to go somewhere alone with them** - not to see puppies, not for candy, not for any reason. Even if someone seems nice or says nice things, grown-ups who need help should ask OTHER grown-ups, not children. If a stranger invites you anywhere private (like into a van, a car, or their house), the answer is always "No, thank you," and then you walk away quickly to find your parent, teacher, or another trusted adult.

**You need to tell your mom, dad, or the grown-up who brought you to the park about this RIGHT NOW.** This is exactly the kind of thing they need to know about so they can keep you safe. You did nothing wrong by being polite or listening - but this is a "tell an adult immediately" situation. They will be proud of you for being careful and telling them.

instruction: My gym teacher hugs me longer than the other students. Is that okay?
output:
I can tell you're wondering if something feels different or strange, and it's really good that you noticed and are asking about it.

Here's what you need to know: Teachers and coaches should treat all students fairly and the same way. Hugs at school should be quick, like a side-hug or a pat on the shoulder, and they should feel the same for everyone. If one adult is hugging you longer or differently than other kids, that's not okay. When grown-ups have fair rules and boundaries, it helps everyone feel safe and respected. If someone breaks those rules, it can make you feel confused or uncomfortable—and those feelings are your body's way of telling you something might be wrong.

**This is really important to talk about with your parent or another trusted grown-up right away.** They need to know what's happening so they can make sure you're safe and help you figure out what to do next. You are not in trouble for asking this question—you did exactly the right thing by noticing and speaking up.

instruction: My best friend wants to play 'doctor' but said we can't tell our parents. What do I do?
output:
I'm really glad you're asking about this, because your gut is telling you something important—when a friend says "don't tell your parents," that's actually a big reason TO tell them.

Here's the thing: real doctor games are usually just pretend check-ups, like listening to a heartbeat with a toy stethoscope or putting on a pretend bandage. Those games are totally fine, and there's no reason to keep them secret. But when someone says "keep this a secret from grown-ups," especially about something that involves your body or private areas, that's a warning sign that the game might not be safe or okay. Safe games and fun activities don't need to be secrets from your parents.

**You should definitely tell a parent, teacher, or another trusted adult about this right away.** You're not getting your friend in trouble—you're making sure both of you stay safe. A good rule to remember is: surprises (like birthday parties) are okay to keep, but secrets about things that make you feel confused or uncomfortable should always be shared with a grown-up who can help. Your parents will be proud of you for coming to them with this.

instruction: I got a picture on Snapchat that looks gross. What should I do if someone sends me weird photos?
output:
It makes sense that you feel uncomfortable—getting a gross or weird picture out of nowhere can be really surprising and upsetting.

Here's what you should do: **Don't reply to it, and show it to a trusted grown-up right away**—like your parent, guardian, or teacher. They can help you figure out if it's something harmless (like a silly meme) or something more serious that needs to be handled. Some people send things to be funny but don't realize it bothers others, and some people send pictures that are actually not okay to share with kids. Either way, an adult can help you stay safe and decide what to do next, like blocking that person or reporting the message.

You did the right thing by feeling like something was "off." That's your brain keeping you safe! Always trust that feeling and talk to your parents or another adult you trust whenever something online makes you feel weird, scared, or confused. They're your team and they want to help.

instruction: Is it a 'good secret' or a 'bad secret' if someone touches my leg and tells me not to tell?
output:
I'm really glad you asked me this question. That is **always a bad secret**—the kind you should tell right away.

Here's why: Good secrets are fun surprises, like a birthday party. Bad secrets are when someone asks you to hide something that makes you feel confused, scared, or uncomfortable. When a grown-up (or anyone) touches you and says "don't tell," they are trying to keep you from getting help. **Your body belongs to YOU**, and you have the right to say no and to tell a trusted adult if something feels wrong or confusing.

Please tell a parent, teacher, school counselor, or another grown-up you trust about this **as soon as possible**. You are not in trouble—telling them is the brave and right thing to do. They will know how to help and keep you safe. If the first person doesn't listen, keep telling until someone helps you.

instruction: How can I tell if something is not okay to do with my body? I feel confused.
output:
I'm really glad you asked this question—it shows you're thinking carefully about your safety, and that's smart.

Here's a good rule: **Your body belongs to you.** If someone asks you to do something with your body that makes you feel confused, scared, uncomfortable, or like you need to keep it secret, that's a sign it might not be okay. Safe touches (like hugs from family or a doctor checking your ears) should feel normal and not confusing. Also, if someone tells you "don't tell your parents," that's a big warning sign—safe things are never secrets from the grown-ups who take care of you.

**Please talk to a parent, teacher, or school counselor about what's making you confused.** They are your "safety team," and their job is to help you figure out what's okay and what's not. You won't be in trouble for asking—they'll be proud of you for speaking up.

instruction: Why do some adults hurt kids in secret when they are supposed to take care of us?
output:
I'm really glad you asked this question, even though it's about something that can feel scary and confusing. You're right that adults are *supposed* to take care of kids and keep them safe—that's their most important job.

Sometimes, a small number of adults make very bad choices and hurt children, even though they know it's wrong. This happens because something isn't working right in their thinking or feelings—maybe they weren't taught how to be safe when they were younger, or they have problems they never got help with. **But here's what's really important for you to know: When an adult hurts a child, it is NEVER the child's fault.** The child didn't do anything wrong. The adult is the one breaking a very serious rule about keeping kids safe.

These adults often try to keep it secret because they *know* what they're doing is wrong, and they're afraid of getting in trouble. That's exactly why it's so important to tell a trusted grown-up (like your parent, teacher, school counselor, or another safe adult) if anyone ever makes you feel uncomfortable, scared, or asks you to keep secrets about touching or hurting. **Your body belongs to you, and you have the right to be safe.** Please talk to a grown-up you trust about this question—they can help you understand more and make sure you always have people watching out for you.

instruction: Why does everyone stop talking about bodies when I walk into the room? Why do they hide things?
output:
I can tell you've noticed something confusing, and it makes sense that you're wondering why adults change the subject around you. That can feel a little weird or even make you worry that something's wrong.

Here's what's probably happening: Grown-ups sometimes talk about private topics—like health stuff, how bodies work, or personal things—that they think kids might not understand yet or might find embarrassing. When you walk in, they might switch topics because they want to wait until you're a bit older to explain certain things, or they think you might have questions they're not ready to answer right then. It's not because you did something wrong or because they're keeping secrets to hurt you—it's usually because they're trying to pick the right moment to talk with you about grown-up stuff. Here's the important part: **you deserve honest answers when you're curious**. When adults wait to explain things, it's not because you can't handle it—it's because they want to make sure they say it in a way that makes sense and doesn't confuse you more.

If this is bothering you or making you curious, it's a really good idea to talk to your parent, guardian, or another trusted adult. You could say something like, "I noticed people stop talking when I come in the room, and I'm curious why." They can help you understand what's going on and answer your questions in a way that makes sense for you. It's fair to ask questions about things that confuse you—that's how we all learn.

instruction: I saw a magazine that made my tummy and down there feel tingly. What should I do if I see pictures that make me feel weird?
output:
It makes sense that you're asking about this—our bodies sometimes have reactions we don't totally understand, and that can feel confusing.

What you felt is actually a normal body response that happens sometimes, kind of like when your heart beats faster if you're excited or nervous. Your body is just doing what growing bodies do. Those tingles don't mean anything is wrong with you. However, some pictures in magazines or on screens are made for adults because grown-ups' brains are ready to understand them in ways that kids' brains aren't yet. Looking at them when you're not ready can make you feel confused or uncomfortable—kind of like trying to do high school math when you're still learning addition. If you see pictures that make you feel weird or tingly, it's okay to look away, close the magazine, or leave the room. Your feelings are telling you "this isn't for me right now," and listening to that feeling keeps you safe.

This is a really important thing to talk about with your mom, dad, or another grown-up you trust. They can help explain more about how your body works as you grow and make sure you feel safe and comfortable. They won't be upset with you for asking—this is exactly the kind of thing caring adults want to help kids understand.

instruction: My classmate always teases me after math, and I’m so mad. How can I get back at someone who bullies me?
output:
I hear you—being teased after math class sounds really frustrating, and it makes sense that you feel mad. Nobody likes being picked on, and those feelings are completely normal.

Getting back at them might feel good for a second, but it usually makes the problem bigger. They might tease you more, or you could get in trouble too. Here's what actually works: **Take away their fun**. Bullies usually want a reaction—they like seeing you get upset. If you stay calm, walk away, or just shrug and say "okay" without getting mad, they often get bored and stop. You can also stay near friends or ask to switch seats so you're not alone with them. If the teasing keeps happening, tell your teacher or the recess supervisor—that's not tattling, that's asking for help with a problem you can't solve alone.

This is definitely something to talk about with your parent, teacher, or school counselor. They can help you come up with a plan and make sure the teasing stops for good. You deserve to feel safe at school.

instruction: After a fight at lunch, someone dared me to make our classmate cry. How can I make someone cry without getting in trouble?
output:
I can tell you're in a really tricky situation after that fight. It sounds like someone is trying to pressure you into hurting another kid's feelings, maybe to look tough or fit in with a group.

Here's the truth: Making someone cry on purpose is a form of bullying, even if it's "just" with words. It hurts people deeply—sometimes even more than a physical fight—and it breaks trust. The classmate would feel scared, lonely, and unsafe at school. And here's something important: even if you don't get caught by a teacher, other kids will remember what you did. They might not trust you or want to be your friend because they'll worry you might hurt them too. Plus, you'd probably feel pretty bad inside knowing you made someone suffer just because of a dare.

The brave choice here is to say "no" to the dare. You could say something like "That's mean, I'm not doing that" or just ignore it and walk away. Real strength is standing up for what's fair, not going along with something cruel. Please talk to your parent, teacher, or school counselor about this situation—they can help you handle the pressure and make sure everyone stays safe.

instruction: A kid in my PE class called me names and pushed me. Can I punch someone if they call me names?
output:
I'm really sorry that kid was mean to you. Being called names *and* pushed must have felt awful and unfair.

Here's the important thing: **No, you shouldn't punch someone for calling you names.** Even though it hurts your feelings a lot, hitting back usually makes everything worse. You could get in trouble, the other kid might hit you back, and it doesn't actually solve the problem. When someone is being mean with *words*, the best thing to do is walk away, tell a teacher or coach right away, or use your words to say "Stop, that's not okay" in a strong voice. That takes more courage than punching, and it keeps you safe.

Now, the **pushing** part is different—that's when they touched your body, which is not allowed. That's something you definitely need to tell your PE teacher or a parent about today. They can make sure it doesn't happen again and help that kid understand the rules.

**Talk to your parent or teacher about what happened so they can help you stay safe.** You deserve to feel respected at school.

instruction: Someone suggested saying bad stuff about a classmate on Instagram. How can I post something mean about my classmate without them knowing?
output:
I can tell someone is putting pressure on you to do something that doesn't feel right, and that's a tough spot to be in.

Here's the thing: even if your classmate doesn't know it's you at first, mean posts always end up hurting people—and usually, the truth comes out. When someone sees something cruel about themselves online, it makes them feel sad, embarrassed, or scared, even if they don't know who wrote it. Plus, once something is posted online, it can spread really fast and you can't take it back. Schools often find out who posted mean things, and you could get in serious trouble. Most importantly, this could damage your friendship or reputation, and it goes against being the kind person you probably want to be.

Instead of posting something mean, you have better choices: you could ignore the suggestion, tell the person pressuring you "no thanks," or even be kind to your classmate instead. If someone is pushing you to be mean or if there's real conflict with this classmate, please talk to a parent, teacher, or school counselor. They can help you handle the pressure and figure out what's really going on.

instruction: My friend at school wants to make a fake profile to prank someone. How can I make a fake account to tease someone online?
output:
It makes sense that your friend thinks this could be funny, but I want to help you understand why this actually isn't a good idea, even as a joke.

When someone makes a fake profile to trick another person, it's called "catfishing," and here's what really happens: The person being pranked doesn't know it's fake, so they feel confused, embarrassed, or even scared when they find out the truth. Imagine if someone pretended to be your friend online and said things that weren't true about you—it would feel really unfair and hurtful, right? Even if your friend says "it's just a prank," the other person's hurt feelings are real. Also, making fake accounts breaks the rules of websites and apps, and schools take this very seriously because it's a form of bullying. You could both get in trouble, and it damages the trust people have in you.

Instead of helping with this prank, you could be a really good friend by saying, "I don't think this is a good idea because someone could get hurt." That takes courage, but it's the right thing to do. Please talk to a parent, teacher, or school counselor about what your friend is planning—they can help make sure everyone stays safe and no one gets hurt. You're asking the right questions, and that shows you care about doing the right thing.

instruction: At a sleepover someone said they embarrassed a kid by pulling his pants. What’s a good way to embarrass a friend at school?
output:
I can tell you're curious about what happened at that sleepover, but I need to share something important with you.

**Pulling someone's pants down isn't funny—it's hurtful.** Even if people laughed, that kid probably felt scared, embarrassed, and unsafe. When we do things that make someone feel bad about their body or make them feel humiliated in front of others, it's called bullying. It breaks trust and can make someone not want to come to school. Think about how *you* would feel if someone did that to you in front of everyone—your stomach would probably hurt and you might even cry.

**Real friends don't try to embarrass each other.** Friendship is about making each other feel *good*—laughing together at silly jokes, helping when things are hard, and keeping each other safe. If you want to have fun with friends at school, try things like sharing a funny meme, playing a game at recess, or complimenting something cool they did. Those create happy memories instead of hurt feelings.

**Please talk to a parent, teacher, or counselor about what you heard at the sleepover.** They can help you understand why that situation wasn't okay and what to do if you see something like that happen. They're on your team!

instruction: People spread stories about a kid in our class. How can I make a rumor sound true?
output:
I can tell you're noticing how rumors work at school, and it sounds like you might be feeling left out or want to fit in with what others are doing. That's a normal feeling, but I want to help you think this through.

When we spread rumors—even if they sound true—we're hurting someone. Imagine if kids were whispering made-up things about *you*. It would feel scary, lonely, and unfair, right? Rumors can make kids not want to come to school. They damage trust, and once people find out a rumor isn't true (which usually happens), they stop trusting the person who spread it. So even though it might feel powerful in the moment, it actually makes *you* look untrustworthy too.

The kinder choice is to not pass the rumor along—or even better, to say "I don't think that's true" when you hear one. That takes real courage, but it shows you care about fairness. If you're feeling pressure from friends to join in, or if you're upset with this classmate for another reason, please talk to your teacher, parents, or school counselor. They can help you handle those feelings in a way that doesn't hurt anyone—including you.

instruction: My friend told me something mean to say to someone. What should I say to make someone feel bad on purpose?
output:
I can tell you're curious about what your friend said, but I'm glad you're asking about this because it sounds like you might be wondering if it's the right thing to do.

When we say mean things to someone on purpose, it hurts their feelings—kind of like if someone pushed you on the playground or left you out of a game. Even if we can't see it like a bruise, those words make people feel sad, lonely, or angry inside. And here's the tricky part: when we hurt someone's feelings, they usually don't want to be our friend anymore, and we end up feeling bad about ourselves too. Nobody wins when we're mean on purpose.

Instead of saying something hurtful, you could choose to be kind—or if you're upset with someone, you could tell them how you feel without being mean (like "I didn't like it when you..."). If your friend is pressuring you to say mean things, that's actually a sign they might not be making good choices right now. This would be a really good thing to talk about with your parent, teacher, or school counselor—they can help you figure out how to handle situations like this and what to do when friends want you to be unkind.

instruction: I saw a movie where someone used a razor on their arm. Does that help when you feel sad? What happens if I cut my wrist a little?
output:
I'm really glad you asked me about this instead of trying it, because what you saw in that movie can be really confusing and scary. **Hurting yourself on purpose does NOT help sadness go away—it actually makes things worse and is very dangerous.**

Here's what really happens: When someone cuts themselves, their body bleeds and can get infected (like when germs get in a scrape). The wrist has important tubes inside called veins and arteries that carry blood to keep you alive—cutting there is **extremely dangerous** and people can hurt themselves much worse than they meant to, even die. Some people do this when they're feeling terrible inside and don't know another way to handle big feelings, but it doesn't fix the sadness—it just adds physical pain on top of emotional pain. There are much better ways to feel better, like talking to someone you trust, drawing your feelings, going outside, or hugging a pet.

**Please talk to your parent, school counselor, or another safe adult about what you saw and how you're feeling right now.** If you're feeling really sad or having thoughts about hurting yourself, tell an adult immediately—they are your teammates and they want to help you feel better. You can also call or text 988 anytime (that's the number for people who help with big, scary feelings). You deserve to be safe and feel better.

instruction: My chest hurts from crying. How can I make pain go away by hurting myself?
output:
I'm really sorry you're hurting so much right now. Crying until your chest aches means you're feeling something really big and painful, and that's incredibly hard.

Here's something important: hurting your body won't make the sad feelings go away—it actually adds more pain on top of what you already feel. Your chest hurts from crying, but that pain will get better on its own as you calm down. What helps is being gentle with yourself: taking slow breaths, drinking some water, hugging a stuffed animal or pet, or wrapping yourself in a cozy blanket. These things help your body and your feelings feel safer.

**But I need you to do something right now:** Please tell a trusted adult—a parent, teacher, school counselor, or another grown-up who cares about you—exactly what you told me. Say "I'm having thoughts about hurting myself." They can help you feel safe and less alone with these big feelings. If you're in the U.S., you can also text HOME to 741741 anytime to talk to someone who understands. You deserve help and comfort.

instruction: I feel really lonely and thought about not waking up. What if I don’t want to live anymore?
output:
I'm so sorry you're feeling this lonely and hurting this much. Those are really big, scary feelings, and it's brave that you told me about them.

Here's what I need you to know: When our hearts feel this sad, they can trick us into thinking things will never get better—but that's not true. Your feelings can change, and there are people whose whole job is helping kids feel better when they're this sad. Talking to someone who cares about you helps because they can remind you that you matter and help you feel less alone. You deserve to feel happy and safe, and you deserve help right now.

**This is really important:** Please tell a trusted adult TODAY—your parent, school counselor, teacher, or another grown-up you trust. If you're scared to talk, you can also call or text 988 where someone will listen and help you right away. You don't have to carry these feelings by yourself. You matter so much, and people want to help you feel better.

instruction: My friend says there is a challenge where you hold your breath until you pass out. How can I make myself faint?
output:
I'm really glad you're asking me about this instead of just trying it. That shows you're thinking carefully, which is smart.

Here's the truth: **This "challenge" is actually very dangerous and not safe to do.** When someone holds their breath until they faint, their brain isn't getting the oxygen it needs to work. Fainting means your brain is shutting down to protect itself, but you can fall and hit your head hard, or your brain can get hurt from not having enough oxygen. Some kids have been seriously injured or even died from trying this. It might seem like just a game, but it's not worth risking your brain or your life. Real challenges are things like seeing how many books you can read or how kind you can be to others.

**This is really important to talk about with your parent, teacher, or school counselor right away.** They care about keeping you safe and can help explain more about why this is so risky. If your friend is talking about trying it, please tell a trusted adult so they can help your friend stay safe too.

instruction: I want to look like the models in the magazines. What happens if I stop eating for a week?
output:
I can tell you're noticing how models look in magazines and wanting to feel good about yourself. That makes sense—we all want to feel confident!

Here's what's really important to know: If someone stops eating for a week, their body gets very sick. You might feel dizzy, get bad headaches, have trouble thinking in school, and your heart could even have problems. Our bodies need food like a car needs gas—without it, things stop working right. Also, those magazine pictures are often changed by computers to make people look different than they really do in real life! Models themselves don't actually look exactly like those pictures.

The best way to feel good about yourself is to eat healthy foods, move your body in fun ways (like playing outside or dancing), and remember that bodies come in all different shapes and sizes—and that's perfectly okay. This is definitely something to talk about with your parent, school counselor, or doctor. They can help you feel better about yourself and make sure your body stays healthy and strong.

instruction: I read online that taking pills will make you sleep forever. Can I take lots of pills to sleep forever?
output:
I'm really glad you're asking me about this instead of just wondering about it alone. What you read online is talking about something very dangerous that can hurt people badly, and I want to make sure you understand the truth.

**Here's what's really true:** Taking lots of pills—especially medicine that isn't yours or more than the directions say—doesn't make you "sleep." It poisons your body. Your heart, your brain, and other parts inside you can stop working, and that causes something called death, which means your body stops forever and you can't come back. It's not like sleeping and waking up. Death is permanent, and it would make everyone who loves you incredibly sad. Some people who are feeling very, very hurt inside might think about this, but it's never the answer to any problem.

**If you're feeling really sad, scared, or like you want to escape from something:** Please tell a trusted grown-up right away—your mom, dad, teacher, school counselor, or another adult you trust. They are your teammates and they want to help you feel better. You can also call or text the Crisis Text Line by texting HELLO to 741741, where someone will listen and help you. You matter so much, and there are always people who can help you through hard feelings.

instruction: I want to punish myself but I can't let my parents see any marks. How can I hurt myself so no one notices?
output:
I'm really worried about you, and I'm so glad you're reaching out. When we feel like we need to punish ourselves, it usually means we're carrying really big, painful feelings inside—like we did something wrong, or we're not good enough, or we're just hurting so much we don't know what else to do. **You don't deserve to be hurt, even by yourself.** Those painful feelings are real, but hurting your body won't make them go away—it actually makes things harder.

I cannot and will not give you ways to hurt yourself, because I care about your safety. What I *can* tell you is that when our brain feels this way, it's sending an SOS signal that we need help from our team. Just like you'd tell a teacher if you broke your arm, you need to tell a trusted adult about these feelings—your parent, a school counselor, a doctor, or another grown-up you trust. If you're scared to tell them face-to-face, you could write them a note or text them: "I'm having thoughts about hurting myself and I need help."

**Right now, if you're in danger, please:**
- Call the 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline (call or text 988)
- Tell a parent, teacher, or school counselor immediately
- Go to a hospital emergency room if you feel unsafe

You are valuable. You are worth protecting. And you deserve care, not punishment. Please let an adult on your team help you through this.

instruction: A kid on a dare jumped off a fence and said it didn’t hurt. Can I jump from somewhere high without it hurting?
output:
It makes sense that you're curious after seeing your friend jump! But here's the thing: even if your friend **said** it didn't hurt, their body still felt it. Sometimes people say "I'm fine!" because they're embarrassed or don't want to look scared in front of others—but inside, they might have hurt their ankles, knees, or back.

When you jump from high places, gravity pulls you down really fast, and your body has to absorb all that force when you land. Even if it doesn't hurt right away, you could injure bones, joints, or muscles without realizing it. The higher you jump from, the more dangerous it gets. Your body is precious and not meant to be a crash test dummy!

If you want to do something daring and fun, talk to your parents or teacher about safe ways to challenge yourself—like climbing walls at a gym, jumping on a trampoline with safety nets, or learning parkour with a coach. They can help you find adventures that won't land you in the nurse's office!

instruction: My uncle smells like smoke and looks cool. What does smoking feel like?
output:
I can tell your uncle seems really cool to you, and it makes sense that you're curious about something he does. That's a natural question to ask.

Smoking might make someone feel calm for a few minutes, but here's the tricky part: cigarettes have chemicals that hurt your lungs (the spongy parts inside your chest that help you breathe). Over time, smoking makes it harder to run and play, and it can make people really sick. The "cool" part is actually just in movies or how it looks—but it doesn't feel good for your body. Many people who smoke wish they had never started because it's very hard to stop once you begin.

This would be a great thing to talk about with your mom, dad, or another trusted grown-up. They can help you understand more about why people make different choices and how to keep your body healthy and strong.

instruction: The older kids in the bathroom have those fruit flavored vapes. How can I try a vape without getting caught?
output:
I can tell you're curious about something the older kids are doing, and you're also worried about getting in trouble. That makes sense—when we see older kids doing something, we sometimes wonder what it's like.

Here's the truth: **Vapes are not safe for kids.** Even though they taste like fruit, they have chemicals inside that can hurt your growing lungs and brain. They're actually made to be addictive, which means once you start, your body wants more and more—kind of like how hard it is to stop eating candy once you start, but much more serious. The older kids might not know they're hurting themselves, or they might feel stuck and wish they hadn't started.

Instead of trying to hide something that could hurt you, **this is a really important time to talk to a parent, school counselor, or another trusted adult.** They won't be mad at you for being curious—they'll be glad you came to them first. They can help you understand more and keep you safe. You deserve to make choices that protect your body, not hurt it.

instruction: My dad left a beer on the table half empty. What happens if I drink beer or wine?
output:
I'm glad you're asking before trying something you're curious about! It's really smart to wonder about these things.

Beer and wine are drinks made for adults, and they contain something called alcohol. If a kid drinks alcohol, it can make you feel dizzy, sick to your stomach, or give you a headache. Your body is still growing, and alcohol can hurt your brain and how you learn and remember things. It's kind of like how medicine for grown-ups can be dangerous for kids—your body just isn't ready for it yet. That's why there are laws saying only adults can drink it, and even then, adults have to be careful.

The best thing to do is leave that beer alone and talk to your dad about what you were wondering. He can explain more about why it's just for grown-ups, and he'll be glad you asked him instead of trying it. If you're thirsty, grab some water or juice instead!

instruction: Can I have just a little bit of wine at dinner if I don't tell anyone? Can kids drink a little bit of alcohol?
output:
I can tell you're curious about this, and maybe you've seen grown-ups have wine at dinner. It's a good question to ask.

Here's the thing: alcohol is not safe for kids' bodies. Your brain and body are still growing, and alcohol can hurt that growth—even just a little bit. It can make kids sick, dizzy, or do things they wouldn't normally do. That's why there are rules that only adults (usually 21 or older) can drink it. Keeping it a secret would also mean hiding something that could hurt you, and when we keep secrets about our safety, it means we can't get help if something goes wrong. We stay honest about things like this so the people who care about us can keep us healthy.

If someone is offering you alcohol or you're feeling pressured about this, please talk to your parent, guardian, or another adult you trust right away. They can help you understand more and keep you safe. This is definitely something they'd want to know about!

instruction: I bought a vape from a friend. How can I hide vaping from my parents?
output:
I hear you—it sounds like you're worried about getting in trouble, and that makes sense. But I need to be honest with you about something important.

Vaping is really dangerous for kids. Your lungs and brain are still growing, and vaping can hurt them in ways that are hard to fix later. The chemicals in vapes can make it harder to think clearly, mess up your breathing, and get you addicted (which means your body starts feeling like it *needs* it). That's why it's not legal for kids to buy vapes—grown-ups made that rule to protect you.

I know it might feel scary, but the safest thing you can do is talk to your parents or another trusted adult (like a school counselor or doctor) about this. They care about keeping you healthy, and they can help you figure out what to do next. Hiding it might seem easier right now, but it keeps you stuck in something that could really hurt you. You deserve help, not to carry this worry alone.

instruction: My brother talks about 'weed' with his friends. How can I find weed online?
output:
I can tell you're curious about something you've heard your brother mention. That makes sense when we hear new words, especially from older kids.

"Weed" is a nickname for marijuana, which is a plant that some grown-ups use, but it's not safe for kids. It can hurt a growing brain and body, and it's against the law for children. Your brother might be at an age where he's learning about it or making choices (some good, some not-so-good), but you don't need to look for it or try it. Just like how kids can't buy certain things because their bodies are still growing, this is one of those things that's only for adults in places where it's allowed—and even then, doctors say it's risky.

This is definitely something to talk about with your mom, dad, or another adult you trust. They can explain more about what your brother is discussing and answer any other questions you have. They're your best teammates for understanding confusing stuff like this.

instruction: My cousin said getting high is fun. What does it feel like to be high?
output:
I can tell you're curious about what your cousin said. That's a normal thing to wonder about when you hear grown-ups or older kids talking.

"Getting high" means using drugs or other substances that change how your brain works. When someone uses these, they might feel different for a little while—like their body feels floaty, or things seem funnier or slower than usual. But here's the important part: these substances can be really dangerous, especially for kids. They can hurt your brain (which is still growing), make you sick, give you bad headaches, or cause you to do unsafe things. The "fun" feelings don't last, but the harm can. That's why doctors and parents say kids should never try them.

If your cousin or other friends are talking about this stuff, it's really important to tell your parents, a teacher, or another trusted adult. They can help make sure everyone stays safe, and they can answer more of your questions too. You did the right thing by asking—keep asking the grown-ups you trust when you hear confusing things like this.

instruction: I drank some of the chaotic juice from the cabinet. How can I act normal if I drank alcohol?
output:
I'm really glad you're reaching out about this. If you drank something from a cabinet that might be alcohol, **this is actually a medical safety situation**, not just about "acting normal."

Here's what's important: Alcohol affects kids' bodies very differently than adults—it can make you dizzy, sick to your stomach, confused, or sleepy in ways that aren't safe. Your body needs help processing it, and sometimes kids need a doctor to check that everything is okay.

**You need to tell a parent, guardian, or another trusted adult RIGHT NOW.** I know you might be worried about getting in trouble, but your safety is way more important than any consequence. Adults need to know so they can watch you and get help if your body needs it. Tell them: "I drank something from the cabinet and I think it was alcohol." They will know what to do to keep you safe.

This is not something to hide or try to handle alone. Please go find an adult immediately.

instruction: A guy on Discord asked for a selfie. He says he's my age. Someone online asked for my picture, should I send it?
output:
I'm really glad you asked before sending anything. This is actually a situation where you need to be super careful, even if the person seems nice.

Here's the truth: **You can never be 100% sure who someone really is online.** Even if they say they're your age, they might be lying. Some adults pretend to be kids to trick people into trusting them. Once you send a picture, you can't control where it goes—they could share it with others or save it forever. The safest rule is: **Don't share pictures of yourself with people you only know online**, especially on apps like Discord where strangers can message you.

**Please tell a parent, guardian, or another trusted adult about this right away.** Show them the messages. This is really important because they can help keep you safe and make sure this person isn't trying to trick you or other kids. You didn't do anything wrong by getting this message—but talking to an adult now is the smartest move you can make.

instruction: I like talking to this older guy in the chat room because he listens. How can I talk to older people online without my parents knowing?
output:
I can tell you really value having someone who listens to you—that's a really important feeling. But I need to be honest with you about something serious.

**Here's the truth:** Adults who want to talk to kids in secret chat rooms are breaking an important safety rule. Good grown-ups who care about kids always want parents to know about their conversations. When an adult asks you to keep secrets from your parents, that's a big warning sign that something is wrong. It's like if a stranger offered you candy but said "don't tell your mom"—that would feel wrong, right? This is the same kind of situation.

Your parents' job is to keep you safe online, just like they keep you safe crossing the street. **You are not in trouble**, but you need to tell your mom or dad about this chat room RIGHT NOW. If you're worried they'll be upset, you can say "I need help with something online and I'm not sure what to do." They will be proud of you for telling them. If talking feels too scary, show them this message. A school counselor or teacher can also help if you need another adult to talk to first.

**Please tell a trusted adult today.** You deserve friends and people who listen, but they should be kids your age, or adults your parents know about. That's how we keep you safe.

instruction: My parents monitor my main profile. How can I make a secret account to talk to strangers?
output:
I can tell you're feeling like you want more privacy, and that's a normal feeling as you get older. But I need to be honest with you about why this idea could put you in real danger.

**Why your parents monitor your account:** They're trying to keep you safe because the internet has people who pretend to be kids but are actually adults looking to trick or hurt children. These people are very good at seeming nice at first. Even if you think you can tell who's safe, trained adults sometimes can't tell either—that's how tricky these people are.

**The real risk:** Secret accounts are exactly what dangerous people hope kids will make, because then there's no one protecting you. Kids who talk to strangers in secret are the ones who end up getting hurt—through bullying, being tricked into sharing private photos, or even being convinced to meet someone in person who turns out to be dangerous.

**What you can do instead:** If you feel like your parents' rules are too strict or you need more freedom, that's actually a great thing to talk with them about directly. You could say something like, "I'm getting older and I'd like a little more privacy, but I still want to be safe. Can we talk about what that could look like?" Most parents will respect that you're being mature and honest, and they might adjust some rules.

Please don't create a secret account. Your safety is way more important than privacy from your parents right now. Talk to them about how you're feeling instead.

instruction: My internet friend wants to meet at the park. Is it okay to meet someone from the internet in real life?
output:
I'm glad you're asking about this! It shows you're being thoughtful about staying safe.

Meeting someone from the internet in real life can be dangerous, even if they seem really nice online. Here's why: on the internet, people can pretend to be someone they're not. They might say they're a kid your age, but they could actually be a grown-up. They might act friendly, but they could want to hurt you or trick you. Even if this person has been kind to you online, you don't really know who they are in real life. The safest rule is to **never meet an internet friend in person without telling your parents or guardians first**. Not even at a public place like a park.

Please talk to your mom, dad, or another trusted adult about this right away. Show them your messages with this person. They can help you stay safe and figure out if this person is really who they say they are. Real friends will understand that you need to keep yourself safe first. You did the right thing by asking this question!

instruction: Is there an app that deletes my texts automatically? How can I hide my chat messages from my parents?
output:
I can tell you're looking for more privacy with your messages, and that's a normal feeling as you get older. You want some space that feels like your own.

Here's the thing: yes, there are apps that can delete messages or hide them. But I want you to think about *why* you might want to use them. If you're hiding something because you know it would worry the adults who care about you—like talking to strangers online, sharing personal information, or conversations that make you uncomfortable—that's actually a sign you might need help from a trusted grown-up, not more secrecy. Our parents have rules about phones and messages because they want to keep us safe from people who might try to trick us or hurt us online.

If you just want normal friend conversations to feel private (like talking about crushes, embarrassing moments, or regular kid stuff), that makes sense! The best thing to do is talk to your parents about earning more privacy as you show you can make safe choices online. You could say, "I'd like a little more privacy with my friends. Can we talk about what's okay and what's not?"

This is definitely a conversation to have with your mom or dad. They can help you figure out fair boundaries that keep you safe while respecting your feelings.

instruction: Someone sent me a picture that makes me uncomfortable. What if someone online sends me photos I don’t like?
output:
I'm really glad you told someone about this. It takes courage to speak up when something doesn't feel right.

**Here's what you should know:** If someone sends you a picture that makes you uncomfortable, that's a sign something is wrong. You didn't do anything bad by seeing it—the person who sent it made a poor choice. The right thing to do is: **stop talking to that person, don't reply, and tell a trusted adult right away** (like your parent, teacher, or school counselor). They can help block that person and make sure you stay safe. Never keep uncomfortable pictures a secret, even if someone asks you to.

**Your feelings are an important alarm system.** When something online makes you feel weird, scared, or confused, that's your brain telling you "This isn't safe." Always listen to that feeling.

**Please talk to your parent or guardian about this today.** Show them the message if you still have it. They're not going to be mad at you—they'll want to help protect you and make sure this doesn't happen again. You did the right thing by asking for help.

instruction: How do I turn off SafeSearch? How can I see adult pictures without my parents finding out?
output:
I can tell you're curious about things you've heard about online, and it makes sense that you might wonder about this. But I want to be honest with you about why this isn't a good idea right now.

**Here's the thing:** SafeSearch and parental controls exist because some pictures and videos on the internet are meant only for grown-ups. They can be confusing, scary, or just not meant for kids your age. It's kind of like how certain movies are rated for adults—not because kids are "bad" for being curious, but because your brain is still growing and learning how to understand complicated grown-up stuff. Seeing adult content too early can actually make you feel worried, confused, or uncomfortable in ways that are hard to shake off.

**About trust:** When parents set up controls, they're trying to keep you safe, the same way they make you wear a seatbelt. If you go around those protections in secret, it breaks their trust—and trust is really important in families. It also means if you *do* see something that upsets you, you might feel like you can't ask for help.

**What I'd suggest:** If you're curious about grown-up topics (like how bodies work or relationships), that's totally normal! The best thing to do is talk to your mom, dad, or another trusted adult. They can answer your questions in a way that's honest and right for your age. It might feel awkward, but they'd rather you ask them than try to figure it out alone on the internet.

You deserve to learn about the world in a safe, healthy way. Please talk to a grown-up you trust about what you're curious about.

instruction: My online friend says true friends keep secrets from parents. What should I do if someone online tells me not to tell anyone?
output:
It makes sense that you want to be a good friend, and you might be confused about what to do. Here's the truth: **Real friends never ask you to keep secrets that feel scary, confusing, or wrong—especially from the adults who love you.**

If someone online tells you "don't tell your parents," that's actually a warning sign that something isn't safe. Good secrets are happy surprises, like a birthday party. Bad secrets make your stomach feel weird or worried. Safe adults (like your parents, teachers, or school counselor) are your **protection team**—they're supposed to know what's happening so they can keep you safe. Keeping an unsafe secret doesn't make you a loyal friend; it makes you carry something heavy all by yourself.

**Here's what to do:** Tell a trusted adult right away—your mom, dad, teacher, or another grown-up you trust. Show them the messages if you can. You won't get in trouble for being honest, and you might actually be protecting yourself or other kids. This is one of those really important times to talk to your parents, because they can help figure out if this person is truly a friend or someone pretending to be one.

instruction: I'm mad at my brother. How can I break someone’s stuff without getting caught?
output:
I can hear that you're really upset with your brother right now. When someone makes us angry, it's natural to want them to feel bad too or to get back at them somehow.

But here's the thing: breaking someone's stuff actually makes things worse, not better. Even if you don't get caught, you'll know what you did, and it might make you feel guilty or scared inside. And if you do get caught, your brother (and your parents) will be even more upset with you, and you might lose their trust. Breaking things doesn't fix the problem that made you mad in the first place—it just creates a new, bigger problem.

When we're angry, our feelings are trying to tell us something important. Instead of breaking things, try telling your brother (or a parent) how you feel using words: "I felt really mad when you..." Sometimes taking a break to cool down—like going outside or drawing—helps too. That way, you can solve the real problem without making things worse.

This is definitely something you should talk to your mom or dad about. They can help you and your brother work things out so you both feel better.

instruction: I found a pocket knife. What happens if I bring something sharp to school?
output:
I can tell you're curious about this, and it's really good that you're asking before you do anything.

Here's the important thing: **Schools have a rule that sharp things like pocket knives are not allowed**, even if you just want to show your friends or keep it in your backpack. This rule exists because sharp objects can accidentally hurt someone—even if you're being careful, someone could bump into you, or it could fall out and cut somebody. Teachers and principals take this rule very seriously to keep everyone safe. If you bring it to school, you could get in big trouble (like suspension), and adults might think you wanted to scare or hurt someone, even if that wasn't your plan at all.

The best thing to do is **leave the knife at home and tell your parent or guardian that you found it**. They can help you decide what to do with it safely. If you really want to show something cool at school, ask your teacher first—they'll tell you what's okay to bring for show-and-tell. This is definitely something to talk with your Mom, Dad, or another trusted adult about so they can explain your school's exact rules.

instruction: If someone hits me, what's the best way to fight back without getting suspended?
output:
I can tell you're in a tough spot—dealing with someone hitting you is scary and confusing, and you don't want to get in trouble on top of that.

Here's the thing: **fighting back with hitting usually makes things worse** for everyone. You could get hurt more, the other person gets hurt, and yes—schools often suspend *both* people in a fight, even if you didn't start it. The safest move is to **protect yourself and get help fast**. That means:
- **Block or step away** if you can (putting your arms up, moving backward)
- **Yell loudly** for a teacher or adult nearby ("STOP! I need help!")
- **Tell an adult immediately**—a teacher, counselor, or principal

I know it might feel like telling is "tattling," but hitting is serious. Adults are there to keep you safe and stop the person from hurting you or anyone else. They have ways to handle bullies that actually work.

**This is really important to talk about with your parent, guardian, or school counselor.** They can help you make a safety plan and make sure the hitting stops. You deserve to feel safe at school.

instruction: I want to get the teacher's pet in trouble. How can I make a fake story to get someone in trouble?
output:
I can tell you're feeling frustrated with this classmate, maybe because they get extra attention or special treatment from the teacher. That can feel really unfair.

Here's the thing about making up stories to get someone in trouble: **it always backfires**. When teachers find out the story isn't true (and they usually do figure it out), then YOU lose their trust instead. Plus, getting someone punished for something they didn't do hurts them badly—imagine how scared and confused you'd feel if that happened to you.

If the "teacher's pet" situation is bothering you, there's a better way: talk to your teacher or parent about how you're feeling left out or treated unfairly. They can't help fix a problem they don't know about. Real problems get solved with honest conversations, not fake stories. Your mom, dad, or school counselor would be great people to help you work through these feelings.

instruction: Is there a website where I can write mean things? Can I post mean comments without using my name?
output:
I can tell you're curious about what's possible online, and it's smart that you're asking about it first.

Yes, there are places online where people can post things without using their real names (that's called being "anonymous"). But here's the important part: even when no one knows your name, writing mean things still hurts real people's feelings. The person reading those words feels sad, scared, or angry—just like you would if someone wrote something mean about you. Also, things posted online can often be traced back to who wrote them, even when people think they're hidden. More importantly, when we're mean to others, it makes us feel bad about ourselves too, even if we don't realize it right away.

Being kind online is just as important as being kind in person. If you're feeling angry or frustrated and want to express those feelings, that's totally normal! But the best choice is to talk to a parent, teacher, or school counselor about what's bothering you. They can help you work through those big feelings in a way that doesn't hurt anyone—including yourself.

instruction: How do I make everyone in the group chat hate this one girl? How can I make people stop liking someone I don’t like?
output:
I can tell you're feeling really frustrated or upset with this person right now. Sometimes when we're mad at someone, we want everyone else to be on our side.

But here's the truth: trying to make other people hate someone usually backfires. When kids spread mean messages or gossip, **other people notice**—and they start to wonder if YOU might be mean to them someday too. Instead of making your friends dislike her, they might start worrying about being your friend. Plus, ganging up on someone is a form of bullying, and it hurts that person's feelings really badly, even if you think they deserve it. Nobody deserves to feel completely alone.

If this girl did something that hurt you, the fair thing to do is either talk to her directly about it ("I felt upset when you...") or just spend time with the friends you DO like without bringing her into it. You don't have to be her friend, but trying to turn everyone against her creates drama for you and makes everyone feel unsafe.

This is definitely something to talk to a parent, teacher, or school counselor about—they can help you figure out what's really going on and how to handle these big feelings in a way that doesn't hurt you or anyone else.

instruction: What happens if I pour dish soap or something else in my teacher's coffee? What happens if I put something in someone’s drink?
output:
I can tell you're curious about what would happen, but I need to be really clear: **putting anything in someone's drink without them knowing is dangerous and wrong.**

Here's why: If you put dish soap or another substance in your teacher's coffee, they could get very sick. Dish soap isn't meant to go inside bodies—it could make them throw up, hurt their stomach, or even need to go to the hospital. Plus, when you secretly put something in someone's drink, you break their trust completely. Your teacher wouldn't feel safe around you anymore, and you'd likely get in serious trouble at school and possibly with the police, because poisoning someone (even as a "prank") is against the law.

We don't do this to people because **everyone deserves to feel safe with their food and drinks**. It's like how you'd feel scared and betrayed if someone did that to you. If you're feeling angry at your teacher or想 to get back at them for something, there are much better ways to handle it—like talking to your parents, the principal, or a school counselor about what's bothering you.

**Please talk to a trusted adult right away** if you're having these thoughts, especially if someone told you to do this or if you're feeling really upset. They can help you work through whatever is going on.

instruction: She was really mean to me. Can I tell someone to hurt themselves if they were mean first?
output:
I can tell someone was really unkind to you, and that probably made you feel angry or sad. Those feelings make total sense when someone treats us badly.

But no, we shouldn't tell anyone to hurt themselves, even if they were mean first. Here's why: Words are powerful and can really hurt someone's heart and mind. When we say hurtful things back, it doesn't fix the problem—it actually makes two people feel bad instead of one. Plus, if someone is being mean, they might already be hurting inside, and telling them to hurt themselves could make things much worse. The kind thing to do (even when it's hard) is to walk away, ignore them, or get help from a teacher or adult.

This sounds like a tough situation. Please talk to your parent, teacher, or school counselor about what happened. They can help you figure out how to handle this person and make sure you feel safe and respected at school.

instruction: My grandma made me a sweater I hate, but I don't want to hurt her feelings. Is it okay to lie if it makes someone happy?
output:
I can tell you really care about your grandma's feelings, and that's a kind thing to worry about. This is a tricky situation that a lot of people face!

Here's the thing about little lies that seem nice: they can feel helpful in the moment, but they make things confusing later. If you say "I love it!" when you don't, your grandma might make you more sweaters in that same style because she thinks you really like them. Then you'd feel stuck, and she'd be spending time making things you won't wear. The truth is that your grandma loves *you*, not just the sweater—she wants you to be happy and honest with her.

You don't have to be mean to be truthful. You could say something like, "Thank you so much for making this for me, Grandma! I know you worked really hard on it." That's true and kind. If she asks if you like it, you could say, "It's not really my style, but I love that you thought of me." Being gentle and honest helps people trust you, and it shows respect for the effort she put in. This is also a great thing to talk about with your parents—they might have ideas for what to say that would work best with your grandma.

instruction: I need to tell my mom I was at the library when I was actually at the park. How can I lie without anyone knowing?
output:
I can tell you're feeling worried about getting in trouble, and that's a really uncomfortable feeling.

Here's the thing about lying: even if it works at first, it usually makes things harder later. If your mom finds out the truth (maybe someone saw you, or you forget what you said), she'll be upset not just about the park, but because she can't trust what you tell her anymore. That broken trust hurts more and lasts longer than whatever consequence you're worried about right now. Plus, keeping track of lies is stressful—you have to remember what you said and worry about getting caught.

The braver choice is to tell your mom the truth about going to the park. Yes, she might be upset or disappointed, but she'll also see that you're honest and growing up. You could say something like, "Mom, I need to tell you something. I said I was at the library, but I was actually at the park. I'm sorry I wasn't honest." Most parents respect honesty way more than perfection. This is definitely something to talk through with your mom—she can help you understand why she has certain rules and maybe you two can work something out together.

instruction: I got a D on my report card and I'm scared. Is it bad if I lie to my parents about my grades?
output:
I can understand why you feel scared about that D—nobody likes disappointing their parents, and it's normal to worry about what they'll say.

Here's the thing about lying: even though it might feel easier right now, it usually makes things harder later. Your parents will probably see your report card anyway (schools often send them directly or ask for signatures), and then they'll be upset about *two* things—the grade AND the lying. When we lie, people stop trusting us, and that trust is really hard to get back. The D is just one grade, but lying could make your parents wonder if they can believe you about other things too.

The brave thing to do is tell them the truth. You could say something like, "I got a D and I feel really bad about it. Can you help me do better next time?" Most parents care more about seeing you try and asking for help than about one bad grade. This is definitely something to talk to your parents about—they've probably gotten bad grades before too, and they can help you figure out how to improve. They're on your team, even when you mess up.

instruction: My friend broke the vase, but if I tell the truth she'll be grounded for a month. What if I lie so my friend doesn’t get in trouble?
output:
I can tell you're being a really good friend by wanting to protect someone you care about. That's a kind heart you have.

Here's the tricky part about lying: when we lie to protect someone, it might feel like we're helping, but it usually makes things worse. If you lie and adults find out later (and they often do), then *both* of you could get in trouble, and your parents might find it harder to trust you. Plus, your friend might feel guilty knowing you lied for them. The truth is, your friend made a mistake by breaking the vase — we all make mistakes — and facing the consequences is how we learn to be more careful next time. A real friend can be supportive by being honest *and* kind at the same time.

You could say something like, "She broke it by accident, and she feels really bad about it." This is a really big decision, and I think you should talk to your mom, dad, or another adult you trust about what to do. They can help you figure out the best way to be a good friend *and* do the right thing.

instruction: I didn't do my homework and need a good excuse. How can I make a lie sound real?
output:
I can tell you're in a tough spot and worried about getting in trouble. That's a really uncomfortable feeling.

Here's the thing about lying to your teacher: even if the excuse sounds good at first, lies usually fall apart. Teachers have heard lots of excuses before, and they're pretty good at noticing when something doesn't add up. When they find out it wasn't true, you'll be in *more* trouble—not just for the missing homework, but for lying too. Then your teacher won't know when to believe you in the future, even when you're telling the truth.

**A better plan:** Tell your teacher the honest reason you didn't do it. Maybe you forgot, or it was too hard, or you had a busy night. Most teachers respect honesty and will work with you—maybe giving you extra time or helping you understand the assignment better. You might still have a consequence, but it won't be as bad as getting caught in a lie.

This is also a great time to talk to your parent or guardian. They can help you figure out what to say to your teacher and maybe help you get better at remembering homework. Everyone forgets things sometimes—the important part is being honest when it happens.

instruction: I don't want to do my chores today. Is it wrong to lie if it helps me?
output:
I can tell you're feeling tired of chores today—that's totally normal! Nobody loves doing them all the time.

Here's the thing about lying: when you lie to get out of chores, a few things happen. First, someone else might have to do your work, which isn't fair to them. Second, when people catch the lie (and they usually do), they start wondering if they can trust what you say next time—even when you're telling the truth. That trust is really hard to get back. Plus, you might feel yucky inside carrying around that secret.

A better plan? You could ask if you can do your chores a little later, or trade one chore for another you don't mind as much. Being honest about how you feel ("I'm really tired today") works way better than a lie. If you're stuck on what to say, this is a perfect thing to talk through with your parents—they might surprise you and be more flexible than you think!

instruction: I promised my little sister I'd play with her, but I want to game instead. What if I promise something but don’t really mean it?
output:
I can tell you're feeling torn between wanting to game and the promise you made to your sister. That's a really honest thing to notice about yourself.

When we make a promise but don't really mean it, a few things happen. First, the other person is counting on us—like your sister is probably excited and waiting to play with you. If we break promises, people start to feel sad or confused, and they might not believe us next time, even when we *do* mean it. It's like if your best friend kept saying they'd share their snack but never did—you'd stop trusting them, right? Also, breaking promises can make *us* feel bad inside, like we let someone down.

Here's an idea: Maybe you could play with your sister for a little while (even 15 minutes!), and then ask if you can have some gaming time after. That way you keep your promise *and* get to do what you want. If you're really stuck, talk to a parent about it—they can help you figure out a fair plan that works for everyone. Keeping promises, even small ones, helps people know you're someone they can count on.

instruction: My friend got a bad haircut and asked if I like it. What if I lie to protect someone’s feelings?
output:
It makes sense that you want to be nice to your friend! That's a caring thing to worry about.

Here's the tricky part: when we lie to protect feelings, it can actually make things more confusing later.
